course_programmes: Ancient Studies; Greek and Latin Languages and Cultures
course_paragraphs_json:
["Course Objective
The aim of this course is to acquire a critical knowledge of ancient philosophy. After completing this course successfully, you will:
(1) be able to describe in your own terms the development of ancient philosophy,
(2) have a general knowledge of important schools, thinkers, their theories, and of (ancient) philosophical key terms, and
(3) have trained in analysing and discussing primary philosophical sources (which you will read in translation).", "Course Content
This course covers Greek and Roman philosophy from the 6th century BCE to the 7th century CE, and aims at providing a thematic introduction to the thought of the presocratics, the sophists, Socrates, Plato, Aristotle, Hellenistic and Roman philosophy, and late ancient Neoplatonism and patristic thought. The main themes to be discussed are philosophy of nature, epistemology, ontology, and ethics and politics. These themes will be discussed with the use of primary philosophical sources.", "Additional Information Teaching Methods
Lecture: 4 x 3 hours per week", "Method of Assessment
Formative assessment: reading questions.
Summative assessment: online and in class discussions; written exam. The final grade is determined for 20% by the discussions, for 80% by the exam. A pass (5.5. or more) for both the discussions and the exam are needed to complete the course.
The resit regulations regarding these assignments are specified in the study manual.
This course is part of the learning path Academic Skills of the BA Classics and Ancient Studies programmes. Its students will be specifically trained and tested in discussion skills.", "Literature
Literature (primary sources) will be made available via Canvas.", "Additional Information Target Audience
This course is part of the first year of the bachelors Classics and Ancient Studies, but is also accessible to other students. No prior knowledge is required.", "Additional Information
This course is part of a joined programme by the Vrije Universiteit Amsterdam (VU) and the University of Amsterdam (UvA). It is taught at a UvA location. For the course schedule see https://rooster.uva.nl/", "Custom Course Registration
First year ACASA students are automatically placed. Other students can register for this course via UvA https://glass.uva.nl
VU students who would like to follow this course as an elective need to request a guest registration at the UvA. See for more information: https://www.uva.nl/en/education/other-programmes/electives/electives.html
Please note:
Course registration periods between VU and UvA differ.
This course is scheduled at the University of Amsterdam."]
course_objective:
The aim of this course is to acquire a critical knowledge of ancient philosophy. After completing this course successfully, you will:
(1) be able to describe in your own terms the development of ancient philosophy,
(2) have a general knowledge of important schools, thinkers, their theories, and of (ancient) philosophical key terms, and
(3) have trained in analysing and discussing primary philosophical sources (which you will read in translation).
course_content: This course covers Greek and Roman philosophy from the 6th century BCE to the 7th century CE, and aims at providing a thematic introduction to the thought of the presocratics, the sophists, Socrates, Plato, Aristotle, Hellenistic and Roman philosophy, and late ancient Neoplatonism and patristic thought. The main themes to be discussed are philosophy of nature, epistemology, ontology, and ethics and politics. These themes will be discussed with the use of primary philosophical sources.
additional_information_teaching_methods: Lecture: 4 x 3 hours per week
method_of_assessment:
Formative assessment: reading questions.
Summative assessment: online and in class discussions; written exam. The final grade is determined for 20% by the discussions, for 80% by the exam. A pass (5.5. or more) for both the discussions and the exam are needed to complete the course.
The resit regulations regarding these assignments are specified in the study manual.
This course is part of the learning path Academic Skills of the BA Classics and Ancient Studies programmes. Its students will be specifically trained and tested in discussion skills.
literature: Literature (primary sources) will be made available via Canvas.
additional_information_target_audience: This course is part of the first year of the bachelors Classics and Ancient Studies, but is also accessible to other students. No prior knowledge is required.

course_paragraphs_json:
["Course Objective
Around the Mediterranean, people from many different cultures and three different continents interacted with each other like (in Plato's words) "frogs around a pond". Cultural contacts are a main theme in the BA programme Ancient Studies. In this course, we try to understand these contacts and the Mediterranean interconnectedness or ‘connectivity’ resulting from it. What forms of contact were there? How far did they extend? What traces did they leave in the historical and material sources? What were the driving factors? What was their effect?
After completing this course, you are able to
identify and summarize the essential viewpoints dealt with in a number of (inter)disciplinary studies in the field of cultural contact and connectivity
reflect on these viewpoints and position yourself in the debate, and develop your own arguments on synchronous and diachronous cultural interactions
formulate research questions from an interdisciplinary approach and select the appropriate research strategies for solving these questions
combine textual and material sources and critically evaluate their respective contributions to research questions
report on your research findings in writing in a consistent, clear and concise manner", "Course Content
In this course, we will discuss and reflect on a selection of cases, which document various interactions within the Mediterranean or between inhabitants of the Mediterranean world and Europe from the Bronze age to late antiquity: e.g. Bronze Age trade networks; sanctuaries as Panhellenic meeting points; travel in the Roman world. Next to cases studies, we focus on various theoretical angles and discuss how the academic debate about cultural contacts has developed over the last 50 years.", "Additional Information Teaching Methods
The sessions will combine introductory lectures by the lecturers with student-led discussions of the literature and assignments to train research skills, which include both in-class exercises and formal assignments.", "Method of Assessment
Participation (includes active participation in discussions in class + submission of formative assignments; pass/fail)
In week 39 students produce a theoretical introduction based on the literature discussed in weeks 37-39 (pass/fail)
Academic paper of ca. 2500 words: 100% of final grade
This course is part of the learning path Academic Skills of the BA Ancient Studies programme. In this course, students of this programme will be specifically trained and tested in formulating research questions and writing skills.
A student passes when all assignments are completed, the paper has a grade of 5,5 or higher, and the total grade (determined by exam and paper) is 5,5 or higher. The resit regulations regarding the assignments are specified in the study manual.", "Literature
Reader (in CANVAS).", "Additional Information Target Audience
BA-students Oudheidwetenschappen / Ancient Studies", "Additional Information
Max. 40 participants.
This course is part of a joined programme by the Vrije Universiteit Amsterdam (VU) and the University of Amsterdam (UvA). It is taught at a UvA location. For the course schedule see https://rooster.uva.nl/", "Custom Course Registration
ACASA students must register via UvA https://glass.uva.nl
VU students who would like to follow this course as an elective need to request a guest registration at the UvA. See for more information: https://www.uva.nl/en/education/other-programmes/electives/electives.html
Please note:
Course registration periods between VU and UvA differ.
This course is scheduled at the University of Amsterdam.", "Recommended background knowledge
This course is part of the learning path Academic Skills of the BA Ancient Studies programme. In this course, students of this programme will be specifically trained and tested in formulating research questions and writing skills.
A student passes when all assignments are completed, the paper has a grade of 5,5 or higher, and the total grade (determined by exam and paper) is 5,5 or higher. The resit regulations regarding the assignments are specified in the study manual."]
course_objective:
Around the Mediterranean, people from many different cultures and three different continents interacted with each other like (in Plato's words) "frogs around a pond". Cultural contacts are a main theme in the BA programme Ancient Studies. In this course, we try to understand these contacts and the Mediterranean interconnectedness or ‘connectivity’ resulting from it. What forms of contact were there? How far did they extend? What traces did they leave in the historical and material sources? What were the driving factors? What was their effect?
After completing this course, you are able to
identify and summarize the essential viewpoints dealt with in a number of (inter)disciplinary studies in the field of cultural contact and connectivity
reflect on these viewpoints and position yourself in the debate, and develop your own arguments on synchronous and diachronous cultural interactions
formulate research questions from an interdisciplinary approach and select the appropriate research strategies for solving these questions
combine textual and material sources and critically evaluate their respective contributions to research questions
report on your research findings in writing in a consistent, clear and concise manner
course_content: In this course, we will discuss and reflect on a selection of cases, which document various interactions within the Mediterranean or between inhabitants of the Mediterranean world and Europe from the Bronze age to late antiquity: e.g. Bronze Age trade networks; sanctuaries as Panhellenic meeting points; travel in the Roman world. Next to cases studies, we focus on various theoretical angles and discuss how the academic debate about cultural contacts has developed over the last 50 years.
additional_information_teaching_methods: The sessions will combine introductory lectures by the lecturers with student-led discussions of the literature and assignments to train research skills, which include both in-class exercises and formal assignments.
method_of_assessment:
Participation (includes active participation in discussions in class + submission of formative assignments; pass/fail)
In week 39 students produce a theoretical introduction based on the literature discussed in weeks 37-39 (pass/fail)
Academic paper of ca. 2500 words: 100% of final grade
This course is part of the learning path Academic Skills of the BA Ancient Studies programme. In this course, students of this programme will be specifically trained and tested in formulating research questions and writing skills.
A student passes when all assignments are completed, the paper has a grade of 5,5 or higher, and the total grade (determined by exam and paper) is 5,5 or higher. The resit regulations regarding the assignments are specified in the study manual.
literature: Reader (in CANVAS).
additional_information_target_audience: BA-students Oudheidwetenschappen / Ancient Studies

course_programmes: Ancient Studies; Archaeology; Greek and Latin Languages and Cultures
course_paragraphs_json:
["Course Objective
After successfully completing this course, all students
Are able to apply basic concepts and theories from the philosophy of science to the humanities in general and to their own specific discipline, and to use them in critically assessing studies relevant to their own disciplines
Have acquired an overview of the historical development and the most important theoretical approaches of the humanities and of their own specific disciplines
Are able to evaluate the limitations and possibilities of specific disciplinary and interdisciplinary approaches in relation to research questions within their own disciplines
Are able to analyze philosophical and theoretical texts relevant to their own discipline, and to relate the concepts involved to their own disciplines
Have practiced discussing philosophical and theoretical concepts during the seminars. They are able to evaluate research papers related to their own discipline from a theoretical/methodological point of view and to form an opinion/take a position in discussions about this among peers.
Have practiced academic writing skills and processing feedback while completing the weekly seminar assignments and leading up to the final assignment. They can reflect critically in writing on the research papers they have read and processed.
GLTC-students (and Ancient Studies students specializing in either Latin or Greek) have gained practical experience with codicology, paleography, text-criticism and literary criticism and are able to reflect critically on methods and theoretical viewpoints in these domains.", "Course Content
Modern academic disciplines are shaped and structured by philosophical concepts and doctrines. This course provides an overview of the history of philosophical thoughts and of philosophical debates about methodology, and their relevance to discussions of methodology, interdisciplinarity, and resource use in philology, cultural history, and archeology of antiquity.
The general theoretical and methodological issues that form the basis of the historical development of science and humanities will be related to the study of the past through texts and material culture. Disciplinary and interdisciplinary approaches will be discussed, with special attention to both limitations and possibilities.
This course consists of one lecture and one seminar per week. The lectures are taught by a lecturer of the Department of Philosophy, on the base of a handbook. The seminars are taught by a lecturer from ACASA, and devoted to the discussion of a selection of key themes and relevant articles. Students will be trained in the close reading of philosophical texts that are crucial to the way their (inter)discipline organizes, produces, and structures knowledge.
Students in the programmes of GLTC and Ancient Studies students specializing in either Latin or Greek follow a different seminar, in which the historical developments of the humanities disciplines are more specifically connected to the field of classics. They will focus on (and practice) paleography, text criticism and literary theory.", "Additional Information Teaching Methods
Weekly lectures (2 hours/week); weekly seminars (2 hours/week)", "Method of Assessment
There will be a written exam for all students based on the handbook and the lectures. (50% of final grade)
In the seminars, the students will work in groups towards a written essay/final assignment (50% of final grade), which is prepared for by means of weekly partial assignments.
The resit regulations will be specified in the study manual.", "Literature
Gerard de Vries & Michiel Leezenberg, History and Philosophy of the Humanities: An Introduction. Amsterdam: Amsterdam University Press, 2018. (paperback ISBN: 9789462987630 ; also available as e-book)
Additional literature will be made available during the course", "Additional Information Target Audience
This course is for second year BA students of Archaeology (ARCH), Classics (GLTC), and Ancient Studies (OHW).", "Additional Information
This course is part of a joined programme by the Vrije Universiteit Amsterdam (VU) and the University of Amsterdam (UvA). It is taught at a UvA location. For the course schedule see https://rooster.uva.nl/", "Custom Course Registration
ACASA students must register via UvA https://glass.uva.nl
This course is not open for elective students.
Please note:
Course registration periods between VU and UvA differ.
This course is scheduled at the University of Amsterdam."]
course_objective:
After successfully completing this course, all students
Are able to apply basic concepts and theories from the philosophy of science to the humanities in general and to their own specific discipline, and to use them in critically assessing studies relevant to their own disciplines
Have acquired an overview of the historical development and the most important theoretical approaches of the humanities and of their own specific disciplines
Are able to evaluate the limitations and possibilities of specific disciplinary and interdisciplinary approaches in relation to research questions within their own disciplines
Are able to analyze philosophical and theoretical texts relevant to their own discipline, and to relate the concepts involved to their own disciplines
Have practiced discussing philosophical and theoretical concepts during the seminars. They are able to evaluate research papers related to their own discipline from a theoretical/methodological point of view and to form an opinion/take a position in discussions about this among peers.
Have practiced academic writing skills and processing feedback while completing the weekly seminar assignments and leading up to the final assignment. They can reflect critically in writing on the research papers they have read and processed.
GLTC-students (and Ancient Studies students specializing in either Latin or Greek) have gained practical experience with codicology, paleography, text-criticism and literary criticism and are able to reflect critically on methods and theoretical viewpoints in these domains.
course_content:
Modern academic disciplines are shaped and structured by philosophical concepts and doctrines. This course provides an overview of the history of philosophical thoughts and of philosophical debates about methodology, and their relevance to discussions of methodology, interdisciplinarity, and resource use in philology, cultural history, and archeology of antiquity.
The general theoretical and methodological issues that form the basis of the historical development of science and humanities will be related to the study of the past through texts and material culture. Disciplinary and interdisciplinary approaches will be discussed, with special attention to both limitations and possibilities.
This course consists of one lecture and one seminar per week. The lectures are taught by a lecturer of the Department of Philosophy, on the base of a handbook. The seminars are taught by a lecturer from ACASA, and devoted to the discussion of a selection of key themes and relevant articles. Students will be trained in the close reading of philosophical texts that are crucial to the way their (inter)discipline organizes, produces, and structures knowledge.
Students in the programmes of GLTC and Ancient Studies students specializing in either Latin or Greek follow a different seminar, in which the historical developments of the humanities disciplines are more specifically connected to the field of classics. They will focus on (and practice) paleography, text criticism and literary theory.
additional_information_teaching_methods: Weekly lectures (2 hours/week); weekly seminars (2 hours/week)
method_of_assessment:
There will be a written exam for all students based on the handbook and the lectures. (50% of final grade)
In the seminars, the students will work in groups towards a written essay/final assignment (50% of final grade), which is prepared for by means of weekly partial assignments.
The resit regulations will be specified in the study manual.
literature:
Gerard de Vries & Michiel Leezenberg, History and Philosophy of the Humanities: An Introduction. Amsterdam: Amsterdam University Press, 2018. (paperback ISBN: 9789462987630 ; also available as e-book)
Additional literature will be made available during the course
additional_information_target_audience: This course is for second year BA students of Archaeology (ARCH), Classics (GLTC), and Ancient Studies (OHW).

course_programmes: Ancient Studies; Archaeology; Communication and Information Studies; Greek and Latin Languages and Cultures; History; Literature and Society; Media, Art, Design and Architecture; Philosophy
course_paragraphs_json:
["Course Objective
After successfully completing the course, students:
have mastered the main characteristics of the religions of the ancient Middle-East (Mesopotamia and the Levant) and of the ancient Greek and Roman worlds;
have a basic knowledge of the deities, religious life, rituals, and customs in said regions, as well as of their possible interconnections;
can recognize various theoretical approaches towards religion in the scholarly literature and apply these;
are familiar with the material and written sources and their problems;
have insights into the embeddedness of religion in the ancient societies under consideration.", "Course Content
This course treats the main characteristics of, and approaches to, religion in the ancient Middle-East and the Greek and Roman worlds. The lectures give an overview of the deities, religious life, rituals, and customs in each of these regions, with attention for possible interconnections. In discussing the various theoretical approaches towards religion, students will learn the - often implicit - theoretical assumptions in the scholarly literature, and gain insight into the coherence between religious changes and societal developments.", "Additional Information Teaching Methods
Lectures.", "Method of Assessment
Written exam (graded on a scale of 1-10). Students pass with a score of 5.5 or higher.", "Literature
The mandatory literature will be announced on CANVAS.", "Additional Information Target Audience
Second year students of Ancient Studies (Oudheidwetenschappen)
Students of the --> Minor in Highlights of the Ancient World
Students of the minor Ancient Near Eastern Languages and Culture
Students from other disciplines who wish to take the course as an elective; especially suitable for Religion and Humanities students. note that a basic knowledge of the ancient world is expected.", "Additional Information
Please note that this is an intensive course. With 3-hour classes in the afternoon, you should be able to dedicate all remaining time to reading the mandatory literature and work on trial questions. N.B. When the text in the study guide is different from that of the course manual, the course manual is valid.
This course is part of a joined programme by the Vrije Universiteit Amsterdam (VU) and the University of Amsterdam (UvA). It is taught at a UvA location. For the course schedule see https://rooster.uva.nl/", "Custom Course Registration
ACASA students must register via UvA https://glass.uva.nl
VU students who would like to follow this course as an elective need to request a guest registration at the UvA. See for more information: https://www.uva.nl/en/education/other-programmes/electives/electives.html
Please note:
Course registration periods between VU and UvA differ.
This course is scheduled at the University of Amsterdam", "Explanation Canvas
All communication about the course takes place via Canvas.", "Recommended background knowledge
There are no formal entry requirements, but a basic knowledge of the history and material culture of the Ancient World and its cultures is expected. Recommended literature in case of deficiencies:
(Ancient Middle-East) - Blois, L. de & R.J. van der Spek, 2019, An Introduction to the Ancient World, 3rd edition, London/New York. Chapters 1-7 (excluding Egypt)
(Greek world) - Barringer, J.M. 2015, The Art and Archaeology of Ancient Greece, Cambridge. Chapters 3-4.
(Roman world) Rüpke, J., 2007. Religion of the Romans, Cambridge/Malden MA. Chapters 7-8."]
course_content: This course treats the main characteristics of, and approaches to, religion in the ancient Middle-East and the Greek and Roman worlds. The lectures give an overview of the deities, religious life, rituals, and customs in each of these regions, with attention for possible interconnections. In discussing the various theoretical approaches towards religion, students will learn the - often implicit - theoretical assumptions in the scholarly literature, and gain insight into the coherence between religious changes and societal developments.
additional_information_teaching_methods: Lectures.
method_of_assessment: Written exam (graded on a scale of 1-10). Students pass with a score of 5.5 or higher.

Students of the --> Minor in Highlights of the Ancient World
Students of the minor Ancient Near Eastern Languages and Culture
Students from other disciplines who wish to take the course as an elective; especially suitable for Religion and Humanities students. note that a basic knowledge of the ancient world is expected.

course_programmes: Ancient Studies; Archaeology; Greek and Latin Languages and Cultures
course_paragraphs_json:
["Course Objective
In this course you will learn to study material and immaterial culture in an integrated way. Attention is paid to material / (cultural) historical, textual and Nachleben- and heritage-related aspects. You visit sites, monuments and museums that are linked to the central theme(s) of the excursion. course_name: Past and Present: Critical Approaches to Antiquity and Archaeological Heritage
course_paragraphs_json:
["Course Objective
After successful completion of this course, you will:
Have broadened your knowledge of antiquity and heritage
Have acquired basic knowledge of the theoretical foundations of the field of heritage studies and its relation to antiquity and archaeology
Have gained a basic knowledge of the practice and structure of heritage management, both nationally (the Netherlands) and internationally
Understand the ideological, political, social and economic values related to the heritage of antiquity and their interaction
Be able to develop a theoretical and practical heritage plan for (tangible or intangible) remains from the past", "Course Content
In this course you are made familiar with the main academic, political and public debates regarding heritage studies and practice. Emphasis will be on the identification of different heritage categories (tangible and intangible) and above all heritage paradigms, from protectionist and conservationist traditions to developmental approaches focusing on the contribution of heritage to socioeconomic and spatial development. In particular, we will explore in this course how these categories and paradigms have relevance for the study of antiquity and archaeology. Central concepts which will be addressed are: heritage, landscape, value, authenticity, appropriation, public participation, conflict, tourism. These will be illustrated and explained through a series of case studies in seminar classes. Particular attention will be paid to the specific role of archaeological heritage in the broader heritage discourse and frameworks.", "Additional Information Teaching Methods
In the first two weeks, there are four classes on a specific theme on a theoretical and practical level. For each class, there will be compulsory reading made available through the Canvas site. Each class will consist of a lecture (ca 1 hr) followed by group discussions.
In the third week, there will be no class, but you are supposed to work on the assignment: make an application document for a topic on the ACASA Heritage List.
In the fourth-seventh week the first classes of the week will be regular classes on a specific theme, with assigned compulsory reading. The second classes will be devoted to pitches for the ACASA Heritage List. At the end of these classes, we will vote which topics should be on the ACASA Heritage List. The final vote for the definitive ACASA Heritage List will be done in the last class, followed by discussion.", "Method of Assessment
The compulsory literature will be assessed by a weekly exam question that you will have to submit through the canvas page (completed/ non-completed).
Each student will work out a specific case-study for the ACASA Heritage List. In a pitch of 5-7 minutes, you will present your case (graded). Moreover, you will be asked to react to pitches of your fellow students (non-graded). In case of a student failing this part of the course, an additional extended paper on a different topic will need to be submitted.
In every class, there will be discussion and the final class will be a discussion class. The participation in the discussion will be assessed (completed/ non-completed).
This course is part of the learning path Academic Skills of the BA programmes Archaeology and Ancient Studies (Oudheidwetenschappen). In this course, students of these programmes will be specifically trained and tested in oral presentations (pitches) and in adapting their presentations to a non-specialist audience.
Attendance
It is highly recommended that you attend all discussion classes in order to pass the exam. Attendance is compulsory for the seminar classes in which pitches are presented. In case you miss a seminar, a full point is deducted from the final grade.
For regulations concerning resitting the exams/assignments see the course manual.
Hours to be spent
A total of 140 hours is expected to be spent on the course divided in the following manner:
Reading and studying compulsory literature: 10 hours per week = 60 hours
Attending classes: 3 hours a week: 18 hrs
Preparing Application Document: 20 hrs
Pitch and discussion preparation: 22 hrs
Preparing for participation in final discussion: 20 hrs", "Literature
Articles for the lecture classes will be made available through the CANVAS page", "Additional Information Target Audience
BA students in Archaeology
BA students in Ancient Studies
BA students in Cultural Heritage
BA students in Urban studies and Geography
BA students of the Saxion University of Applied Sciences who follow the preparatory minor ('Doorstroomminor') Archaeology", "Additional Information
This course is part of a joined programme by the Vrije Universiteit Amsterdam (VU) and the University of Amsterdam (UvA). It is taught at a UvA location. For the course schedule see https://rooster.uva.nl/", "Custom Course Registration
ACASA students must register via UvA https://glass.uva.nl
VU students who would like to follow this course as an elective need to request a guest registration at the UvA. See for more information: https://www.uva.nl/en/education/other-programmes/electives/electives.html
Please note:
Course registration periods between VU and UvA differ.
This course is scheduled at the University of Amsterdam.", "Explanation Canvas
Please consult Canvas before the teaching block starts."]

Emphasis will be on the identification of different heritage categories (tangible and intangible) and above all heritage paradigms, from protectionist and conservationist traditions to developmental approaches focusing on the contribution of heritage to socioeconomic and spatial development. Attendance
It is highly recommended that you attend all discussion classes in order to pass the exam. Attendance is compulsory for the seminar classes in which pitches are presented. In case you miss a seminar, a full point is deducted from the final grade.
For regulations concerning resitting the exams/assignments see the course manual.
Hours to be spent
A total of 140 hours is expected to be spent on the course divided in the following manner:

Attending classes: 3 hours a week: 18 hrs

course_name: The Classical Canon 2: The Sociology of Cultural Selection
course_paragraphs_json:
["Course Objective
Expanding your knowledge of diverse forms of the classical canon from Antiquity to the present day
Acquiring knowledge of diverse scholarly explanations of content, context, causes and functions of cultural selections concerning the formation of classical canons
Application of diverse models from the sociology of culture to specific historical contexts including the present
Identification of both general and specific processes of canon formation and shifts of canon
Critical reflection on significance and value of the concept ‘canon’ and related concepts such as ‘classics’, ‘classicism’, ‘renaissance’ from the perspective of cultural philosophy and sociology
Development of writing skills", "Course Content
The module The Classical Canon 2: The Sociology of Cultural Selection in Theory and Practice is a sequel of the 1st-year module The Classical Canon I: The Heritage of Antiquity. While in that first course the emphasis was on the question ‘of what does the canon consist?’, more abstract problems related to canons and their historical role and function now follow. In the course of this module our attention will be on the particular reasons, sociological and historical, why canons have come into existence, how they developed and evolved through time and which canons have been most influential and why. These aspects will be studied in two ways: on the one hand we browse chronologically through a series of decisive moments in canon formation, from antiquity to the present day; on the other hand we will present a representative selection of theoretical concepts – from philosophy, sociology and art history – that will enable you to gain insights into content and function of canons and the mechanisms of cultural selection. The course will lead us from Roman antiquity to the Middle Ages, the Renaissance, Winckelmann and the 18th and 19th centuries CE to the 'culture wars' of recent decades.", "Additional Information Teaching Methods
Lectures/seminars (2 sessions of 2 hours per week; all sessions mandatory, as specified on Canvas).", "Method of Assessment
Different kinds of written assignment, including two short papers.
All assignments are mandatory. Grading is on a scale of 1 to 10. You will pass the course with a final grade of 5.5 or higher and a grade of 5.5 or higher for your paper(s). If your paper(s) - and hence your final grade - prove to be insufficient, there are two possible ways of remedying this. The first possibility is to use the feedback provided by the instructors and to improve your original essay; in this case, your final grade for the essay cannot be higher than 6. The second possibility is to write a new essay, on a new topic; in this case no maximum score is set for your second effort. The other assignments cannot be redone.
This course is part of the learning path Academic Skills of the BA Ancient Studies programme. In this course, students of this programme will be specifically trained and tested in writing skills.", "Entry Requirements
See under Target audience. A basis knowledge of Mediterranean antiquity is needed.", "Literature
Relevant literature via CANVAS.", "Additional Information Target Audience
2nd year students Ancient Studies (Oudheidwetenschappen).
The course is open as an elective, preferably but not exclusively for students who have completed the first year of a humanities programme. Elective students are asked to consult the coordinator prior to registration.", "Additional Information
The course is open as an elective, preferably but not exclusively for students who have completed the first year of a humanities programme. Elective students are asked to consult the coordinator prior to registration.
This course is part of a joined programme by the Vrije Universiteit Amsterdam (VU) and the University of Amsterdam (UvA). It is taught at a UvA location. For the course schedule see https://rooster.uva.nl/", "Custom Course Registration
ACASA students must register via UvA https://glass.uva.nl
VU students who would like to follow this course as an elective need to request a guest registration at the UvA. See for more information: https://www.uva.nl/en/education/other-programmes/electives/electives.html
Please note:
Course registration periods between VU and UvA differ.
This course is scheduled at the University of Amsterdam.", "Recommended background knowledge
See under Target audience. A basis knowledge of Mediterranean antiquity is needed."]
course_objective:
Expanding your knowledge of diverse forms of the classical canon from Antiquity to the present day
Acquiring knowledge of diverse scholarly explanations of content, context, causes and functions of cultural selections concerning the formation of classical canons
Application of diverse models from the sociology of culture to specific historical contexts including the present
Identification of both general and specific processes of canon formation and shifts of canon
Critical reflection on significance and value of the concept ‘canon’ and related concepts such as ‘classics’, ‘classicism’, ‘renaissance’ from the perspective of cultural philosophy and sociology
Development of writing skills
course_content: The module The Classical Canon 2: The Sociology of Cultural Selection in Theory and Practice is a sequel of the 1st-year module The Classical Canon I: The Heritage of Antiquity. While in that first course the emphasis was on the question ‘of what does the canon consist?’, more abstract problems related to canons and their historical role and function now follow. In the course of this module our attention will be on the particular reasons, sociological and historical, why canons have come into existence, how they developed and evolved through time and which canons have been most influential and why. These aspects will be studied in two ways: on the one hand we browse chronologically through a series of decisive moments in canon formation, from antiquity to the present day; on the other hand we will present a representative selection of theoretical concepts – from philosophy, sociology and art history – that will enable you to gain insights into content and function of canons and the mechanisms of cultural selection. The course will lead us from Roman antiquity to the Middle Ages, the Renaissance, Winckelmann and the 18th and 19th centuries CE to the 'culture wars' of recent decades.
additional_information_teaching_methods: Lectures/seminars (2 sessions of 2 hours per week; all sessions mandatory, as specified on Canvas).
method_of_assessment:
Different kinds of written assignment, including two short papers.
All assignments are mandatory. Grading is on a scale of 1 to 10. You will pass the course with a final grade of 5.5 or higher and a grade of 5.5 or higher for your paper(s). If your paper(s) - and hence your final grade - prove to be insufficient, there are two possible ways of remedying this. The first possibility is to use the feedback provided by the instructors and to improve your original essay; in this case, your final grade for the essay cannot be higher than 6. The second possibility is to write a new essay, on a new topic; in this case no maximum score is set for your second effort. The other assignments cannot be redone.
This course is part of the learning path Academic Skills of the BA Ancient Studies programme. In this course, students of this programme will be specifically trained and tested in writing skills.

course_paragraphs_json:
["Course Objective
In this course students
Become familiar with creative writing as a discipline and an art form
Study examples of creative reception of the material and textual heritage of the ancient world, and reflect on their cultural-historical context
Learn how to read and write fiction, poetry, and/or (creative) non-fiction about topics related to the ancient world with a wider, non-specialist audience in mind, and identify how and where these audiences can be found", "Course Content
Students attend lectures on the general principles of reception theory as well as the forms and conventions of creative writing, and discuss examples of ways in which the heritage of the ancient world can be brought under the attention of a wider, non-specialist audience. In subsequent, intensive writing clinics, they develop their creative writing and revision skills, which they further practice in writing workshops. For their final assignment, they choose a reception topic (e.g. from the ACASA heritage list), reflect upon an appropriate form to engage a wider, non-specialist audience, and display creativity and originality in exploring that topic within their chosen form. They present their final assignment to their fellow students.", "Additional Information Teaching Methods
Students attend two lectures on the reception of the ancient world, on top of a general introduction into the art of creative writing. In the second and third week, students will attend writing clinics with plenary sessions and break-out sessions in peer-groups. In the fourth week, students finish and present their final assignments.", "Method of Assessment
Attendance of the lectures, clinics and presentations (conditions met/not met)
Participation in discussion and feedback in the writing clinics and peer-groups (conditions met/not met)
Final creative writing assignment (graded, 100%)
Presentation of creative writing assignment (conditions met/not met)
This course is part of the learning path Academic Skills of the BA Ancient Studies programme. In subsequent, intensive writing clinics, they develop their creative writing and revision skills, which they further practice in writing workshops. course_name: History and Culture of the Ancient Near East
course_programmes: Ancient Studies; Archaeology; Communication and Information Studies; Greek and Latin Languages and Cultures; History; Literature and Society; Media, Art, Design and Architecture; Philosophy
course_paragraphs_json:
["Course Objective
This course aims to:
introduce students to the material and non-material heritage of the ancient Near East using methodologies developed in archaeology and Assyriology
survey the major periods of Mesopotamian history by examining artifacts that have survived in the material record, key episodes and interpretive models proposed by modern scholars
teach students how to make well-grounded arguments based on the interpretation of ancient texts and artifacts
encourage students to reflect critically on how historians reconstruct the ancient past by using diverse types of evidence", "Course Content
Ancient Mesopotamia was the birthplace of some of the most important developments in human history. The first cities and empires, the earliest writings, the origins of mathematics, chemistry and astronomy: many of the ideas and worldviews that have shaped western civilization have their roots in the ancient Near East, and more particularly, in Mesopotamia. This course explores the cultures of present-day Iraq, Syria, Turkey and Iran from the Neolithic (ca. 10,000 BCE) to the end of the Achaemenid period (ca. 330 BCE). Students will learn about the rich history of this region through its literature, its art and its architecture. Topics to be covered include: early complex societies, state formation and political organization, religion, ethnicity, trade, diplomacy and warfare, family life, the position of women in society and crafts.", "Additional Information Teaching Methods
Lectures, given twice a week. If the course is given online, some classes may be provided as pre-recorded lectures. Attendance is mandatory.", "Method of Assessment
Written exam.
Students following the Ancient Near East track and who have already taken Elementary Akkadian 1 and 2, will complete a selection of short translation exercises (30% of grade) in addition to the final exam (70% of grade).
The resit regulations regarding the assignments are specified in the study manual.", "Literature
Course textbook: van de Mieroop, Marc. 2016. A History of the Ancient Near East, ca. 3000–323 BC (3rd ed.). Chichester UK; Malden MA.
Additional literature and study material will be provided via Canvas.", "Additional Information Target Audience
Target audience:
BA2 students of Ancient Studies with specialisation Ancient History;
BA2 students of Ancient Studies with specialisation Ancient Near Eastern Studies;
Other interested students can take the course as an elective."]
course_objective:
This course aims to:
introduce students to the material and non-material heritage of the ancient Near East using methodologies developed in archaeology and Assyriology
survey the major periods of Mesopotamian history by examining artifacts that have survived in the material record, key episodes and interpretive models proposed by modern scholars
teach students how to make well-grounded arguments based on the interpretation of ancient texts and artifacts
encourage students to reflect critically on how historians reconstruct the ancient past by using diverse types of evidence
course_content: Ancient Mesopotamia was the birthplace of some of the most important developments in human history. The first cities and empires, the earliest writings, the origins of mathematics, chemistry and astronomy: many of the ideas and worldviews that have shaped western civilization have their roots in the ancient Near East, and more particularly, in Mesopotamia. This course explores the cultures of present-day Iraq, Syria, Turkey and Iran from the Neolithic (ca. 10,000 BCE) to the end of the Achaemenid period (ca. 330 BCE). Students will learn about the rich history of this region through its literature, its art and its architecture. Topics to be covered include: early complex societies, state formation and political organization, religion, ethnicity, trade, diplomacy and warfare, family life, the position of women in society and crafts.
additional_information_teaching_methods: Lectures, given twice a week. If the course is given online, some classes may be provided as pre-recorded lectures. Attendance is mandatory.
method_of_assessment:
Written exam.
Students following the Ancient Near East track and who have already taken Elementary Akkadian 1 and 2, will complete a selection of short translation exercises (30% of grade) in addition to the final exam (70% of grade).
The resit regulations regarding the assignments are specified in the study manual.
literature:
Course textbook: van de Mieroop, Marc. 2016. A History of the Ancient Near East, ca. 3000–323 BC (3rd ed.). Chichester UK; Malden MA.
Additional literature and study material will be provided via Canvas.

course_name: Archaeology of the Ancient Near East
course_programmes: Ancient Studies; Archaeology; Communication and Information Studies; Greek and Latin Languages and Cultures; History; Literature and Society; Media, Art, Design and Architecture; Philosophy
course_paragraphs_json:
["Course Objective
Upon completion of this course you will have:
Acquired a general knowledge of the main cultural and historical developments of the Near East between the 10th and 1st millennia BC, from an archaeological perspective
Acquired an understanding of the datasets, theories and approaches that characterize the field of Near Eastern archaeology
The ability to formulate a relevant research question and construct a basic research design to investigate a topic of your choice within the discipline", "Course Content
The region of West Asia that in western scholarship is traditionally called the Near East has seen many cultural developments in antiquity that have had a global impact and continue to shape our world today. They include the earliest sedentary farming societies, metallurgy, urbanism, writing and administration, states and empires. Archaeology has played a major role in rediscovering the cultural significance of the ancient Near East, in addition to Biblical scholarship and cuneiform studies, and continues to do so. This course introduces you to the ancient Near East from an archaeological perspective, focusing on developments in the Fertile Crescent and Mesopotamia. It discusses the datasets, theories and approaches that characterize the field of Near Eastern archaeology, and challenges you to think about how new research could expand and improve our knowledge about the ancient Near East. The course consists of 1) an archaeology-based overview of the societies and cultures of the Ancient Near East, and 2) a presentation and further discussion of several themes related to sedentism and food production, ancient urbanism and town-countryside relationships, including power and monumentality, food supply system, and administration.", "Additional Information Teaching Methods
Lecture classes and discussion classes.", "Method of Assessment
Assignments (written and oral) (25%), written exam (75%).
The resit regulations will be specified in the study manual.", "Literature
Matthews, R. 2003: The Archaeology of Mesopotamia. Theories and Approaches, London: Routledge;
Additional literature (scholarly articles and excavation reports).", "Additional Information Target Audience
Target audience:
BA2 students of Ancient Studies who specialize in Ancient Near Eastern Studies
Students of the minor Ancient Near Eastern Languages and Cultures
Interested students of archaeology, (ancient) history, assyriology, classics or other disciplines who wish to take the course as an elective.", "Recommended background knowledge
This course is designed primarily for students who have taken the course History and Culture of the Ancient Near East, or a similar introductory course. Students without this background knowledge are accepted in the course but are advised to do some independent background reading to gain a basic knowledge of the main historical periods and associated cultures. Marc van de Mieroop's A History of the Ancient Near East is recommended."]
course_objective:
Upon completion of this course you will have:
Acquired a general knowledge of the main cultural and historical developments of the Near East between the 10th and 1st millennia BC, from an archaeological perspective
Acquired an understanding of the datasets, theories and approaches that characterize the field of Near Eastern archaeology
The ability to formulate a relevant research question and construct a basic research design to investigate a topic of your choice within the discipline
course_content: The region of West Asia that in western scholarship is traditionally called the Near East has seen many cultural developments in antiquity that have had a global impact and continue to shape our world today. They include the earliest sedentary farming societies, metallurgy, urbanism, writing and administration, states and empires. Archaeology has played a major role in rediscovering the cultural significance of the ancient Near East, in addition to Biblical scholarship and cuneiform studies, and continues to do so. This course introduces you to the ancient Near East from an archaeological perspective, focusing on developments in the Fertile Crescent and Mesopotamia. It discusses the datasets, theories and approaches that characterize the field of Near Eastern archaeology, and challenges you to think about how new research could expand and improve our knowledge about the ancient Near East. The course consists of 1) an archaeology-based overview of the societies and cultures of the Ancient Near East, and 2) a presentation and further discussion of several themes related to sedentism and food production, ancient urbanism and town-countryside relationships, including power and monumentality, food supply system, and administration.
additional_information_teaching_methods: Lecture classes and discussion classes.
method_of_assessment:
Assignments (written and oral) (25%), written exam (75%).
The resit regulations will be specified in the study manual.
literature:
Matthews, R. 2003: The Archaeology of Mesopotamia. Theories and Approaches, London: Routledge;
Additional literature (scholarly articles and excavation reports).
additional_information_target_audience:
Target audience:
BA2 students of Ancient Studies who specialize in Ancient Near Eastern Studies
Students of the minor Ancient Near Eastern Languages and Cultures
Interested students of archaeology, (ancient) history, assyriology, classics or other disciplines who wish to take the course as an elective.
recommended_background_knowledge: This course is designed primarily for students who have taken the course History and Culture of the Ancient Near East, or a similar introductory course. Students without this background knowledge are accepted in the course but are advised to do some independent background reading to gain a basic knowledge of the main historical periods and associated cultures. Marc van de Mieroop's A History of the Ancient Near East is recommended.

course_paragraphs_json:
["Course Objective
Students will deepen their knowledge of Akkadian grammar and continue to develop their skills in deciphering and reading cuneiform. Readings from Mesopotamian texts in the original script and language will include, among others, Old Babylonian letters, excerpts from Standard Babylonian epics, historical and procedural texts.", "Course Content
In this course students with a thorough basic knowledge of Akkadian (equivalent of Elementary Akkadian 1 & 2) will continue to grapple with the intricacies of the Babylonian and Assyrian languages and the cuneiform writing system. They will master the fundamentals of phonology, morphology and grammar and be introduced to the Standard Babylonian literary dialect, which developed from Old Babylonian.", "Additional Information Teaching Methods
Seminars (4 hrs/week). Attendance is mandatory.", "Method of Assessment
In-class participation and preparation of weekly assignments (40%)
Written exam (60%)
The resit regulations regarding the assignments are specified in the study manual.", "Literature
For this course you will need three items: a grammar book, a sign list and a dictionary. If you cannot obtain them yourself, the teacher will provide you with pdf files of the necessary literature:
Course textbook: Richard Caplice, Introduction to Akkadian (2002, 4th edition).
Sign list: Rykle Borger, Mesopotamisches Zeichenlexikon (last edition 2010) or Rene Labat, Manuel d’épigraphie akkadienne (last edition 1976).
Dictionaries:
CDA: A Concise Dictionary of Akkadian, 2nd edition 2000, edited by Jeremy Black, Andrew George and Nicolas Postgate.
AHw: von Soden, Wolfram. Akkadisches Handwörterbuch. 3 volumes. Wiesbaden, Harrassowitz, 1965-1981.
CAD: The Assyrian Dictionary of the Oriental Institute of the University of Chicago. 21 volumes. Chicago: The Oriental Institute of the University of Chicago, 1956-2010. (Download individual volumes (PDF): http://oi.uchicago.edu/research/publications/assyrian-dictionary-oriental-institute-university-chicago-cad)
Note: Facsimile copies and editions of the texts we read will be provided by the teacher.", "Additional Information Target Audience
Target audience: Bachelor students who specialize in ancient Near Eastern Studies (with Akkadian language).", "Recommended background knowledge
A thorough knowledge of Akkadian (Babylonian/Assyrian) grammar, vocabulary and cuneiform signs (Neo-Assyrian monumental script), equivalent to at least one full year of study is obligatory. Students should have followed Elementary Akkadian 1-2 and ideally one additional Akkadian reading course at the VU or elsewhere. In case of doubts about qualifications acquired outside the VU, please contact the course coordinator."]

course_programmes: Ancient Studies; Archaeology; Communication and Information Studies; Greek and Latin Languages and Cultures; History; Literature and Society; Media, Art, Design and Architecture; Philosophy
course_paragraphs_json:
["Course Objective
Students who successfully complete this course will have a basic knowledge of and insight into:
The nature, aims and objectives of modern archaeology and its relationship with (ancient) history, anthropology and the sciences
The history of archaeology as an academic discipline, with attention for shifts in nature, aims and objectives and theoretical frameworks
The relationship between material culture and patterns in human behaviour and thinking, as well as current methods to study this relationship
The various theoretical perspectives involved in reconstructing past human behaviour and societies, with special attention for the role of anthropology and history
The role of archaeology and heritage in the contemporary world", "Course Content
This first level course offers students an introduction to key concepts and practical approaches in archaeology. Students will become acquainted with the nature, aims and research objectives of modern-day archaeology. They will also gain an insight into the history of archaeology as an academic discipline and its (evolving) relationship with (ancient) history, anthropology and the natural sciences. Students will be introduced to the various ways in which archaeologists use material culture to reconstruct the human past and past societies, with special attention being paid to the role of anthropological and historical approaches. The links between archaeological theory and practice will be further explored by the use of case studies drawn from a wide range of time periods and geographical regions. Finally, consideration will also be given to the politics of archaeology, and an introduction will be given to the opportunities and challenges that face archaeology and heritage in today’s world.
Depending on the general timetable and the availability of ongoing excavations a (non-mandatory) field trip may be organized.", "Additional Information Teaching Methods
Lectures (3 x 2 hours per week). Average number of contact hours per week: 6 hours. Course timetable to be published on rooster.uva.nl", "Method of Assessment
Two written examinations: a midterm in week 3 (40%) and a final exam in week 8 (60%).
A minimum score of 55% (or 5.5 on a scale of 10) on the final is needed to pass the course.
The resit regulations will be specified in the UvA study manual.", "Literature
For this course you are expected to buy a copy of:
Renfrew, C./Bahn, P./DeMarrais, E., 2024, Archaeology: Theories, Methods and Practice, Thames & Hudson, ninth edition. €48.95 ISBN 0500297096
In addition, a syllabus will be made available on Canvas, with guidelines on how to approach the handbook and with trial questions and points of discussion for each class.", "Additional Information Target Audience
Target audience:
First year students in Archaeology.
Second year students Ancient Studies with a specialization in Archaeology.
Also available to other students as an elective; no entry requirements.", "Additional Information
This course is part of a joined programme by the Vrije Universiteit Amsterdam (VU) and the University of Amsterdam (UvA). It is taught at a UvA location. For the course schedule see https://rooster.uva.nl/", "Custom Course Registration
First year ACASA students are automatically placed. Other students can register for this course via UvA https://glass.uva.nl
VU students who would like to follow this course as an elective need to request a guest registration at the UvA. See for more information: https://www.uva.nl/en/education/other-programmes/electives/electives.html
Please note:
Course registration periods between VU and UvA differ.
This course is scheduled at the University of Amsterdam."]
course_objective:
Students who successfully complete this course will have a basic knowledge of and insight into:
The nature, aims and objectives of modern archaeology and its relationship with (ancient) history, anthropology and the sciences
The history of archaeology as an academic discipline, with attention for shifts in nature, aims and objectives and theoretical frameworks
The relationship between material culture and patterns in human behaviour and thinking, as well as current methods to study this relationship
The various theoretical perspectives involved in reconstructing past human behaviour and societies, with special attention for the role of anthropology and history
The role of archaeology and heritage in the contemporary world
course_content:
This first level course offers students an introduction to key concepts and practical approaches in archaeology. Students will become acquainted with the nature, aims and research objectives of modern-day archaeology. They will also gain an insight into the history of archaeology as an academic discipline and its (evolving) relationship with (ancient) history, anthropology and the natural sciences. Students will be introduced to the various ways in which archaeologists use material culture to reconstruct the human past and past societies, with special attention being paid to the role of anthropological and historical approaches. The links between archaeological theory and practice will be further explored by the use of case studies drawn from a wide range of time periods and geographical regions. Finally, consideration will also be given to the politics of archaeology, and an introduction will be given to the opportunities and challenges that face archaeology and heritage in today’s world.
Depending on the general timetable and the availability of ongoing excavations a (non-mandatory) field trip may be organized.
additional_information_teaching_methods: Lectures (3 x 2 hours per week). Average number of contact hours per week: 6 hours. Course timetable to be published on rooster.uva.nl
method_of_assessment:
Two written examinations: a midterm in week 3 (40%) and a final exam in week 8 (60%).
A minimum score of 55% (or 5.5 on a scale of 10) on the final is needed to pass the course.
The resit regulations will be specified in the UvA study manual.
literature:
For this course you are expected to buy a copy of:
Renfrew, C./Bahn, P./DeMarrais, E., 2024, Archaeology: Theories, Methods and Practice, Thames & Hudson, ninth edition. €48.95 ISBN 0500297096
In addition, a syllabus will be made available on Canvas, with guidelines on how to approach the handbook and with trial questions and points of discussion for each class.
additional_information_target_audience:
Target audience:
First year students in Archaeology.
Second year students Ancient Studies with a specialization in Archaeology.
Also available to other students as an elective; no entry requirements.

course_paragraphs_json:
["Course Objective
On completion of this course, you will have:
acquired a critical understanding of the specific contribution of archaeology and its subdisciplines (e.g. iconography, zooarchaeology, archaeobotany) to the study of ancient religions, in comparison to other disciplines in the humanities, such as theology, anthropology, ancient history and material culture studies;
learnt to apply theoretical notions and concepts related to the study of religion to an archaeological dataset;
gained more detailed knowledge of the most important cult places and the associated material culture, including animal bones and plant remains, in the Mediterranean and Northwest-Europe from c. 800 BC to 250 AD;
gained insight into the origin, development and level of organization of cult communities in the ancient world;
had practical experience of what is required for an academic paper that follows disciplinary conventions and a given stylesheet", "Course Content
This course is about the archaeology of cult places. We discuss a number of key cultic and ritual sites in the Mediterranean and Northwest-Europe in the period from c. 800 BC (the period of the rise of the Greek city-states) to 250 AD (the crisis of the Roman cities of the West). In the lectures various aspects of the materiality of ancient religions will be discussed. In the seminars the students will present case-studies in which these aspects are further explored.", "Additional Information Teaching Methods
Interactive lectures / seminars (two times 2 hrs per week).", "Method of Assessment
The examination for this course consists of one non-graded assignment and two graded components.
Assignment in week 1 (graded completed/not completed)
Written paper (80%)
To pass this course the assignment for week 1 should have been made and uploaded, while the grade for the written paper should be 5.5 or above. If the written paper is insufficient, you will get the chance to rewrite your essay (the highest grade possible will then be 6.5) or to write an entirely new paper on a different subject.", "Literature
There is no course book with this module. The literature will be announced and/or made available on Canvas.", "Additional Information Target Audience
This course is compulsory for 2nd year BA Archaeology students and for 2nd year BA Ancient Studies who follow the specialization Archaeology. Also students of the 'Doorstroom minor Archeologie' of the Saxion University of Applied Sciences and students of the premaster of Archaeology take this course.", "Additional Information
This course is part of the learning path Academic Skills of the BA Archaeology programme. In this course, students of the programme will be specifically trained and tested in writing skills.
This course is part of a joined programme by the Vrije Universiteit Amsterdam (VU) and the University of Amsterdam (UvA). It is taught at a UvA location. For the course schedule see https://rooster.uva.nl/", "Custom Course Registration
ACASA students must register via UvA https://glass.uva.nl
This course is not open for elective students.
Please note:
Course registration periods between VU and UvA differ.
This course is scheduled at the University of Amsterdam."]
course_content: This course is about the archaeology of cult places. We discuss a number of key cultic and ritual sites in the Mediterranean and Northwest-Europe in the period from c. 800 BC (the period of the rise of the Greek city-states) to 250 AD (the crisis of the Roman cities of the West). In the lectures various aspects of the materiality of ancient religions will be discussed. In the seminars the students will present case-studies in which these aspects are further explored.
additional_information_teaching_methods: Interactive lectures / seminars (two times 2 hrs per week).
method_of_assessment:
The examination for this course consists of one non-graded assignment and two graded components.
Assignment in week 1 (graded completed/not completed)
Written paper (80%)
To pass this course the assignment for week 1 should have been made and uploaded, while the grade for the written paper should be 5.5 or above. If the written paper is insufficient, you will get the chance to rewrite your essay (the highest grade possible will then be 6.5) or to write an entirely new paper on a different subject.
literature: There is no course book with this module. The literature will be announced and/or made available on Canvas.
additional_information_target_audience: This course is compulsory for 2nd year BA Archaeology students and for 2nd year BA Ancient Studies who follow the specialization Archaeology. Also students of the 'Doorstroom minor Archeologie' of the Saxion University of Applied Sciences and students of the premaster of Archaeology take this course.

course_paragraphs_json:
["Course Objective
In this course you will:
Gain an understanding of the key historical developments in archaeological theory
Develop a critical understanding of issues and debates in contemporary archaeological theory
Develop the skills and knowledge to assess the value and relevance of theoretical frameworks used in archaeological practice
Discuss and reflect upon theoretical frameworks and historical developments within peer-led groups
Develop the ability to apply archaeological theory to one's own archaeological research", "Course Content
The aim of this course is to provide an intensive undergraduate level introduction to archaeological theory and interpretation. The course will review the historical development of archaeological theory and will explore and evaluate the major interpretative frameworks used by different schools of thought. In addition to attending lectures students will be asked to read and reflect upon theoretically-driven case studies in weekly seminars. It is expressly intended that the student will not only learn a range of theoretical approaches but will also learn how to select and apply archaeological theory to study archaeological materials and human behaviour.
Content will include the following:
Archaeology and culture history
Migrations and diffusion
Processual Archaeology
Post processual archaeology
Practice theory, habitus & agency
Biographical approaches to materials and landscapes
Colonialism and post-colonial archaeologies", "Additional Information Teaching Methods
Seminars and lectures, 2 x 2 hours per week", "Method of Assessment
Class Participation (completed/ non-completed);
Oral Presentations (completed/non-completed);
Essay Exam (graded).
This will be a formal closed book-examination about course material and literature.
This course is part of the learning path Academic Skills of the BA Archaeology programme. Its students will be specifically trained and tested in more advanced discussion skills (such as chairing, moderating, mediating).
The resit regulations will be specified in the study manual.", "Literature
Key texts:
Johnson, M. 2010. Archaeological Theory, an introduction. Oxford, Blackwell Publishing.
Harris, O.J.T. and Cipolla, C.N. 2017. Archaeological Theory in the New Millennium: Introducing Current Perspective. London and New York, Routledge.
(Additional) literature will be made available on Canvas. Students need to have read the specified texts for class.", "Additional Information Target Audience
BA2 Archaeology students
Students from Saxion University of Applied Sciences who take the preparatory minor ('doorstroomminor') Archaeology
ACASA students of Classics or Ancient Studies who wish to take the course as an elective and have completed the module What is Archaeology? (BA1 Archaeology)", "Additional Information
This course is part of a joined programme by the Vrije Universiteit Amsterdam (VU) and the University of Amsterdam (UvA). It is taught at a UvA location. For the course schedule see https://rooster.uva.nl/", "Custom Course Registration
ACASA students must register via UvA https://glass.uva.nl
This course is not open for elective students.
Please note:

This course is scheduled at the University of Amsterdam."]
course_objective:
In this course you will:
Gain an understanding of the key historical developments in archaeological theory
Develop a critical understanding of issues and debates in contemporary archaeological theory
Develop the skills and knowledge to assess the value and relevance of theoretical frameworks used in archaeological practice
Discuss and reflect upon theoretical frameworks and historical developments within peer-led groups
Develop the ability to apply archaeological theory to one's own archaeological research
course_content:
The aim of this course is to provide an intensive undergraduate level introduction to archaeological theory and interpretation. The course will review the historical development of archaeological theory and will explore and evaluate the major interpretative frameworks used by different schools of thought. In addition to attending lectures students will be asked to read and reflect upon theoretically-driven case studies in weekly seminars. It is expressly intended that the student will not only learn a range of theoretical approaches but will also learn how to select and apply archaeological theory to study archaeological materials and human behaviour.
Content will include the following:
Archaeology and culture history
Migrations and diffusion
Processual Archaeology
Post processual archaeology
Practice theory, habitus & agency
Biographical approaches to materials and landscapes
Colonialism and post-colonial archaeologies
additional_information_teaching_methods: Seminars and lectures, 2 x 2 hours per week
literature:
Key texts:
Johnson, M. 2010. Archaeological Theory, an introduction. Oxford, Blackwell Publishing.
Harris, O.J.T. and Cipolla, C.N. 2017. Archaeological Theory in the New Millennium: Introducing Current Perspective. London and New York, Routledge.
(Additional) literature will be made available on Canvas. Students need to have read the specified texts for class.
additional_information_target_audience:
BA2 Archaeology students
Students from Saxion University of Applied Sciences who take the preparatory minor ('doorstroomminor') Archaeology
ACASA students of Classics or Ancient Studies who wish to take the course as an elective and have completed the module What is Archaeology? (BA1 Archaeology)

course_paragraphs_json:
["Course Objective
After successful completion of this module, you will be able to
Apply the basic skills of archaeological field work and field recording methods
Identify archaeological features and structures, and show basic knowledge about their interpretation
Demonstrate a good understanding of the aims, methods and results of the archaeological fieldwork project
Write daily reports and a final report to record your understanding of these aims, methods and results
Inform the public about the excavation results
Understand the site's location in the landscape
Demonstrate personal skills in teamwork and collaboration
Understand the basics of the Dutch heritage regulations in archaeology (AMZ) and the quality system (KNA)", "Course Content
Excavation and practicals. Practicals and formal classes in Amsterdam provide information on the field school project and an introduction to the material culture of the Roman, Medieval and Modern periods. The module takes four weeks, of which minimally two will be spent in the field. In the field you will learn excavation techniques, such as levelling, and sectioning settlement features, such as post-holes, ditches, wells and pits. You will not only learn how to handle a shovel and trowel but also how to retrieve information from remains left in the ground. You will be introduced into digital data collection, but you will also learn to make accurate analogue scale drawings of features. Finds are processed during the fieldwork as much as possible. You will write daily reports, as is customary in most digs. The field school takes place on a location outside of Amsterdam, where you will stay during the week.", "Additional Information Teaching Methods
Formal classes and practicals in Amsterdam
Fieldwork on a location outside Amsterdam, with overnight stay, minimal two weeks", "Method of Assessment
Attendance of the practicals (P/NP) Daily reports (completed/non-completed) Commitment to fieldwork Further Assignments (completed/non-completed) In all four respects conditions must be met in order to pass this course.", "Literature
Literature will be made available via Canvas.", "Additional Information Target Audience
1st year students Archaeology
This course is also offered as a restricted choice elective for BA2 Ancient Studies students with specialisation Archaeology and for pre-Master’s programme Archaeology students (on the condition that there are enough places available).", "Additional Information
This course is part of a joined programme by the Vrije Universiteit Amsterdam (VU) and the University of Amsterdam (UvA). It is taught at a UvA location. For the course schedule see https://rooster.uva.nl/", "Custom Course Registration
First year ACASA students are automatically placed.
This course is not open for elective students.
Please note: This course is scheduled at the University of Amsterdam"]

Practicals and formal classes in Amsterdam provide information on the field school project and an introduction to the material culture of the Roman, Medieval and Modern periods. The module takes four weeks, of which minimally two will be spent in the field. In the field you will learn excavation techniques, such as levelling, and sectioning settlement features, such as post-holes, ditches, wells and pits. You will not only learn how to handle a shovel and trowel but also how to retrieve information from remains left in the ground. You will be introduced into digital data collection, but you will also learn to make accurate analogue scale drawings of features. Finds are processed during the fieldwork as much as possible. You will write daily reports, as is customary in most digs. The field school takes place on a location outside of Amsterdam, where you will stay during the week.

course_paragraphs_json:
["Course Objective
This course offers BA2 students of the Archaeology programme of ACASA an opportunity to get more familiar with archaeological fieldwork. A detailed description of learning objectives can be found on the Canvas site. The particulars will be determined on an individual basis, in consultation with the course coordinator and with the fieldwork director of your chosen project.
You are able to explain how (part of) the fieldwork contributes to answering the site-level research questions.
You are able to describe the fieldwork project in terms of its value to the public outreach.
You are able to hold a progress meeting about the part of the project in which you are working with your immediate supervisor.
You are able to write daily/trench reports and can argue the decisions made in the field.
You are familiar with the KNA protocols for desk research, field survey and excavation (soil and sediment). You are able to explain the difference between conducting archaeological fieldwork in Pleistocene and Holocene contexts", "Course Content
In this module you can participate in one of the interesting and exciting ACASA fieldwork projects. Further information about these projects and the possibilities they offer will be made available to the students on the Canvas page of the module. For an impression of current ACASA fieldwork projects, see www.uva.nl/discipline/archeologie/onderzoek/onderzoek.html. In consultation with the course coordinator and with the fieldwork director you can partially shape your field school during these projects to your own interests. Do you want to gain more experience in archaeological fieldwork itself? Or focus on the study of finds from one of the excavations? Or do you have your own idea about your contribution to the projects (more material-, GIS- or heritage-oriented)? This module can be completed in various ways.", "Additional Information Teaching Methods
Fieldwork", "Method of Assessment
Written report and oral evaluation. This course is part of the learning path Academic Skills of the BA Archaeology programme. All assessment will take place on a pass/fail basis.", "Entry Requirements
