Knowledge and understanding of the statistical methods and visualisation techniques that are regularly used in historical research
The ability to critically reflect on how historians use and present (quantitative) data
The ability to select, structure and manipulate numeric data critically by themselves: creating pivot tables and simple data visualisations such as graphs and maps, and to use them for analysis in their papers and presentations
course_content:
This course aims to familiarise you with basic data analysis techniques for historical research. Traditionally, socio-economic historians often worked with numbers. They conducted research on, for example, demographic developments and wages and prices in the past, or they analysed social characteristics of groups of people. In recent decades, we have seen the rise of new quantitative methods thanks to the rapidly growing availability of digitised historical sources. Within the field of digital humanities, for instance, quantitative approaches are also used to analyse large text corpora.
In this course, you will learn what is necessary to understand such research, and how to critically and responsibly assess, visualise, and interpret quantitative data yourself. These skills can be used in the continuation of your studies, in your own research, but they are also useful in various other societal fields. Basic knowledge of statistics and digital technology also helps you to better assess the value of certain claims (both in academic literature and more broadly).
Students who get a taste for Digital Humanities and want to delve further can opt for the Digital Humanities and Social Analytics Minor in their third year

course_paragraphs_json:
["Course Objective
The course will familiarise students with the concept of migration and learn to see global history as a history of mobilities of human and other than humans. The course engages with critical literature in the field, and introduce grounded perspectives on migration and mobilities that configure globe and globalization. By the end of the course:
students will be able to illustrate the overlapping dynamics of migration and settler colonialism.
students will be able to demosntrate ethnonationalism through histories of migration.
students will be to identify between labour mobility and European colonial expansionism.
student will be able to discuss connection between diaspora, refugeehood, and their world-making beyond one's homelands.
students will be discuss the connection between global migration and environmental histories through other-than-human mobilities", "Course Content
The course begins with an introduction to colonial worldmaking through reading 19th Century English church-man petitions to facilitate migration of imperial subjects to Canada as well as the establishment of Hovevei Zion to colonize Palestine. Then, they progress with literatures and key concpets of migration studies.", "Additional Information Teaching Methods
The course will be a combination of lectures, (supervised) student-led classes (documentaries and discussions) and student group presentations.", "Method of Assessment
Group presentations and reports

Individual essays (based on literature review, ethnographic research or visual studies)", "Literature

course_objective:
The course will familiarise students with the concept of migration and learn to see global history as a history of mobilities of human and other than humans. The course engages with critical literature in the field, and introduce grounded perspectives on migration and mobilities that configure globe and globalization. By the end of the course:
students will be able to illustrate the overlapping dynamics of migration and settler colonialism.
students will be able to demosntrate ethnonationalism through histories of migration.
students will be to identify between labour mobility and European colonial expansionism.
student will be able to discuss connection between diaspora, refugeehood, and their world-making beyond one's homelands.
students will be discuss the connection between global migration and environmental histories through other-than-human mobilities
course_content: The course begins with an introduction to colonial worldmaking through reading 19th Century English church-man petitions to facilitate migration of imperial subjects to Canada as well as the establishment of Hovevei Zion to colonize Palestine. Then, they progress with literatures and key concpets of migration studies.
additional_information_teaching_methods: The course will be a combination of lectures, (supervised) student-led classes (documentaries and discussions) and student group presentations.
method_of_assessment:
Group presentations and reports
Walking migration tours or collecting oral histories of migration
Individual essays (based on literature review, ethnographic research or visual studies)
literature: Book chapters and articles as indicated in the syllabus.
additional_information_target_audience: Second-year students of History and International Studies; social science students; exchange students.
recommended_background_knowledge: This course is an elective for second-year students of History and International Studies. The course is also open to students who have completed at least one year of History or Social Sciences.

course_paragraphs_json:
["Course Objective
After completing this course, students will:
have an understanding of the main historical developments that shaped our idea of what scientific or academic knowledge is;
understand how several institutions helped to create, preserve and pass on this knowledge throughout history;
have a broad overview of the changing practices of scholarly and scientific knowledge production over time;
understand how the advent of the internet, data digitisation and artificial intelligence have changed both the practices of knowledge production as well as the status and accessibility of knowledge;
be able to reflect on the position of their own discipline within today’s knowledge society", "Course Content
In the course History of Knowledge, we will focus on questions about what knowledge is and what was seen as valuable knowledge, from classical antiquity up until today, and the way this knowledge was preserved and passed on over time, with special attention for the institutions that played a major role in the process: the library, monasteries, the university, the Republic of Letters, the internationalisation of the sciences in the 19th century, and the latest developments marked by the digital turn and artificial intelligence. Students will learn to reflect about different styles and methods of knowledge production, the necessity of preserving existing knowledge, the relation between authoritative knowledge and power, the accessibility of knowledge over time and for various social groups, and the challenges for and the relevance of the humanities in the digital era.", "Additional Information Teaching Methods
The course consists of lectures (2 x 2 hours a week).", "Method of Assessment
Written assignments (40%)
Final written examination (60%)", "Literature
A reading list will be provided via Canvas", "Additional Information Target Audience
This course is part of the 2nd year Bachelor’s programs History, Geschiedenis and Literature & Society: English", "Additional Information
This course is part of the Academic Core. Attendance is compulsory. Students may miss maximum 2 classes."]
course_content: In the course History of Knowledge, we will focus on questions about what knowledge is and what was seen as valuable knowledge, from classical antiquity up until today, and the way this knowledge was preserved and passed on over time, with special attention for the institutions that played a major role in the process: the library, monasteries, the university, the Republic of Letters, the internationalisation of the sciences in the 19th century, and the latest developments marked by the digital turn and artificial intelligence. Students will learn to reflect about different styles and methods of knowledge production, the necessity of preserving existing knowledge, the relation between authoritative knowledge and power, the accessibility of knowledge over time and for various social groups, and the challenges for and the relevance of the humanities in the digital era.
additional_information_teaching_methods: The course consists of lectures (2 x 2 hours a week).
method_of_assessment:
Written assignments (40%)
Final written examination (60%)
literature: A reading list will be provided via Canvas
additional_information_target_audience: This course is part of the 2nd year Bachelor’s programs History, Geschiedenis and Literature & Society: English

course_paragraphs_json:
["Course Objective
At the end of the course students can:
Understand key political, social and cultural debates and analytical concepts in the history and anthropology of the Maghreb.
Interpret and assess a selection of (translated) primary sources (e.g. archival sources, ethnographies, oral traditions and oral histories, documentary films) relevant to the course topics.
Reflect on key (sensitive) scholarly debates regarding migration, gender, colonialism, nationalism, and religion in the Maghreb and take up an informed position on them.", "Course Content
This course introduces students to key debates in the history and anthropology of the Maghreb (with emphasis on Morocco, Algeria and Tunisia), while continuously connecting the region to world history at large. The course reflects on the history of both disciplines in the region and offers critical insights into the construction of historical and ethnographic knowledge. It provides insight into political, social, and cultural issues that have caught the attention of historians and anthropologists, such as Islam and religious minorities, gender, colonialism and the colonial legacy, nationalism, language and ethnicity, migration and development, and revolts and revolutions.", "Additional Information Teaching Methods
Lectures and seminars, 4 contact hours in total per week. Students should come to class prepared to actively discuss the readings.", "Method of Assessment
Source analysis
Written exam", "Literature
A reading list of mandatory articles will be distributed at the beginning of the course.
Recommended reading: P.C. Naylor, North Africa : a history from antiquity to the present (University of Texas Press 2015, Revised edition)", "Additional Information Target Audience
This course is an elective for BA 2 students Geschiedenis and BA2 students History and International Studies. The course is also open to BA2/3 students in Cultural Anthropology and Development Sociology, Political Science, and Theology and Religious Studies. Exchange students should have a background in any of these fields.", "Custom Course Registration

course_paragraphs_json:
["Course Objective
Learning to do historical research on the basis of primary and secondary sources; learning to present about the progress and results of research orally and in writing ; acquiring insight in, and applying, concepts and theories about global commodity chains; situating case-studies in historical debates.", "Course Content
Who benefited from a cup of coffee ? Who dominated the ivory trade ? What steps did it take to turn cotton grown in Asia, Africa or America into a shirt sold in a shop in Europe ? Such questions are the subject of the 'commodity chain' approach in Global History. Historians use the concept of 'commodity chains' to analyze and explain connections between flows of goods, power relations and consumption patterns in various parts of the world throughout history. In this course, we will discuss the state of the art of the commodity chain approach in history, and then apply it in a variety of case studies between c. 1500 and the present.", "Additional Information Teaching Methods
Research Seminar", "Method of Assessment
Contributions to discussions in class and on canvas (20 %) , oral presentations (15 %), final individual paper or identifiable part of a collective product (65 %)
Remarks: Attendance in class mandatory; if a student is absent more than two times without a valid reason, he/she will be excluded from the course"]
course_objective: Learning to do historical research on the basis of primary and secondary sources; learning to present about the progress and results of research orally and in writing ; acquiring insight in, and applying, concepts and theories about global commodity chains; situating case-studies in historical debates.
course_content: Who benefited from a cup of coffee ? Who dominated the ivory trade ? What steps did it take to turn cotton grown in Asia, Africa or America into a shirt sold in a shop in Europe ? Such questions are the subject of the 'commodity chain' approach in Global History. Historians use the concept of 'commodity chains' to analyze and explain connections between flows of goods, power relations and consumption patterns in various parts of the world throughout history. In this course, we will discuss the state of the art of the commodity chain approach in history, and then apply it in a variety of case studies between c. 1500 and the present.
additional_information_teaching_methods: Research Seminar
method_of_assessment:
Contributions to discussions in class and on canvas (20 %) , oral presentations (15 %), final individual paper or identifiable part of a collective product (65 %)
Remarks: Attendance in class mandatory; if a student is absent more than two times without a valid reason, he/she will be excluded from the course

course_paragraphs_json:
["Course Objective
The goal is to learn how to identify, know, understand and apply scholarly approaches of Environmental History; to design and conduct a historical research independently; to apply concepts and theories in a research paper; to take a stand in a historical debate.", "Course Content
In this course we focus on the complex historical relationship between humans and the environment. It addresses environmental change in relation to large global processes like population growth, industrialization, technological progress, the rise of the nation state, (de)colonisation and urbanization. We read studies from environmental history on topics like drought and floods, human - animal relations and climate change.
Examples of questions area: How did human societies interact with the environment? How did we cope with climate change? What was the role of climate sceptics in the democratic debate? How did human-made oases for tourism and draining aquifers affect long-term chances for agriculture and for surviving chances of indigenous peoples? How did low-lying countries cope with (locally) rising sea levels? How did we cope with periods of drought? Did the societal improvement of hydro-resilience in the former colonies also include low-income groups? How important was animal agency in history?
We concentrate on the period 1800-2000, when the global population underwent unprecedented growth, cities exploded worldwide and environmental change occurred at an ever higher speed, thanks to the transition from organic to fossil fuels. We compare developments in some global regions, in particular Europe (Netherlands, England and Germany), USA and Asia (Indonesia, India and the Middle East). The course content is enriched by and connected to on-going research projects like Coping with Drought: https://copingwithdrought.com.
As a special primary source we will explore newspaper databases.", "Additional Information Teaching Methods
Seminar of 2 sessions of 2 hours per week in April and May. Final
presentations of research projects and submission research paper in
June.", "Method of Assessment
Literature reading and writing assignments 40%, Oral presentation (10%), Research paper (50%).", "Literature
Literature is provided by the lecturer in CANVAS.", "Additional Information Target Audience
BA 2 students HiS", "Additional Information
Deze cursus wordt gegeven in het Nederlands (deel werkcolleges, werkstuk) en Engels (hoorcolleges) .", "Custom Course Registration
Access for students who have not done BA1 HIS only after approval of the lecturer.", "Explanation Canvas
yes", "Recommended background knowledge
The knowledge acquired in the first year of the BA study History & International Studies (HIS)."]
course_objective: The goal is to learn how to identify, know, understand and apply scholarly approaches of Environmental History; to design and conduct a historical research independently; to apply concepts and theories in a research paper; to take a stand in a historical debate.
course_content:
In this course we focus on the complex historical relationship between humans and the environment. It addresses environmental change in relation to large global processes like population growth, industrialization, technological progress, the rise of the nation state, (de)colonisation and urbanization. We read studies from environmental history on topics like drought and floods, human - animal relations and climate change.
Examples of questions area: How did human societies interact with the environment? How did we cope with climate change? What was the role of climate sceptics in the democratic debate? How did human-made oases for tourism and draining aquifers affect long-term chances for agriculture and for surviving chances of indigenous peoples? How did low-lying countries cope with (locally) rising sea levels? How did we cope with periods of drought? Did the societal improvement of hydro-resilience in the former colonies also include low-income groups? How important was animal agency in history?
We concentrate on the period 1800-2000, when the global population underwent unprecedented growth, cities exploded worldwide and environmental change occurred at an ever higher speed, thanks to the transition from organic to fossil fuels. We compare developments in some global regions, in particular Europe (Netherlands, England and Germany), USA and Asia (Indonesia, India and the Middle East). The course content is enriched by and connected to on-going research projects like Coping with Drought: https://copingwithdrought.com.
As a special primary source we will explore newspaper databases.

course_paragraphs_json:
["Course Objective
After completion of this course, you are able to:
Understand key historical and anthropological theories and analytical concepts in the study of migration, diaspora and transnational relations and apply these concepts and theories to ethnographic and historical case studies.
Understand and analyze social relations and political organization in spaces of ambiguous sovereignty in modern and contemporary history.
Critically reflect on interdisciplinarity in the study of migration, diaspora and transnational relations.", "Course Content
International relations are usually studied from a top-down perspective. This advanced, interdisciplinary course develops a bottom-up historical perspective on both the agents of international interactions (migrants and diaspora) and the places where migration and diaspora have rendered state sovereignties ambiguous and complex. Each week, we address one way in which we can study international relations, migration, diaspora and spaces of ambiguous sovereignty from a historical and anthropological perspective. We look at old and new methods, theories and source materials in this field. The course covers modern and contemporary history and is arranged around different themes including: travels, people, objects, places, ideas, voices and sounds.", "Additional Information Teaching Methods
Seminars, in total 2 to 4 contact hours per week.", "Method of Assessment
Oral presentation
Written exam", "Literature
The full reading list will be made available to students at the start of the course.", "Additional Information Target Audience
This is a mandatory course for BA 2 students History and International Studies. Other students from the Humanities and Social Sciences are welcome to join, but must have completed all of their first year courses and should contact the coordinator first in order to be admitted to the course.", "Explanation Canvas
Teaching materials, including handouts and powerpoints, will be made available online on Canvas after each seminar. The literature used is available from the university library in digital format.", "Recommended background knowledge
Students should have successfully completed all first-year coursework."]

course_content: International relations are usually studied from a top-down perspective. This advanced, interdisciplinary course develops a bottom-up historical perspective on both the agents of international interactions (migrants and diaspora) and the places where migration and diaspora have rendered state sovereignties ambiguous and complex. Each week, we address one way in which we can study international relations, migration, diaspora and spaces of ambiguous sovereignty from a historical and anthropological perspective. We look at old and new methods, theories and source materials in this field. The course covers modern and contemporary history and is arranged around different themes including: travels, people, objects, places, ideas, voices and sounds.

course_paragraphs_json:
["Course Objective
During this course and after completing it, students will:
develop a familiarity with the history of Latin America since the late eighteenth century.
acquire knowledge from (and critically assess) academic literature.
be able to recognize historiographical debates in the field.
apply historical knowledge acquired in previous courses to further examine the peculiarities of Latin American history in a global context.
understand and discuss primary sources (translated into English, in case of written sources) in their historical context.
use their historical knowledge to understand and take a critical stance in contemporary discussions in and about Latin America.
be able to effectively communicate their ideas in oral form.
further develop their academic writing skills, by preparing a final paper based on a critical historiographic survey", "Course Content
This course offers students an introduction to the history of modern Latin America. Starting with the period of revolutions that swept through the region in the late eighteenth and early nineteenth centuries, it discusses the main political, social, and economic developments that shaped its history in the last two centuries. Avoiding a juxtaposition of national cases and events, the course develops a global and transnational perspective that focuses on several crucial aspects, including the processes of state-building and economic transformation, the consequences of internal and international migrations and displacements, the development of nationalist and populist ideologies, the recurrence of military dictatorships, and the victories and defeats of revolutionary movements. Moreover, it pays particular attention to the relationship between Latin America and other regions of the world, in particular Western Europe and the United States.", "Additional Information Teaching Methods
Two sessions per week. Students should come to the meetings prepared to actively discuss the readings.", "Method of Assessment
Participation in class + assignments about primary sources + final research paper", "Literature
Chasteen, John C. Born in Blood & Fire: A Concise History of Latin America. Fourth edition. New York: W.W. Norton & Company, 2016.
Students will also read a selection of book chapters, articles, and primary sources that will be available via the VU Library and/or in Canvas.
Additionally, students will be encouraged to discuss a selection of Latin American films, music, art, and literature.", "Additional Information Target Audience
BA2 students History and International Studies and Geschiedenis.
The course is open as an elective course for VU-students and exchange students."]
course_objective:

be able to recognize historiographical debates in the field.
apply historical knowledge acquired in previous courses to further examine the peculiarities of Latin American history in a global context.
understand and discuss primary sources (translated into English, in case of written sources) in their historical context.
use their historical knowledge to understand and take a critical stance in contemporary discussions in and about Latin America.
be able to effectively communicate their ideas in oral form.
further develop their academic writing skills, by preparing a final paper based on a critical historiographic survey
course_content: This course offers students an introduction to the history of modern Latin America. Starting with the period of revolutions that swept through the region in the late eighteenth and early nineteenth centuries, it discusses the main political, social, and economic developments that shaped its history in the last two centuries. Avoiding a juxtaposition of national cases and events, the course develops a global and transnational perspective that focuses on several crucial aspects, including the processes of state-building and economic transformation, the consequences of internal and international migrations and displacements, the development of nationalist and populist ideologies, the recurrence of military dictatorships, and the victories and defeats of revolutionary movements. Moreover, it pays particular attention to the relationship between Latin America and other regions of the world, in particular Western Europe and the United States.
additional_information_teaching_methods: Two sessions per week. Students should come to the meetings prepared to actively discuss the readings.
method_of_assessment: Participation in class + assignments about primary sources + final research paper
literature:
Chasteen, John C. Born in Blood & Fire: A Concise History of Latin America. Fourth edition. New York: W.W. Norton & Company, 2016.
Students will also read a selection of book chapters, articles, and primary sources that will be available via the VU Library and/or in Canvas.
Additionally, students will be encouraged to discuss a selection of Latin American films, music, art, and literature.

BA2 students History and International Studies and Geschiedenis.
The course is open as an elective course for VU-students and exchange students.

course_name: The Middle East in Contemporary History
course_paragraphs_json:
["Course Objective
Students can:
demonstrate historical-political trajectories that constitute contemporary Middle East,
analytically debate Orientalism and engage with misrepresentations of the Middle East through works of revolutionary/social justice-oriented thinkers from Nazik Al-Abid, Abdul Rahman Al-Kawakibi to Edward Said and from the Middle East.
define the notion of Empire as a mode of persistent domination that remains in effect in the Middle East.", "Course Content
In the midst of what ICJ called a plausible genocide in Gaza, some in the Global North said, 'the situation in the Middle East should not divide us'; however, the question remains: what and where is this Middle East? This course addresses these questions by diving into the Middle East's historiographies, histories and memories to open up its political-historical construction. The course discusses how past and present influence the armed conflicts in the Middle East and how historiographies have shaped the dominant imagination of the Global North about the peoples of the Middle East.
This course unpacks the notion of Empire and Dispossession through revolutionary thinkers whose criticism of colonialism shaped colonial struggles against French and British mandates in the Middle East and their legacy have enabled resistance against Middle Eastern authoritarian regimes and also Israel as the ongoing colonial settler project. Furthermore, it shows Empire is mode of persistent domination that impacts of decolonized nations through cultural framing, Racialisations and border regimes.
This course engages with Middle Eastern thinkers such as Nazik Al-Abid, Abdul Rahman Al-Kawakibi to Edward Said to introduce Orientalism and Islamophobic framing of Muslims and peoples of the contemporary Middle East. The course also discusses Racism and Aryanism within the Middle East (the case of Iran), and it ends by engaging the cultural politics of images, visuals, aesthetics and objects in and from the Middle East.
This course operates through academic dialogues that begin from the point of view of dispossessed and colonised peoples such as Palestinians and engages with literature that radically criticised and dismantled perspectives of the Dominant.", "Additional Information Teaching Methods
This course partially uses the flipping classroom method, which means students receive content in advance and discuss it in class during group discussions or in conversations with the teacher. Attendance is mandatory, and students missing two lectures will be given extra assignments and tasks to compensate for their absence. Students missing three lectures will not be allowed to finish the course.", "Method of Assessment
Students will deliver three assignments: 10% (a freestyle essay on historical visual representations of the Middle East), 45% (an essay introducing one of the key revolutionary critical and social justice-oriented thinkers of the Middle East), and 45% (a final paper/essay or an open book exam). The overall word count of assessments (min 4000 words and max 5000 words)", "Literature
Please refer to the course manual", "Recommended background knowledge
Students are recommended to familiarise themselves with news outlets such as Aljazeera International, the map of the Middle East and sectarian differences in Islam."]
course_objective:
Students can:
demonstrate historical-political trajectories that constitute contemporary Middle East,
analytically debate Orientalism and engage with misrepresentations of the Middle East through works of revolutionary/social justice-oriented thinkers from Nazik Al-Abid, Abdul Rahman Al-Kawakibi to Edward Said and from the Middle East.
define the notion of Empire as a mode of persistent domination that remains in effect in the Middle East.
course_content:
In the midst of what ICJ called a plausible genocide in Gaza, some in the Global North said, 'the situation in the Middle East should not divide us'; however, the question remains: what and where is this Middle East? This course addresses these questions by diving into the Middle East's historiographies, histories and memories to open up its political-historical construction. The course discusses how past and present influence the armed conflicts in the Middle East and how historiographies have shaped the dominant imagination of the Global North about the peoples of the Middle East.
This course unpacks the notion of Empire and Dispossession through revolutionary thinkers whose criticism of colonialism shaped colonial struggles against French and British mandates in the Middle East and their legacy have enabled resistance against Middle Eastern authoritarian regimes and also Israel as the ongoing colonial settler project. Furthermore, it shows Empire is mode of persistent domination that impacts of decolonized nations through cultural framing, Racialisations and border regimes.
This course engages with Middle Eastern thinkers such as Nazik Al-Abid, Abdul Rahman Al-Kawakibi to Edward Said to introduce Orientalism and Islamophobic framing of Muslims and peoples of the contemporary Middle East. The course also discusses Racism and Aryanism within the Middle East (the case of Iran), and it ends by engaging the cultural politics of images, visuals, aesthetics and objects in and from the Middle East.
This course operates through academic dialogues that begin from the point of view of dispossessed and colonised peoples such as Palestinians and engages with literature that radically criticised and dismantled perspectives of the Dominant.
additional_information_teaching_methods: This course partially uses the flipping classroom method, which means students receive content in advance and discuss it in class during group discussions or in conversations with the teacher. Attendance is mandatory, and students missing two lectures will be given extra assignments and tasks to compensate for their absence. Students missing three lectures will not be allowed to finish the course.
method_of_assessment: Students will deliver three assignments: 10% (a freestyle essay on historical visual representations of the Middle East), 45% (an essay introducing one of the key revolutionary critical and social justice-oriented thinkers of the Middle East), and 45% (a final paper/essay or an open book exam). The overall word count of assessments (min 4000 words and max 5000 words)
literature: Please refer to the course manual
recommended_background_knowledge: Students are recommended to familiarise themselves with news outlets such as Aljazeera International, the map of the Middle East and sectarian differences in Islam.

course_paragraphs_json:
["Course Objective
In the course of their study of Themes in Political History, students will:
develop a familiarity with major topics in modern political history,
develop their ability to identify and evaluate contemporary cultural and/or media mobilisations of topics in political history,
acquire knowledge from and critically assess academic literature,
be able to build their own research topic on a theme in political history,
be able to formulate arguments in written form,
be able to effectively communicate their ideas in oral form.", "Course Content
This course offers students an introduction to ‘big’ themes in modern political history that might include violence, (in)equality, citizenship, freedom and responsibility, ideologies or social movements. The course explores the themes through historical case studies from Europe, Asia and Oceania to underline the global and transnational connections as well as specificities of political histories. Each topic is examined at three levels: first, historical actors’ understandings of the politics of their own actions; second, how scholars have explained ‘the political’ in these histories; and third, how the past is mobilised in the present for contemporary political purposes. We therefore examine primary sources, historiography and contemporary representations and debates around each major theme. The course encourages students to critically evaluate the political as a category of historical action, as well as an approach to the past, and a way of understanding its relevance to the present.", "Additional Information Teaching Methods
1 lecture and 1 seminar per module, plus class discussions and presentations. Students must be prepared to actively discuss the work they prepared for class.", "Method of Assessment
Class participation (10%), module assignments (50%), final essay (40%).", "Literature
A selection of book chapters, articles, and primary sources will be made available via the VU Library and/or in Canvas.", "Additional Information
BA2 students History and International Studies and Geschiedenis.
The course is also open as an elective course for VU-students and Exchange Students."]
course_objective:
In the course of their study of Themes in Political History, students will:
develop a familiarity with major topics in modern political history,
develop their ability to identify and evaluate contemporary cultural and/or media mobilisations of topics in political history,
acquire knowledge from and critically assess academic literature,
be able to build their own research topic on a theme in political history,
be able to formulate arguments in written form,
be able to effectively communicate their ideas in oral form.
course_content: This course offers students an introduction to ‘big’ themes in modern political history that might include violence, (in)equality, citizenship, freedom and responsibility, ideologies or social movements. The course explores the themes through historical case studies from Europe, Asia and Oceania to underline the global and transnational connections as well as specificities of political histories. Each topic is examined at three levels: first, historical actors’ understandings of the politics of their own actions; second, how scholars have explained ‘the political’ in these histories; and third, how the past is mobilised in the present for contemporary political purposes. We therefore examine primary sources, historiography and contemporary representations and debates around each major theme. The course encourages students to critically evaluate the political as a category of historical action, as well as an approach to the past, and a way of understanding its relevance to the present.
additional_information_teaching_methods: 1 lecture and 1 seminar per module, plus class discussions and presentations. Students must be prepared to actively discuss the work they prepared for class.
method_of_assessment: Class participation (10%), module assignments (50%), final essay (40%).
literature: A selection of book chapters, articles, and primary sources will be made available via the VU Library and/or in Canvas.

course_paragraphs_json:
["Course Objective
After finishing this course, the student:
knows written and oral elementary Arabic language utterances and can understand and use them; (knowledge, insight and skill);
is able to recognize, understand and use written and oral language utterances in Arabic (knowledge, insight and skill);
is able to apply these elementary grammatical constructions of those lessons in Arabic;
is able to have a simple elementary conversation in standard Arabic and to present him/herself;
is be able to understand and to translate a short Arabic text.", "Course Content
During Arabic I, the students will study: the alphabet, elementary spelling (short and long vowels, shadda), the article, spelling of the hamza, spelling of the alif (alif al-madda and al-maqṣūra), gender, cases, the personal pronoun, suffixes of the person, the adjective, the nisba noun, the interrogative pronouns, the particles of jarr, the concept “to have”. In addition, simple reading texts are regularly distributed in the lessons to prepare at home and to read together in class. In class, Arabic is used as the language of instruction as much as possible. In addition, short dialogue exercises are offered.", "Additional Information Teaching Methods
Seminars.
For complete language acquisition, the student must be exposed to all elements of the language, including: reading, writing, listening and speaking. This is crucial to gaining an overall competency and fluency in Arabic. In each course, a dictation will be done. This exercise is precious and essential at the beginning of the language learning.", "Method of Assessment
Homework will be given for each next course and must be send to the teacher before the course. Seriousness, rigour and attendance result in a bonus for the student in his global average at the end of the period.
Assessments consist of:
Assignment (25%)
Oral exam (25%)
Final exam of 3 hours consisting of oral and written expression and comprehension (50%)
Oral participation and homework (bonus)", "Literature
There is no book to purchase for this module. All teaching material will be provided by the teacher.", "Additional Information Target Audience
The course is part of the Bachelor Theology and Religious Studies: track Islam, and of the Minor Arabic and Sources of Islam.", "Additional Information
After three absences without justification, the student willautomatically fail the final exam and will have to take the resit to complete this course.", "Custom Course Registration
You can only register for this course if you are enrolled in the minor Arabic and Sources of Islam, or if you are taking the Islam track (part of the bachelor of Theology and Religious Studies), the Free Choice track (part of the bachelor of Theology and Religious Studies) or the History and International Studies track (part of the bachelor History).", "Recommended background knowledge
This course is designed for students without prior knowledge of Arabic. We will start from the level 0, so there is no need for a specific background knowledge."]
course_content: During Arabic I, the students will study: the alphabet, elementary spelling (short and long vowels, shadda), the article, spelling of the hamza, spelling of the alif (alif al-madda and al-maqṣūra), gender, cases, the personal pronoun, suffixes of the person, the adjective, the nisba noun, the interrogative pronouns, the particles of jarr, the concept “to have”. In addition, simple reading texts are regularly distributed in the lessons to prepare at home and to read together in class. In class, Arabic is used as the language of instruction as much as possible. In addition, short dialogue exercises are offered.
additional_information_teaching_methods:
Seminars.
For complete language acquisition, the student must be exposed to all elements of the language, including: reading, writing, listening and speaking. This is crucial to gaining an overall competency and fluency in Arabic. In each course, a dictation will be done. This exercise is precious and essential at the beginning of the language learning.
method_of_assessment:
Homework will be given for each next course and must be send to the teacher before the course. Seriousness, rigour and attendance result in a bonus for the student in his global average at the end of the period.
Assessments consist of:
Assignment (25%)
Oral exam (25%)
Final exam of 3 hours consisting of oral and written expression and comprehension (50%)
Oral participation and homework (bonus)
literature: There is no book to purchase for this module. All teaching material will be provided by the teacher.
additional_information_target_audience: The course is part of the Bachelor Theology and Religious Studies: track Islam, and of the Minor Arabic and Sources of Islam.
recommended_background_knowledge: This course is designed for students without prior knowledge of Arabic. We will start from the level 0, so there is no need for a specific background knowledge.

course_paragraphs_json:
["Course Objective
The end goal of Elementary Latin 1 and 2 is to translate and read relatively simple Latin historical sources from ancient to postclassical times. At the end of Elementary 1, students:
Have a basic Latin vocabulary and understanding of elementary morphology and syntax
Are able to use instruments such as dictionaries/glossaries, annotations, grammars/overviews of morphology and syntax
Are able to translate simple Latin sentences
Are able to paraphrase simple Latin texts at section level
Have insight in the value of reading Latin texts in the primary language for understanding the meaning and value of historical sources", "Course Content
The course Elementary Latin 1 (6 ECTS) introduces you to Latin on a basic level. Students memorize a glossary and complete exercises on morphology and syntax. They train their skills in translating and interpreting small Latin texts. During the course, they are introduced to relatively simple textual sources, with a focus on medieval texts. They also learn about the importance of reading sources in the primary language to understand the meaning and historical value.", "Additional Information Teaching Methods
Seminars (2 x 2 hours a week).", "Method of Assessment
Written exams: half-term test (30%) and final exam (70%). The resit in the resit period covers both tests (= 100 %); resits of one of the partial exams are not possible.", "Entry Requirements
The course is intended for students with no prior knowledge of Latin. The course is therefore not open to students with a Dutch 'eindexamen Latijn' or comparable secondary school certificates (e.g. British GCE level).", "Literature
Study materials will be distributed through Canvas.", "Additional Information Target Audience
The course is open to
BA 2 students in History and International Studies
BA students in Ancient Studies (who can take it as an elective)
Minor students and other elective students", "Recommended background knowledge
The course is intended for students with no prior knowledge of Latin. The course is therefore not open to students with a Dutch eindexamen Latijn or comparable secondary school certificates (e.g. British GCE level)."]

course_paragraphs_json:
["Course Objective
The students are able to successfully handle uncomplicated oral and written tasks in a wide number of basic social situations;
The students are able to understand uncomplicated speech and texts about some basic topics;
The students can describe in simple (yet grammatically correct) terms aspects of their background, immediate environment and matters in areas of immediate need;
The students can communicate in simple and routine tasks requiring a simple and direct exchange of information on familiar and routine matters;
The students can write short, simple texts; their grammar and spelling are correct;
The students master the most basic structures of French grammar and are able to explain them in their own words;
The students gain basic knowledge of French-speaking countries or settings, and are able to handle some intercultural communication skills.
The aimed CERF level at the end of the course is A1 (basic).", "Course Content
This is an online course. Students learn to handle a variety of basic communicative tasks, including understanding spoken French, speaking French, reading texts and writing short – yet grammatically correct – texts. Students will train sentences and frequently used expressions related to areas of most immediate relevance (e. g. very basic personal and family information, shopping, food). Students learn essential verbs, nouns and cases while working to build vocabulary and learn the basics of French grammar, syntax and spelling. Students practice listening, speaking, reading, and writing skills. Students will also be introduced to French culture through short texts and videos from the internet, TV, magazines and newspapers.", "Additional Information Teaching Methods
Seminars (2×2 hours per week): discussion of assigned readings and language exercises; practical training; self study.", "Method of Assessment
Mandatory weekly assignments (25%) and final oral exam (75%). Contrary to the standard exam schedule, resits of the oral exam French 1 will take place in week 7 of period 2. In this way, students will have the possibility to retake the French 1 exam before they participate in the French 2 exam.", "Literature
Édito A1 Course book (newest edition, 2022): ISBN 978-2278104468.
Édito A1 Exercise book (newest edition, 2022): ISBN 978-2278103652.
You must have your own copy of both books before the start of the course.
IMPORTANT: Please make sure that you purchase the right edition (2022): check the ISBN!", "Additional Information Target Audience
Anybody who is interested in discovering their French;
BA 2 students in History and International Studies.", "Additional Information
PLEASE NOTE:
This is a 100% online course.
This course is worth 6 EC. According to European regulations, 1 EC represents 25 to 30 hours of study (including class attendance, mandatory weekly assignments, and exams). This means that you will need to spend 150 to 180 hours if you want to pass, even if you have prior knowledge of French.
This course is highly focused on grammar.
Some students may experience this course as challenging.
If you decide to enroll in this course, you have read and understood this Course Description and the Study Guide (the latter will be available on Canvas end of July)."]
course_content: This is an online course. Students learn to handle a variety of basic communicative tasks, including understanding spoken French, speaking French, reading texts and writing short – yet grammatically correct – texts. Students will train sentences and frequently used expressions related to areas of most immediate relevance (e. g. very basic personal and family information, shopping, food). Students learn essential verbs, nouns and cases while working to build vocabulary and learn the basics of French grammar, syntax and spelling. Students practice listening, speaking, reading, and writing skills. Students will also be introduced to French culture through short texts and videos from the internet, TV, magazines and newspapers.
additional_information_teaching_methods: Seminars (2×2 hours per week): discussion of assigned readings and language exercises; practical training; self study.
method_of_assessment: Mandatory weekly assignments (25%) and final oral exam (75%). Contrary to the standard exam schedule, resits of the oral exam French 1 will take place in week 7 of period 2. In this way, students will have the possibility to retake the French 1 exam before they participate in the French 2 exam.
literature:
Édito A1 Course book (newest edition, 2022): ISBN 978-2278104468.
Édito A1 Exercise book (newest edition, 2022): ISBN 978-2278103652.
You must have your own copy of both books before the start of the course.
IMPORTANT: Please make sure that you purchase the right edition (2022): check the ISBN!
additional_information_target_audience:
Anybody who is interested in discovering their French;
BA 2 students in History and International Studies.

course_paragraphs_json:
["Course Objective
Acquiring knowledge of and insight into the sound system, word formation processes and sentence structures of Moroccan Arabic. Developing basic conversation skills in Moroccan Arabic (the spoken language of large regions in Morocco, including most of the major cities). The goal of this course is to reach level A1 of the Common European Framework of Reference (CEFR). At the end of this course, you will be able to communicate in Moroccan Arabic about simple and daily life matters, such as introducing yourself, describing your family situation and housing situation, asking people for directions, and ordering food in a restaurant.", "Course Content
Language skills classes. We will not pay attention to written language as Moroccan Arabic is a language variety that is only used for oral communication.", "Additional Information Teaching Methods
2 x 2 hours of language classes per week.", "Method of Assessment
Oral and written exam. The oral exam represents two thirds of your final grade and the written exam one third. Both components must be graded at least 5.5.", "Literature
Hoogland, J. (2018). The Routledge introductory course in Moroccan Arabic.", "Additional Information Target Audience
Anybody who wants to learn the basics of spoken Moroccan Arabic.
The course is also open to BA 2 students in History and International Studies.", "Additional Information
The language of instruction is English."]
course_objective: Acquiring knowledge of and insight into the sound system, word formation processes and sentence structures of Moroccan Arabic. At the end of this course, you will be able to communicate in Moroccan Arabic about simple and daily life matters, such as introducing yourself, describing your family situation and housing situation, asking people for directions, and ordering food in a restaurant.

course_paragraphs_json:
["Course Objective
Introduces you to the Spanish language on a basic level which is level A1 of active language skills and level A2 of passive language skills (CEFR). Get a basic knowledge of all the grammar and vocabulary of the book that is used. On completing this course students can participate in simple conversations, read and understand simple texts and write a short text about every day subjects.", "Course Content
The minor course Spanish 1 (6ec) introduces you to the Spanish language on a basic level. You will reach level A1 of active language skills and level A2 of passive language skills (CEFR). This means that you can participate in simple conversations, read and understand simple texts and write a short text about every day subjects.", "Additional Information Teaching Methods
Two 90 minutes seminars per week. Please note: 80% attendance is compulsory: you cannot miss more than three lectures.", "Method of Assessment
Written exam", "Literature
Aula Internacional Plus 1. Corpas, Jaime et al. Uitgeverij Talenland (Publishers) aulainternacional.difusion.com", "Additional Information Target Audience
The minor Spanish is open to all bachelor students, including BA 2 students History and International Studies. If you are a master student you are also allowed to follow this course but do not forget: your credits in Spanish do not count for your master program.", "Additional Information
In this course all lectures are in English language."]

On completing this course students can participate in simple conversations, read and understand simple texts and write a short text about every day subjects.

course_paragraphs_json:
["Course Objective
Dutch Language is intended for FGW/HIS students: they receive curricular credits for this.
The goal is to learn Dutch to use, to improve your general oral and written language skills. Communication objectives can be linked to the levels of the CEFR.
Dutch language is not a course Dutch linguistics. Everything is focused on communication and language use. Of course you will learn something about grammar and phonology, but not on an academic theoretical level.
For students who do not yet speak Dutch, the intended end goal is A2+. If you start at a higher level, the intended language proficiency level is also higher. You will receive 12 credits if you have made sufficient effort (attendance and homework) and have passed two courses, one intensive day course and one semi-intensive evening course, regardless of the level you reach.
For Dutch Language you do one intensive day course (4x per week lesson) and one less intensive evening course (2x per week lessons).
Day courses:
0 - A2: lessons on Monday, Tuesday, Thursday, Friday; 3 contact hours per lesson, at least 3 hours of homework per lesson.
A2 - B1: classes on Monday, Tuesday, Thursday, Friday; 3 contact hours per lesson, at least 3 hours of homework per lesson.
B1 - B1+: lessons on Monday evening and Thursday evening; 2.5 contact hours per lesson, at least 2.5 hours of homework per lesson.
B1+ - B2: lessons on Monday evening and Thursday evening; 2.5 contact hours per lesson, at least 2.5 hours of homework per lesson.
Evening courses:
0 - A1: lessons on Monday evening and Thursday evening; 2.5 contact hours per lesson, at least 2.5 hours of homework per lesson.
A1 - A2: lessons on Monday evening and Thursday evening; 2.5 contact hours per lesson, at least 2.5 hours of homework per lesson.
A2 - A2+: lessons on Monday evening and Thursday evening; 2.5 contact hours per lesson, at least 2.5 hours of homework per lesson.
A2+ B1: lessons on Monday evening and Thursday evening; 2.5 contact hours per lesson, at least 2.5 hours of homework per lesson.
B1 - B1+: lessons on Monday evening and Thursday evening; 2.5 contact hours per lesson, at least 2.5 hours of homework per lesson.
B1+ - B2: lessons on Monday evening and Thursday evening; 2.5 contact hours per lesson, at least 2.5 hours of homework per lesson.
Special courses:
Evening - Sprint for students who speak fluent German: 0 - A2: lessons on Monday evening and Thursday evening; 2.5 contact hours per lesson, at least 2.5 hours of homework per lesson.
Evening: Professional Dutch 1 and 2 for students who have B2 level: B2 - B2+ / B2+ C1; lessons on Tuesday or Wednesday evening, 3 hours per lesson, at least 3 hours of homework per lesson.
Below are three examples of the possibilities, so you do at least one day and one evening course from our program.
NB One week before the academic year we start with the intensive day course!
A. You don't speak Dutch yet. In the first period you start the day course level 1 to A2 (4 mornings per week lessons). In our period 2 (mid-November to the end of January) you will do the next course in the evening, level 2.1, to A2 (2 evenings a week).
B. You already speak and write Dutch at A1 level. In the first period you do level 1.2) in the evening to A2 (2 evenings a week). Then you do level 2 in the day course, to B1 (4 mornings per week lessons).
C. You already speak and write Dutch at B1 level. In the first period you do level 3 (3x a week lessons) in the day course to B1+. Then you do level 4 in the evening course, to B2 (2x a week lessons).", "Course Content
In the two course periods of 'Dutch as a second language' you will learn to communicate in Dutch on the basis of concrete language tasks. At home, you prepare the tasks with the book and online: you do vocabulary exercises, read short texts and listen to dialogues.
In the classroom, you work towards being able to complete the tasks. You practice with the words, grammar and pronunciation and do speaking assignments together with other students. You will also learn something about Dutch society and culture.
The exact course content (which language tasks you learn to perform and which themes are discussed) depends on your intake level.", "Additional Information Teaching Methods
Dutch language is about practicing skills, to acquire a certain level of proficiency. Therefore, attendance is mandatory. To earn credits, attendance must be at least 80%.
For Dutch Language, you follow one intensive day course (9 weeks, 4 lessons per week) and one less intensive evening course (8 weeks, 2 lessons per week).
The lessons (work groups) are interactive. In a group of maximum 20 students of your own level, you practice communicative language tasks which you prepare at home (you practise the vocabulary and do reading and listening assignments at home). You practice words, grammar and pronunciation and do speaking assignments in groups with other students. Your teacher speaks Dutch as much as possible, also when giving explanations and feedback. Individual feedback is mainly given on homework tasks (writing and speaking assignments).
Homework is important: you prepare for the lessons and do homework assignments after the lessons. Self-study: during the intensive daytime course, you spend at least 12 hours on homework, in the evening course at least 5 hours.", "Method of Assessment
To obtain 12 credits, the student meets the following requirements:
* Attendance: at least 80%.
* Compulsory homework done, according to the homework schedule.
* Passed the final exams of two course periods. In the final tests, we test vocabulary and all language skills.
Offline education: five tests:
vocabulary
writing skills
speaking/reading skills
listening skill
reading comprehension
In the case of an online course:
vocabulary
listening and speaking assessment
reading and writing assessment", "Literature
We use Code+. Which part you need to buy depends on the course you are taking. Above A2, you will also need the Van Dale pocket dictionary Nederlands als tweede taal (Nt2).", "Additional Information Target Audience
You will be placed in a group with 'regular' VU-NT2 students: in the daytime course these are mainly refugees, in the evening course these are (exchange) students, expats, and other migrants.", "Additional Information
If your language level allows you to start with an evening course, consult your study advisor to see if this fits into your programme. For most HIS students, starting with the intensive day course (end of August!) fits best into the programme. Please note that the course starts one week before the normal academic year.", "Custom Course Registration
Step 1: Students History and International Studies should notify dr. Chiel van den Akker before 1st July that they would like to take this module (c.m.vanden.akker@vu.nl).
Step 2: Apply via the website of VU-NT2: https://nt2.vu.nl/en/application/index.aspx. Fill in the application form. Don't forget to mention that you are a HIS student.
VU-NT2 will inform you about the procedure (intake, course dates etc). Do you have questions? Please send an e-mail to vu-nt2@vu.nl.", "Explanation Canvas
Bij de start van de cursusperiode krijg je een uitnodiging om deel te nemen aan de Canvascursus. Hierop plaatsen we het huiswerk. Je levert je huiswerk ook in via Canvas. Verder vind je hier de regels, allerlei nuttige informatie en tips om de taal goed te leren.", "Recommended background knowledge
It is easier to learn the language at this fast pace if you have previously learned another foreign language at school."]
course_objective:
Dutch Language is intended for FGW/HIS students: they receive curricular credits for this.
The goal is to learn Dutch to use, to improve your general oral and written language skills. Communication objectives can be linked to the levels of the CEFR.
Dutch language is not a course Dutch linguistics. Everything is focused on communication and language use. Of course you will learn something about grammar and phonology, but not on an academic theoretical level.
For students who do not yet speak Dutch, the intended end goal is A2+. If you start at a higher level, the intended language proficiency level is also higher. You will receive 12 credits if you have made sufficient effort (attendance and homework) and have passed two courses, one intensive day course and one semi-intensive evening course, regardless of the level you reach.
For Dutch Language you do one intensive day course (4x per week lesson) and one less intensive evening course (2x per week lessons).
Day courses:
0 - A2: lessons on Monday, Tuesday, Thursday, Friday; 3 contact hours per lesson, at least 3 hours of homework per lesson.
A2 - B1: classes on Monday, Tuesday, Thursday, Friday; 3 contact hours per lesson, at least 3 hours of homework per lesson.
B1 - B1+: lessons on Monday evening and Thursday evening; 2.5 contact hours per lesson, at least 2.5 hours of homework per lesson.
B1+ - B2: lessons on Monday evening and Thursday evening; 2.5 contact hours per lesson, at least 2.5 hours of homework per lesson.
Evening courses:
0 - A1: lessons on Monday evening and Thursday evening; 2.5 contact hours per lesson, at least 2.5 hours of homework per lesson.
A1 - A2: lessons on Monday evening and Thursday evening; 2.5 contact hours per lesson, at least 2.5 hours of homework per lesson.
A2 - A2+: lessons on Monday evening and Thursday evening; 2.5 contact hours per lesson, at least 2.5 hours of homework per lesson.
A2+ B1: lessons on Monday evening and Thursday evening; 2.5 contact hours per lesson, at least 2.5 hours of homework per lesson.
B1 - B1+: lessons on Monday evening and Thursday evening; 2.5 contact hours per lesson, at least 2.5 hours of homework per lesson.
B1+ - B2: lessons on Monday evening and Thursday evening; 2.5 contact hours per lesson, at least 2.5 hours of homework per lesson.
Special courses:
Evening - Sprint for students who speak fluent German: 0 - A2: lessons on Monday evening and Thursday evening; 2.5 contact hours per lesson, at least 2.5 hours of homework per lesson.
Evening: Professional Dutch 1 and 2 for students who have B2 level: B2 - B2+ / B2+ C1; lessons on Tuesday or Wednesday evening, 3 hours per lesson, at least 3 hours of homework per lesson.
Below are three examples of the possibilities, so you do at least one day and one evening course from our program.
NB One week before the academic year we start with the intensive day course!
A. You don't speak Dutch yet. In the first period you start the day course level 1 to A2 (4 mornings per week lessons). In our period 2 (mid-November to the end of January) you will do the next course in the evening, level 2.1, to A2 (2 evenings a week).
B. You already speak and write Dutch at A1 level. In the first period you do level 1.2) in the evening to A2 (2 evenings a week). Then you do level 2 in the day course, to B1 (4 mornings per week lessons).
C. You already speak and write Dutch at B1 level. In the first period you do level 3 (3x a week lessons) in the day course to B1+. Then you do level 4 in the evening course, to B2 (2x a week lessons).
course_content:
In the two course periods of 'Dutch as a second language' you will learn to communicate in Dutch on the basis of concrete language tasks. At home, you prepare the tasks with the book and online: you do vocabulary exercises, read short texts and listen to dialogues.
In the classroom, you work towards being able to complete the tasks. You practice with the words, grammar and pronunciation and do speaking assignments together with other students. You will also learn something about Dutch society and culture.
The exact course content (which language tasks you learn to perform and which themes are discussed) depends on your intake level.
additional_information_teaching_methods:
Dutch language is about practicing skills, to acquire a certain level of proficiency. Therefore, attendance is mandatory. To earn credits, attendance must be at least 80%.
For Dutch Language, you follow one intensive day course (9 weeks, 4 lessons per week) and one less intensive evening course (8 weeks, 2 lessons per week).
The lessons (work groups) are interactive. In a group of maximum 20 students of your own level, you practice communicative language tasks which you prepare at home (you practise the vocabulary and do reading and listening assignments at home). You practice words, grammar and pronunciation and do speaking assignments in groups with other students. Your teacher speaks Dutch as much as possible, also when giving explanations and feedback. Individual feedback is mainly given on homework tasks (writing and speaking assignments).
Homework is important: you prepare for the lessons and do homework assignments after the lessons. Self-study: during the intensive daytime course, you spend at least 12 hours on homework, in the evening course at least 5 hours.
method_of_assessment:
To obtain 12 credits, the student meets the following requirements:
* Attendance: at least 80%.
* Compulsory homework done, according to the homework schedule.
* Passed the final exams of two course periods. In the final tests, we test vocabulary and all language skills.
Offline education: five tests:
vocabulary
writing skills
speaking/reading skills
listening skill
reading comprehension
In the case of an online course:
vocabulary
listening and speaking assessment
reading and writing assessment
literature: We use Code+. Which part you need to buy depends on the course you are taking. Above A2, you will also need the Van Dale pocket dictionary Nederlands als tweede taal (Nt2).
additional_information_target_audience: You will be placed in a group with 'regular' VU-NT2 students: in the daytime course these are mainly refugees, in the evening course these are (exchange) students, expats, and other migrants.
recommended_background_knowledge: It is easier to learn the language at this fast pace if you have previously learned another foreign language at school.
