het wetenschappelijke ‘apparaat’ (woordenboeken, digitale middelen, o.a. MNW, WNT, STCN, BNTL, Biografisch Portaal, enz.) adequaat toepassen bij het zelf uitvoeren van een onderzoek.
uitleggen hoe canonisatie en literatuurgeschiedschrijving bijdragen aan een steeds wisselend beeld van de literatuur van Middeleeuwen, Rederijkerstijd, Renaissance en vroege Verlichting.
reflecteren op de afstand tussen je eigen schrijverschap en het auteurschap van auteurs uit het verleden door oude literaire vormen zelf toe te passen.
course_content: In deze module maken de studenten kennis met de Nederlandse literatuur van de Middeleeuwen tot de vroege 18de eeuw. Die literatuur is voor een deel vreemd en anders dan de moderne letterkunde, tegelijkertijd is er veel herkenbaar en zelfs actueel. In dit college, dat de periode 1100-1720 bestrijkt, worden de Middeleeuwen, rederijkerstijd, renaissance en het classicisme behandeld aan de hand van een syllabus en een keuze aan teksten. Uit de Middeleeuwen komen onder meer de ridderroman en religieuze lyriek aan bod. De rederijkerij is een cultureel wapen in de handen van met name de stedelijke burgerij. Vanaf 1550 begint de renaissance, auteurs gaan zich richten naar (meestal aan de oudheid ontleende) voorschriften, voorbeelden en theorieën. Tegelijkertijd vinden er belangrijke ontwikkelingen plaats in de politieke en religieuze situatie in de Nederlanden, die leiden tot de vorming van de Republiek. In de zeventiende eeuw, de Gouden Eeuw, groeit ons land uit tot een wereldmacht. Bij de behandeling van de teksten ligt de nadruk, behalve op de literaire ontwikkelingen, ook steeds op de maatschappelijke rol die teksten in de samenleving hebben vervuld, van statusverhoging tot politiek wapen, en van vermaak tot emancipatoire kracht. Aan de hand van een individuele praktijkopdracht krijgt de student een basisvaardigheid in het omgaan met de wetenschappelijk hulpmiddelen voor het vak. Ook maken de studenten creatieve opdrachten waarin ze hun kennis van de oudere literatuur verwerken.
additional_information_teaching_methods:
Er is wekelijks een hoorcollege (1:45 uur), een werkcollege (1:45 uur) en een practicum (3:45 uur). Tijdens het hoorcollege wordt de stof geïntroduceerd, tijdens het werkcollege worden de gemaakte verwerkingsopdrachten besproken. drie creatieve opdrachten, waarvan er twee elk voor 10% meetellen met het eindcijfer. Bovendien moet je een creatieve opdracht naar keuze opnemen in je portfolio.

course_paragraphs_json:
["Course Objective
Als je dit vak hebt afgerond, kun je:
beschrijven hoe het uitgeefproces van een (literaire) uitgeverij in de praktijk functioneert en welke rollen daarbij vervuld moeten worden.
diverse rollen vervullen bij het samenstellen van een groepspublicatie (auteur, uitgever, (beeld)redacteur marketeer).
originele creatieve bijdragen in uiteenlopende genres leveren aan de groepspublicatie over een bepaald thema, daarbij rekeninghoudend met het publiek.
jezelf committeren aan de samenwerking en verantwoordelijkheid nemen voor het eigen aandeel bij het realiseren van een groepspublicatie.
constructieve feedback geven aan medestudenten binnen een groepsproces.
je eigen werk en dat van anderen met een redacteursoog evalueren en op basis van ontvangen feedback verbeteren.
de ontwikkeling die je als auteur het afgelopen collegejaar hebt doorgemaakt analyseren en evalueren.", "Course Content
Gedurende het eerste jaar van je studie ‘Creatief Schrijven Nederlands’ heb je een aantal teksten geschreven en verzameld in je portfolio. Ook heb je in cursussen geleerd over de productie, distributie en receptie van literatuur; in sommige colleges werd in het bijzonder aandacht besteed aan het uitgeven van teksten. In het vak ‘Pop-up Uitgeverij’ gaan jullie die zaken bij elkaar brengen. Met de eigen geschreven teksten uit het portfolio én nieuw werk, gaan jullie in groepsverband een (e-)magazine maken. Je leert daarbij de problemen en dilemma’s die bij het uitgeven van een tekst een rol spelen van binnenuit kennen. Daarbij verdiep je je kennis van het uitgeverijwezen. Elk jaar heeft het magazine een ander thema dat jullie zelf mogen kiezen – zolang het maar verband houdt met literatuur en samenleving en rekening houdt met de interesses van het door jullie beoogde publiek. Jullie zijn vrij om in overleg met je team en de hoofdredacteur teksten en media in allerlei soorten en maten aan te leveren als deze maar te maken hebben met het door jullie gekozen centrale thema. Eén tekst staat vast: iedereen schrijft een eigen zogenoemde longread over een onderwerp naar keuze dat te maken heeft met het thema van jullie tijdschrift. Iedereen heeft tijdens het maakproces minstens twee verschillende rollen.", "Additional Information Teaching Methods
Bij de organisatie van en het werken aan het e-magazine hebben jullie veel vrijheid. Jullie zitten aan het stuur. De colleges en de practica zijn bedoeld ter ondersteuning en contextualisering. De hoorcolleges plaatsen de practicumopdracht (het maken van het magazine) in een breder literatuurwetenschappelijk kader. Deze hoorcolleges gaan in op recente ontwikkelingen binnen het uitgeversvak. De werkcolleges gaan steeds in op tricks, tools en dilemma’s, relevant bij het opzetten en publiceren van een e-magazine. Tijdens de practica werk je met je medestudenten aan het magazine.
Aanwezigheid: actieve deelname is verplicht bij alle colleges en practica. Bij niet deelnemen moet ongeacht de reden van afwezigheid een extra opdracht gemaakt worden.", "Method of Assessment
Opdrachten en toetsing:
Het eindcijfer is het resultaat van het gewogen gemiddelde van de volgende cijfers:
Cijfer practicumopdracht (e-magazine): 70%, waarvan 30% voor de groep als geheel (cijfer is dus voor iedereen hetzelfde) en 40% individueel (de eigen geleverde content)
Cijfer presentatie over de geschreven bijdrage in relatie tot thema en publiek: 30%
Reflectie op de teksten in het portfolio (voldaan/niet voldaan)
Alle deelopdrachten moeten met een voldoende worden beoordeeld om de cursus af te kunnen ronden.", "Literature
Je leest theoretische en praktische teksten over uitgeven en content marketing. Joost Nijsens ABC van de literaire uitgeverij (Amsterdam: Podium, 2012) is een handige wegwijzer voor wat betreft het uitgeverijbedrijf en kan je attent maken op andere mogelijk relevante secundaire literatuur. Je zult er vaak iets uit lezen. Het is te leen in de VU-bibliotheek, of te verkrijgen op bol.com. Overige literatuur is digitaal beschikbaar. De bibliografie vind je aan het eind van deze handleiding en zal gedurende de cursus worden aangevuld.", "Additional Information Target Audience
Het vak is bedoeld voor eerstejaarsstudenten Creatief Schrijven Nederlands."]

course_paragraphs_json:
["Course Objective
Kennismaking met enkele belangrijke periodes en stromingen binnen de (Europese) literatuur vanaf de Oudheid tot en met de negentiende eeuw aan de hand van klassiek geworden meesterwerken. Aan het eind van de cursus kun je:
canoniseringsprocessen beschrijven;
aan de hand van klassiek geworden literaire werken enkele belangrijke periodes en stromingen binnen de (Europese) literatuur vanaf de Oudheid tot eind negentiende eeuw noemen;
de inhoud van klassiek geworden literaire werken samenvatten;
de receptie van klassiek geworden literaire werken beschrijven;
klassiek geworden literaire werken uit de wereldliteratuur in hun cultuurhistorische en maatschappelijke context plaatsen;
aan de hand van de bestudeerde (technieken in) literaire werken zelf een (korte) creatieve tekst schrijven (voor de studenten Creatief schrijven).", "Course Content
Elke week, dat wil zeggen vóór elk college, leest de student een ‘literair meesterwerk’ met de bijbehorende secundaire literatuur. Bij de bespreking van elke tekst gaan we in op de redenen waarom deze als een meesterwerk wordt beschouwd: status in het literaire veld, literaire prijzen, aandacht in wetenschappelijke studies en receptie. Soms zal de docent naast het te lezen meesterwerk ook enkele fragmenten uit andere canonieke teksten uit de betreffende periode/stroming bespreken.", "Additional Information Teaching Methods
Een college per week.", "Method of Assessment
Schriftelijk tentamen na periode 1, wekelijks korte schriftelijke opdrachten over het te behandelen werk en na periode 1 een creatieve opdracht (voor de studenten uit de specialisatie Creatief Schrijven Nederlands). Alle opdrachten moeten met een voldoende (5,5) worden afgesloten. De korte schriftelijke opdrachten dienen op Canvas te worden ingeleverd voor aanvang van het betreffende college.
Het eindcijfer van de minorstudenten bestaat uit deze korte schriftelijke opdrachten (10%) en het schriftelijke tentamen (90%).
Het eindcijfer van de studenten in de specialisatie Creatief Schrijven Nederlands bestaat uit de korte schriftelijke opdrachten (10%), het schriftelijk tentamen (50%) en een creatieve opdracht (40%). Verder: actieve participatie, blijkend uit inbreng tijdens de discussie over de te lezen teksten.", "Literature
Na een algemene inleiding over theoretische kwesties als periodisering, classificering en canonvorming worden vijf werken besproken. De definitieve leeslijst zal zo snel mogelijk op Canvas bekend worden gemaakt, maar in elk geval worden de volgende werken gelezen: Thomas More (Utopia), Ivan Toergenjev (Eerste liefde) en Gustave Flaubert (Madame Bovary – in de vertaling van Hans van Pinxteren). De teksten moeten in Nederlandse vertaling gelezen worden. De te lezen secundaire literatuur wordt via Canvas bekendgemaakt.", "Additional Information Target Audience
Dit is een verplicht vak voor studenten van de bachelor Creatief Schrijven Nederlands. Ook is het een verplicht onderdeel van de minor Nederlands ‘De Schrijfacademie’. Een vervolg op dit college is voor hen ‘Wereldliteratuur 2’ (periode 2 + 3, 6 EC). Zie voor de andere verplichte onderdelen van deze minor de studiegids.", "Additional Information
Er is verplichte aanwezigheid (minimaal 80% aanwezigheid).
Dit onderdeel vormt inhoudelijk één geheel met Wereldliteratuur 2, maar kan zelfstandig gevolgd worden. In dit eerste deel komt de literatuur tot en met de negentiende eeuw aan bod; in het tweede deel staan de twintigste en de eenentwintigste eeuw centraal."]
course_content: Elke week, dat wil zeggen vóór elk college, leest de student een ‘literair meesterwerk’ met de bijbehorende secundaire literatuur. Bij de bespreking van elke tekst gaan we in op de redenen waarom deze als een meesterwerk wordt beschouwd: status in het literaire veld, literaire prijzen, aandacht in wetenschappelijke studies en receptie. Soms zal de docent naast het te lezen meesterwerk ook enkele fragmenten uit andere canonieke teksten uit de betreffende periode/stroming bespreken.
additional_information_teaching_methods: Een college per week.
method_of_assessment:
Schriftelijk tentamen na periode 1, wekelijks korte schriftelijke opdrachten over het te behandelen werk en na periode 1 een creatieve opdracht (voor de studenten uit de specialisatie Creatief Schrijven Nederlands). Alle opdrachten moeten met een voldoende (5,5) worden afgesloten. De korte schriftelijke opdrachten dienen op Canvas te worden ingeleverd voor aanvang van het betreffende college.
Het eindcijfer van de minorstudenten bestaat uit deze korte schriftelijke opdrachten (10%) en het schriftelijke tentamen (90%).
Het eindcijfer van de studenten in de specialisatie Creatief Schrijven Nederlands bestaat uit de korte schriftelijke opdrachten (10%), het schriftelijk tentamen (50%) en een creatieve opdracht (40%). Verder: actieve participatie, blijkend uit inbreng tijdens de discussie over de te lezen teksten.
literature: Na een algemene inleiding over theoretische kwesties als periodisering, classificering en canonvorming worden vijf werken besproken. De definitieve leeslijst zal zo snel mogelijk op Canvas bekend worden gemaakt, maar in elk geval worden de volgende werken gelezen: Thomas More (Utopia), Ivan Toergenjev (Eerste liefde) en Gustave Flaubert (Madame Bovary – in de vertaling van Hans van Pinxteren). De teksten moeten in Nederlandse vertaling gelezen worden. De te lezen secundaire literatuur wordt via Canvas bekendgemaakt.
additional_information_target_audience: Dit is een verplicht vak voor studenten van de bachelor Creatief Schrijven Nederlands. Ook is het een verplicht onderdeel van de minor Nederlands ‘De Schrijfacademie’. Een vervolg op dit college is voor hen ‘Wereldliteratuur 2’ (periode 2 + 3, 6 EC). Zie voor de andere verplichte onderdelen van deze minor de studiegids.

course_content: Hoe kun je je publiek boeien vanaf de eerste zin? Hoe schrijf je een pakkende tekst? Deze vragen houden de literatuur sinds de klassieke oudheid bezig en de antwoorden zijn ook buiten de literatuur relevant. Immers, een advocaat moet zijn gehoor weten te overtuigen van de onschuld van zijn cliënt of van verzachtende omstandigheden. En een politicus moet zijn boodschap duidelijk kunnen overbrengen om kiezers te overtuigen. Na enkele introducerende colleges over de klassieke retorica, analyseer je enkele essays, geef je een presentatie van je bevindingen, maak je een opzet voor een eigen essay en schrijf je ten slotte zelf een essay.

course_content:
Bij het vak Creatief Schrijven II diep je in een reeks werkcolleges een aantal centrale theoretische begrippen uit de verteltechniek uit. Dit aan de hand van verschillende fragmenten, verhalen en andere teksten van belangwekkende Nederlandstalige auteurs. We bestuderen de stijl en inzet van deze schrijvers, brengen hun poëtica in kaart – als opmaat om een eigen poëtica te ontwikkelen.
De te lezen romans, verhalen en fragmenten vormen de bron om door creatieve nabootsing én variatie tot oorspronkelijke vertellingen te komen. Speciale aandacht zal daarbij besteed worden aan het bewustzijn van personages en hoe een spanningsboog – mét maar ook zonder een evidente plot – kan worden opgebouwd. Dat gebeurt aan de hand van de opgegeven literatuur, ook door het bestuderen van schrijfhandleidingen, waarover studenten korte presentaties geven, waarbij ze telkens ook een schrijfopdracht formuleren. Die presentatie is het fundament van een essay over een afzonderlijke schrijfmethode.
Tot slot, maar zeker niet in de laatste plaats, gaan studenten iedere week fictionele teksten schrijven, waarvan er één gaandeweg in omvang groeit.
additional_information_teaching_methods: Werkcolleges
method_of_assessment:
Actieve participatie en aanwezigheid (80% van de colleges) is verplicht; de student moet mee kunnen discussiëren en er blijk van geven inzicht te hebben en mee kunnen praten over de in de oefeningen behandelde schrijftechnieken en de opgegeven literatuur. Onder actieve participatie wordt ook verstaan dat de student zich aan de opgegeven deadlines houdt. Getoetst wordt op:
een afgeronde fictionele tekst van 2000 woorden: 50% van het eindcijfer;
een beschouwend essay van circa 1000 woorden over een schrijfhandleiding literatuur (met als basis een over dat boek gegeven presentatie): 50% van het eindcijfer.
Alle onderdelen moeten minstens met een 5,5 beoordeeld zijn om het vak te halen.
literature: Te lezen primaire en secundaire teksten worden voor aanvang van de cursus via Canvas bekendgemaakt.
additional_information_target_audience: Het vak is bedoeld voor studenten van de BA-track Creatief schrijven Nederlands.

course_content:
In het college Grammatica verdiep je je in de syntaxis en de semantiek van het Nederlands. Je leert hoe Nederlandse zinnen in elkaar zitten en hoe in het Nederlands betekenis kan worden uitgedrukt met behulp van talige vormen (woorden, zinsdelen, zinnen, paragrafen). Schoolgrammatica is doorgaans gericht op het aanleren van foefjes om een bepaald label op een woordgroep te plakken (onderwerp), zonder dat dit tot inzichten leidt. In deze cursus gaat het juist om die inzichten. Een beter begrip van de structuur van taal en de manier waarop betekenis tot stand komt, geeft je de mogelijkheid om op taalgebruik te reflecteren. Ook op creatief taalgebruik, en dus op je eigen creatieve werk. Waarom heeft een bepaalde zin een zeker effect, waarom heeft een andere formulering dat minder? Met grammaticaal inzicht en de beheersing van de terminologie kun je dat analyseren en erover discussiëren. Deze reflectie kan je ook in staat stellen beter (efficiënter, doelbewuster) te gaan praten en schrijven.
In deze cursus vergaar je bovendien een deel van de kennis en vaardigheden die nodig zijn voor een didactische vervolgopleiding.
additional_information_teaching_methods: Werkcolleges
literature: wordt op de eerste bijeenkomst duidelijk gemaakt
additional_information_target_audience: Het vak is bedoeld voor studenten van de BA-track Creatief schrijven Nederlands. Andere belangstellenden die Nederlandstalig zijn, zijn van harte welkom.
recommended_background_knowledge: De cursus Introduction Linguistics van de VU wordt sterk aanbevolen. Studenten dievergelijkbare introducties in de Taalwetenschap hebben gevolgd kunnen eveneens deelnemen. Neem daarvoor contact op met de docent.

course_paragraphs_json:
["Course Objective
Aan het eind van deze cursus kun je:
opvattingen in de literatuurwetenschap over vormen en functies van verhalen uitleggen;
secundaire literatuur over vormen en functies van verhalen evalueren;
enkele specifieke vormen van verhalen (in hun historische ontwikkeling) herkennen en methoden toepassen om deze verhalen te analyseren.
de theorie over verhalen en hun functies in verschillende media uiteenzetten.", "Course Content
Verhalen vormen een van de belangrijkste onderwerpen van de literatuurwetenschap. De theorie van vertellen en verhalen, de narratologie, is nog steeds een centrale literatuurwetenschappelijke theorie. In dit onderdeel wordt de analyse van de vorm van verhalen gekoppeld aan hun functie. Die functie kun je op verschillende manieren bestuderen: theoretisch, interpretatief, historisch en empirisch. Het accent ligt op de specifieke vorm en functie van narratieve teksten.
Waarin onderscheidt een verhaal zich van een argumentatieve tekst? Wat is kenmerkend voor een literair verhaal? Hoe onderscheidt zich dat van verhalen in bijvoorbeeld de Bijbel of de rechtspraak? Hebben verhalen specifieke functies, denk aan identificatie en empathie, die niet-verhalende teksten missen? Ook zijn er in de literatuur verhalende genres met een specifieke functie ontstaan zoals requiemliteratuur en fantasy of met een specifieke vorm, zoals de graphic novel? In dit onderdeel verken je het denken over de vormen en functies van verhalende teksten in en buiten de literatuur.", "Additional Information Teaching Methods

Schriftelijk tentamen (70% van het eindcijfer).
Drie tussentijdse opdrachten (30% van het eindcijfer).
Beide deeltoetsen dienen met een voldoende (minimaal 5,5) te worden afgesloten.", "Literature
Elke week komen een primaire tekst en enkele artikelen aan de orde. De precieze opgave daarvan staat in de studiehandleiding op Canvas.", "Additional Information Target Audience
Studenten uit de bachelorspecialisatie Creatief Schrijven Nederlands."]

course_paragraphs_json:
["Course Objective
Als je deze cursus hebt gevolgd kan je:
uitleggen welke  dynamische intermediale  relaties tussen literatuur en aangrenzende media  bestaan;
theorieën  over intertekstualiteit en intermedialiteit toepassen in eigen creatief werk;
met behulp van de  kennis over genrekenmerken, een tekst herschrijven  naar een ander tekstgenre of andere kunstvorm  (filmscript, film, jeugdboek etc).", "Course Content
In dit vak concentreren we ons op adaptaties van literaire teksten en narratieve aspecten van relaties tussen woord en beeld en daarmee op vragen als: hoe kun je een literair verhaal bewerken voor een ander publiek of omzetten in een ander genre, toneelstuk of film en hoe ondersteunen beelden een (literair) verhaal?
Na een introducerend hoorcollege over adaptaties, intermedialiteit en storytelling richten we ons in werkcolleges op verschillende soorten bewerkingen van (literaire) teksten (zoals bewerkingen voor een jeugdig publiek) of een ander medium: toneel- en film. Daarnaast richten we ons ook op films als zelfstandig verhalend werk (als speelfilm of korte reclamefilm) en scenario’s.
Gastcolleges van bekende toneel- en scenarioschrijvers en filmers maken onderdeel uit van het vak.", "Additional Information Teaching Methods
Werkcolleges (2 x 2 uur per week)", "Method of Assessment
Toetsing:
Participatie, aanwezigheid en tussentijdse opdrachten moeten voldoende zijn (geen cijfer) (10 %)
Mondelinge presentatie (30 %) naar aanleiding van een van de onderwerpen die op college aan bod zijn geweest.
Creatieve opdracht (60%) in de vorm van een bewerking van een literaire tekst voor een ander publiek. Dit kan een tekst zijn in een ander genre, een korte film of een scenario. Alle creatieve producten moeten vergezeld zijn van een analyse en toelichting.
Voor beide onderdelen (mondelinge presentatie en creatieve opdracht) moet minimaal een 5.5 gehaald zijn.", "Literature
Primaire en secundaire teksten worden voor aanvang van de cursus via Canvas bekendgemaakt.", "Additional Information Target Audience

course_paragraphs_json:
["Course Objective
Na het volgen van deze cursus kun je:
Een gedicht uit het hoofd voordragen.
Aan de hand van stijlkenmerken het werk van verschillende dichters onderscheiden.
Een persoonlijke canon (eigen bloemlezing van gedichten) onderbouwen.
Zelf een gedicht schrijven met een duidelijk herkenbare, persoonlijke stijl, met het oog op een publieke voordracht.
De stilistische keuzes in een zelfgeschreven gedicht onderbouwen.
De stilistische keuzes in gedichten van medestudenten beoordelen.", "Course Content
In deze cursus vergroot je je belezenheid, je schrijfvaardigheid en je podiumervaring. Je leest gedichten van klassieke en hedendaagse auteurs en onderzoekt wat hun stijl herkenbaar maakt. Je schrijft ook zelf gedichten, waarbij je jouw persoonlijke vorm, stem en stijl verder ontwikkelt. In de cursus wordt veel aandacht besteed aan voordracht (al dan niet uit het hoofd). Voor wie dat wil, is er de mogelijkheid om toe te werken naar een voordracht bij Poetry International.", "Additional Information Teaching Methods
Twee werkcolleges per week, van 3.45 uur (verplichte aanwezigheid – je mag hooguit één bijeenkomst missen in geval van onvoorziene omstandigheden). De overige tijd besteed je aan het voorbereiden van de opdrachten.
Tijdens de cursus brengen we een bezoek aan Poetry International (verplichte deelname, op eigen kosten).", "Method of Assessment
Er zijn 5 verplichte opdrachten en één bonusopdracht. De vijf verplichte opdrachten tellen ieder voor 20% mee. De bonusopdracht kan het cijfer van één van de andere opdrachten vervangen (je moet wel eerst alle opdrachten gedaan hebben). De opdrachten 1 tot en met 3 hebben betrekking op het werk van dichters van de website van Poetry International. De opdrachten 4 tot en met 6 hebben betrekking op het eigen werk van studenten.
Minibloemlezing Poetry-dichters inclusief onderbouwing van de samenstelling (20%)
Analyse en identificatie stijl van Poetry-dichters (20%)
Voordracht gedicht van een Poetry-dichter (20%)
Creatieve opdracht: schrijf een eigen gedicht inclusief onderbouwing van stilistische keuzes (20%)
Analyse en identificatie stijl van medestudenten (20%)
BONUS-opdracht: Voordracht eigen werk bij Poetry (20%)", "Literature
Te lezen secundaire teksten worden voor aanvang van de cursus via Canvas bekendgemaakt.
Tijdens de cursus maken we voor de primaire teksten gebruik van het archief op de website van Poetry International: https://www.poetryinternational.com/en/poets-poems/poems.", "Additional Information Target Audience
De cursus is uitsluitend toegankelijk voor tweedejaars studenten Creatief Schrijven Nederlands.", "Additional Information
Verplichte workshop van Poetry International in semester 2 voorafgaand aan de cursus. Deelname aan de workshop is een ingangseis voor de cursus. Aan deze workshop zijn geen kosten verbonden voor de student.
Verplicht bezoek aan Poetry International tijdens de cursus. Daaraan zijn kosten verbonden voor de student (ter indicatie het studententarief 2025: 17,50 euro).", "Recommended background knowledge
Je moet de volgende cursussen met succes hebben afgerond:
Literaire analyse
Literatuurwetenschap
Schrijvers aan het werk I, II en III"]

Zelf een gedicht schrijven met een duidelijk herkenbare, persoonlijke stijl, met het oog op een publieke voordracht.

De stilistische keuzes in gedichten van medestudenten beoordelen.
course_content: In deze cursus vergroot je je belezenheid, je schrijfvaardigheid en je podiumervaring. Je leest gedichten van klassieke en hedendaagse auteurs en onderzoekt wat hun stijl herkenbaar maakt. Je schrijft ook zelf gedichten, waarbij je jouw persoonlijke vorm, stem en stijl verder ontwikkelt. In de cursus wordt veel aandacht besteed aan voordracht (al dan niet uit het hoofd). Voor wie dat wil, is er de mogelijkheid om toe te werken naar een voordracht bij Poetry International.
additional_information_teaching_methods:
Twee werkcolleges per week, van 3.45 uur (verplichte aanwezigheid – je mag hooguit één bijeenkomst missen in geval van onvoorziene omstandigheden). De overige tijd besteed je aan het voorbereiden van de opdrachten.
Tijdens de cursus brengen we een bezoek aan Poetry International (verplichte deelname, op eigen kosten).
method_of_assessment:
Er zijn 5 verplichte opdrachten en één bonusopdracht. De vijf verplichte opdrachten tellen ieder voor 20% mee. De bonusopdracht kan het cijfer van één van de andere opdrachten vervangen (je moet wel eerst alle opdrachten gedaan hebben). De opdrachten 1 tot en met 3 hebben betrekking op het werk van dichters van de website van Poetry International. De opdrachten 4 tot en met 6 hebben betrekking op het eigen werk van studenten.
Minibloemlezing Poetry-dichters inclusief onderbouwing van de samenstelling (20%)
Analyse en identificatie stijl van Poetry-dichters (20%)
Voordracht gedicht van een Poetry-dichter (20%)
Creatieve opdracht: schrijf een eigen gedicht inclusief onderbouwing van stilistische keuzes (20%)
Analyse en identificatie stijl van medestudenten (20%)
BONUS-opdracht: Voordracht eigen werk bij Poetry (20%)
literature:
Te lezen secundaire teksten worden voor aanvang van de cursus via Canvas bekendgemaakt.
Tijdens de cursus maken we voor de primaire teksten gebruik van het archief op de website van Poetry International: https://www.poetryinternational.com/en/poets-poems/poems.
additional_information_target_audience: De cursus is uitsluitend toegankelijk voor tweedejaars studenten Creatief Schrijven Nederlands.
recommended_background_knowledge:
Je moet de volgende cursussen met succes hebben afgerond:
Literaire analyse
Literatuurwetenschap
Schrijvers aan het werk I, II en III

course_paragraphs_json:
["Course Objective
At the end of the course:
Students will be able to recall key concepts and debates about the relationship between literature and society.
Students will understand, interpret and explain literary and critical texts from diverse national, cultural, and historical backgrounds.
Students will be able to apply their knowledge to a variety of literary texts and present their research findings both in writing and verbally.
Students will analyse and break down complex texts and debates to understand their components and relationships.
Students will be able to evaluate, assess and critique literary works and peer feedback, providing constructive criticism.
Students will creatively produce original research and presentations, synthesising their understanding and analysis of the texts.", "Course Content
For centuries, literary and other cultural texts have changed the way people think and look at the world. They reveal social injustices and societal ills, offering ideas and ammunition for social change, thereby helping people to imagine different, better realities. A single text may trigger an individual’s struggle for emancipation, but also that of a group or a nation. This course will explore the important ways in which literary texts have contributed to societal change and have liberated people throughout the centuries up to the present.
The texts we discuss have instigated individual readers as well as collectivities to discover and become aware of injustices, unfairness and abuse. This course analyzes that process, using the following questions as leading threads in the discussions: Which rhetorical strategies employed in the texts evoke the readers’ empathy and possible agency? How do the texts simultaneously assist in emboldening the reader, strengthening an emerging community, and gaining acceptance from a wider audience? In which way do they balance realities that are already being lived and imagined possibilities that have yet to materialize? How do they interact with other expressions of the struggle for emancipation, by way of imitation, opposition, appropriation? And, finally, how do they function within the communities that they have helped found, how are they remembered, recreated, redefined, and to which purposes?", "Additional Information Teaching Methods
Students and instructor meet three times per week: Lectures, 1 x 2 hours per week. Seminar meetings, 2 x 2 hours per week.", "Method of Assessment
Assessment: Participation (20%), written task (50%), and final report (30%).
Students will only receive credits for the course if their grade for the written exam is 5.5 or higher. They are not allowed to compensate an exam grade that is below 5.5 with other partial grades.", "Literature
Primary and secondary sources; to be announced on Canvas.", "Additional Information Target Audience
This course is only open for first year students of Literature & Society: English, or students enrolled in the Schoolvakminor English Literature.
Please note, this course is NOT suitable for exchange students.", "Additional Information
This course is obligatory in the first year. Attendance required: 80% (including lectures, seminars, practicums). Students who miss more than 20% will not receive credits for the course. Exceptions may be made in grave personal circumstances. Make sure to inform both your lecturer and the academic advisor in such cases.", "Custom Course Registration
There is a slightly different enrollment procedure for this module. The standard procedure of the Faculty of Humanities has students sign up for (i) the module, and (ii) the form of tuition (lecture and/or preferred seminar group). However, for this module the instructor will assign the students to the seminar groups. Therefore, students should sign up for (i) the module, but not for (ii) the seminar groups.", "Recommended background knowledge
The history and literature of social movements such as feminism and the abolitionist and anti-apartheid movements."]
course_objective:
At the end of the course:
Students will be able to recall key concepts and debates about the relationship between literature and society.
Students will understand, interpret and explain literary and critical texts from diverse national, cultural, and historical backgrounds.
Students will be able to apply their knowledge to a variety of literary texts and present their research findings both in writing and verbally.
Students will analyse and break down complex texts and debates to understand their components and relationships.
Students will be able to evaluate, assess and critique literary works and peer feedback, providing constructive criticism.
Students will creatively produce original research and presentations, synthesising their understanding and analysis of the texts.
course_content:
For centuries, literary and other cultural texts have changed the way people think and look at the world. They reveal social injustices and societal ills, offering ideas and ammunition for social change, thereby helping people to imagine different, better realities. A single text may trigger an individual’s struggle for emancipation, but also that of a group or a nation. This course will explore the important ways in which literary texts have contributed to societal change and have liberated people throughout the centuries up to the present.
The texts we discuss have instigated individual readers as well as collectivities to discover and become aware of injustices, unfairness and abuse. This course analyzes that process, using the following questions as leading threads in the discussions: Which rhetorical strategies employed in the texts evoke the readers’ empathy and possible agency? How do the texts simultaneously assist in emboldening the reader, strengthening an emerging community, and gaining acceptance from a wider audience? In which way do they balance realities that are already being lived and imagined possibilities that have yet to materialize? How do they interact with other expressions of the struggle for emancipation, by way of imitation, opposition, appropriation? And, finally, how do they function within the communities that they have helped found, how are they remembered, recreated, redefined, and to which purposes?
additional_information_teaching_methods: Students and instructor meet three times per week: Lectures, 1 x 2 hours per week. Seminar meetings, 2 x 2 hours per week.
method_of_assessment:
Assessment: Participation (20%), written task (50%), and final report (30%).
Students will only receive credits for the course if their grade for the written exam is 5.5 or higher. They are not allowed to compensate an exam grade that is below 5.5 with other partial grades.

course_paragraphs_json:
["Course Objective
At the end of Academic Skills 1 students will be able to:
Identify the characteristics of a well-defined research topic (e.g., focus, clarity, relevance).
Remember the fundamental rules of MLA citation style for in-text citations and Works Cited pages and explain why proper citation is necessary to avoid plagiarism and to maintain academic integrity.
Implement MLA citation style in writing, correctly formatting in-text citations and the Works Cited page.
Examine sample citations for accuracy and consistency with MLA style guidelines and assess the correctness of MLA formatting in a paper, ensuring all sources are properly cited and produce a properly formatted academic essay or research paper using MLA citation style throughout.
Discuss the standard structure of an academic essay (introduction, body paragraphs, conclusion) and explain how each part of the essay contributes to the overall argument and organization.", "Course Content
Set up as a mini-thesis trajectory, this module (together with Academic Skills 2) teaches students how to conduct and write about research in the field of literary studies. In Academic Skills 1, students are introduced to particular aspects of the research and writing process (topic delineation, finding sources, MLA citation style, structuring an essay, paragraph writing), and they submit short written assignments on each of these aspects.", "Additional Information Teaching Methods
Lecture: 1 x 1.5 hours per week.", "Method of Assessment
Short written assignments graded with a pass or fail.", "Entry Requirements
Students must have participated in Literary Theory (L_ELBALES101).", "Literature
To be announced.", "Additional Information Target Audience
This module is part of the Bachelor’s program Literature & Society: English.", "Additional Information
This module is part of the BRCS (Binding Recommendation on Continuation of Studies). This means you have to pass this course in order to get a positive BRCS. If you do not pass this course, you will receive a negative binding recommendation for your study programme. This means you won’t be able to re-enroll in this particular VU programme for the next three years.
Passing the English Language Test (L_ELT) is a prerequisite for being awarded credits for this module."]
course_objective:
At the end of Academic Skills 1 students will be able to:
Identify the characteristics of a well-defined research topic (e.g., focus, clarity, relevance).
Remember the fundamental rules of MLA citation style for in-text citations and Works Cited pages and explain why proper citation is necessary to avoid plagiarism and to maintain academic integrity.
Implement MLA citation style in writing, correctly formatting in-text citations and the Works Cited page.
Examine sample citations for accuracy and consistency with MLA style guidelines and assess the correctness of MLA formatting in a paper, ensuring all sources are properly cited and produce a properly formatted academic essay or research paper using MLA citation style throughout.
Discuss the standard structure of an academic essay (introduction, body paragraphs, conclusion) and explain how each part of the essay contributes to the overall argument and organization.

["Course Objective
After having successfully completed this course, students will be able to:
analyze a variety of literary texts using the skill of close reading;
provide an interpretation of a literary text, in class and in writing;
support their interpretation with evidence from the text.", "Course Content
This course will provide a grounding in critical analysis of genre in English Literature as well as provide a thorough introduction to the concept of close reading, which will be the basis of all courses in our program. course_content: This course will provide a grounding in critical analysis of genre in English Literature as well as provide a thorough introduction to the concept of close reading, which will be the basis of all courses in our program. This course examines the specificities and characteristics that are associated with various genres of literature -- poetry, fiction, and drama -- and guides the student through an understanding that genre and literary form helps shape the way we look at and analyze a text. Students will become familiar with the terminology used in literary analysis.

course_paragraphs_json:
["Course Objective
Creative writing offers students an opportunity to approach the object of their study from a new perspective: that of writing rather than reading. The objectives of this course are (1) to train students to read literary texts with an awareness of the writers’ poetic and narrative strategies, (2) to teach students to actively apply such literary techniques in their own writing of literary texts, (3) to introduce students to different theories on the relation between the writer and the meaning of the text. The course trains students' writing skills, aiming to foster a regular writing practice and a playfulness in approaching the act of writing that will sustain students' creative and academic writing practices throughout their curriculum. The seminar setup of a small writing community also trains students in drafting and revising their texts, as well as in providing constructive feedback on each other's work.", "Course Content
The course combines the reading of literary texts in English, with an eye on the authors' poetics, and the fostering of a practice of creative writing in which the studied techniques are used by students in their own literary texts.", "Additional Information Teaching Methods
2 seminar meetings of 2 hours each per week.", "Method of Assessment
Written assignments. An average grade of 5.5 is required to pass the course.", "Entry Requirements
Students must have participated in Literary Theory (L_ELBALES101).", "Literature
To be announced.", "Additional Information Target Audience
This module is part of the BA track Literature and Society: English. Participation by students from outside of this track is not possible.", "Additional Information
Attendance in the course seminars is compulsory. If you are absent at more than 20% of the seminars, you cannot pass the course. Exceptions may be made in grave personal circumstances. Make sure to inform both your lecturer and the student advisor in such cases.", "Custom Course Registration
There is a slightly different enrollment procedure for this module. The standard procedure of the Faculty of Humanities has students sign up for (i) the module, (ii) the form of tuition (lecture and/or preferred seminar group), and (iii) the exam. However, for this module the instructor will assign the students to the seminar groups. Therefore, students should sign up for (i) the module, but not for (ii) the seminar groups.", "Explanation Canvas
Students must check the course's Canvas page regularly for announcements."]
course_objective: Creative writing offers students an opportunity to approach the object of their study from a new perspective: that of writing rather than reading. The objectives of this course are (1) to train students to read literary texts with an awareness of the writers’ poetic and narrative strategies, (2) to teach students to actively apply such literary techniques in their own writing of literary texts, (3) to introduce students to different theories on the relation between the writer and the meaning of the text. The course trains students' writing skills, aiming to foster a regular writing practice and a playfulness in approaching the act of writing that will sustain students' creative and academic writing practices throughout their curriculum. The seminar setup of a small writing community also trains students in drafting and revising their texts, as well as in providing constructive feedback on each other's work.
course_content: The course combines the reading of literary texts in English, with an eye on the authors' poetics, and the fostering of a practice of creative writing in which the studied techniques are used by students in their own literary texts.

course_paragraphs_json:
["Course Objective
At the end of this course, students can:
Describe the role of globalization in different national and cultural contexts;
Explain the effect of globalization on identity, tourism, and nationalism, among other concepts;
Relate concepts used in class, such as “imagined communities” or “decentered identity” to current events and/or other texts and media;
Use cultural theory to analyze literary texts, both in class discussions and in writing;
Write a clear and coherent argument about one of the primary texts, and use theory to frame this argument.", "Course Content
What purpose does an attachment to “place” serve in a globalized world? How does our ability to travel and communicate across vast distances affect our own beliefs, perspectives, and identities? Who benefits from these experiences, and who is excluded? And what role does literature, specifically, play in all of these debates?
In this course, we cover these and other questions to figure out what it means to read and tell stories in a globalized world. Covering topics such as nationalism, identity, translation, race, and tourism, we explore both the limits and opportunities offered by literature in a transnational era.", "Additional Information Teaching Methods
Seminars, 2 x 2 hours per week.", "Method of Assessment
You will be assessed on the following aspects:
Participation (20%)
Writing portfolio (30%)
Final essay or similar assignment (50%)
The precise details will be announced on the course syllabus, which will be posted on Canvas.
Please note that you must score at least 5,5 on both the final assignment and participation to pass the course.", "Entry Requirements
Students must have participated in Literary Theory (L_ELBALES101).", "Literature
To be announced in the course syllabus, which will be posted to Canvas.", "Additional Information Target Audience
This module is part of the Bachelor’s track Literature & Society: English.", "Additional Information
The level of English in this course is high. Since class discussion is a central part of this course, attendance is compulsory and you are expected to participate. If you are absent at more than 20% of the seminars (i.e. 3 times per period), you cannot pass the course.", "Custom Course Registration
There is a slightly different enrollment procedure for this module. The standard procedure of the Faculty of Humanities has students sign up for (i) the module, and (ii) the form of tuition (lecture and/or preferred seminar group). However, for this module the instructor will assign the students to the seminar groups. Therefore, students should sign up for (i) the module, but not for (ii) the seminar groups."]
course_content:
What purpose does an attachment to “place” serve in a globalized world? How does our ability to travel and communicate across vast distances affect our own beliefs, perspectives, and identities? Who benefits from these experiences, and who is excluded? And what role does literature, specifically, play in all of these debates?
In this course, we cover these and other questions to figure out what it means to read and tell stories in a globalized world. Covering topics such as nationalism, identity, translation, race, and tourism, we explore both the limits and opportunities offered by literature in a transnational era.
additional_information_teaching_methods: Seminars, 2 x 2 hours per week.
method_of_assessment:
You will be assessed on the following aspects:
Participation (20%)
Writing portfolio (30%)
Final essay or similar assignment (50%)
The precise details will be announced on the course syllabus, which will be posted on Canvas.
Please note that you must score at least 5,5 on both the final assignment and participation to pass the course.

course_paragraphs_json:
["Course Objective
Students research and present on the possibilities and potential pitfalls of the Bachelor’s program Literature and Society, track English.", "Course Content
This course is built around an interview assignment. First-year students interview a third-year student of the Literature and Society program, track English, to learn about the program’s possibilities and potential pitfalls. They subsequently present on their findings in class to an audience of the program’s students (years one, two, and three) and teachers.", "Additional Information Teaching Methods
We meet once a week for two hours in period 4.
Attendance is mandatory.
Meetings are held on campus; no hybrid alternative is offered.
Devices with access to social media (this includes laptops) are not allowed in class. If an exception needs to be made for medical reasons, students must contact the academic advisor prior to the start of the course.
There will be no meetings in period 5.", "Method of Assessment
The course is assessed with either a pass (“voldaan”) or a fail (“niet voldaan”). For a pass (“voldaan”), students must satisfactorily execute the interview assignment, i.e., both conduct the interview and present in class. No alternative assignment will be offered.", "Additional Information Target Audience
This course is part of the Bachelor’s program Literature and Society, track English."]
course_objective: Students research and present on the possibilities and potential pitfalls of the Bachelor’s program Literature and Society, track English.
course_content: This course is built around an interview assignment. First-year students interview a third-year student of the Literature and Society program, track English, to learn about the program’s possibilities and potential pitfalls. They subsequently present on their findings in class to an audience of the program’s students (years one, two, and three) and teachers.
additional_information_teaching_methods:
We meet once a week for two hours in period 4.
Attendance is mandatory.
Meetings are held on campus; no hybrid alternative is offered.
Devices with access to social media (this includes laptops) are not allowed in class. If an exception needs to be made for medical reasons, students must contact the academic advisor prior to the start of the course.
There will be no meetings in period 5.
method_of_assessment: The course is assessed with either a pass (“voldaan”) or a fail (“niet voldaan”). For a pass (“voldaan”), students must satisfactorily execute the interview assignment, i.e., both conduct the interview and present in class. No alternative assignment will be offered.
additional_information_target_audience: This course is part of the Bachelor’s program Literature and Society, track English.

course_paragraphs_json:
["Course Objective
At the end of the course students will
understand and be able to apply key themes and theories that underpin the genre of literature we call Life Writing.
have learned new vocabulary and methodologies found in Life Writing Studies.
be able to use the course tools to reflect on selected texts.
have practiced writing academically and creatively on the writing of life narratives.", "Course Content
Life Writing is a rather new, interdisciplinary field covering a broad spectrum of writing categories such as (auto)biography, memoir, diary, travel writing, graphic novel, letter writing, poetry and online blog. In this introductory course we will examine the various debates that life writing scholars have been engaged in since its beginning ca. two decades ago. Which new perspectives on historical events or the formation of identity can writing ‘from life’ reveal? How can life writing possibly retrieve and recover perspectives and voices that would otherwise be lost? How are politics and privileges involved in this? How do social, cultural, and technological shifts determine what, how and why people remember, and how they express their life experiences? These and more questions will be central to the class discussions.", "Additional Information Teaching Methods
Two interactive seminar sessions per week:
plenary discussions on the assigned texts (both creative texts and scholarly texts); some plenary discussions may be led by students
in-class group work (creative work; academic reflections)
videoclip viewings and discussion
discussion of written assignments
In addition, there may be one excursion to the VU Botanical Garden, the Amsterdamse Bos, or the medicinal garden at Beatrixpark (all located in the southern part of Amsterdam).
6 credits = 20 hours per week:
4 hours: class sessions
16 hours: self-study (including writing two Canvas posts; preparations for the final exam)", "Method of Assessment

understand and be able to apply key themes and theories that underpin the genre of literature we call Life Writing.
have learned new vocabulary and methodologies found in Life Writing Studies.
be able to use the course tools to reflect on selected texts.
have practiced writing academically and creatively on the writing of life narratives.

In this introductory course we will examine the various debates that life writing scholars have been engaged in since its beginning ca. two decades ago. Which new perspectives on historical events or the formation of identity can writing ‘from life’ reveal? How do social, cultural, and technological shifts determine what, how and why people remember, and how they express their life experiences? These and more questions will be central to the class discussions.

course_paragraphs_json:
["Course Objective
Students become acquainted with the study of identity representation in Shakespeare’s plays and sonnets as well as their film adaptations. By the end of the course, students can:
Interpret the selected primary texts, i.e., Shakespeare’s plays and sonnets as well as their film adaptations.
Explain the concepts and arguments put forward in the selected secondary literature.
Do all this in clear and concise written English.", "Course Content
Central to this course is the question: How does the representation of identity (mainly in terms of gender, ethnicity, sexuality, and age) shift from Shakespeare’s plays and sonnets to their film adaptations?
Topics and plays/film adaptations discussed in previous years include:
Social change in Romeo and Juliet (William Shakespeare, 1595).
Gender in Shakespeare in Love (John Madden, 1998) and Shakespeare’s sonnets (1609).
Ethnicity in West Side Story (Robert Wise and Jerome Robbins, 1961).
Sexuality in Private Romeo (Alan Brown, 2011).
Age in Wellkåmm to Verona (Suzanne Osten, 2006).
Both plays and film adaptations are subject to change.", "Additional Information Teaching Methods
We meet once a week for four hours.
Attendance is mandatory.
Meetings are held on campus; no hybrid alternative is offered.
Each meeting consists of group discussions, exam instruction/practice, and a lecture portion.
Prior to each meeting, students complete a Canvas assignment.
Devices with access to social media (this includes laptops) are not allowed in class. If an exception needs to be made for medical reasons, students must contact the academic advisor prior to the start of the course.
There will be no meetings in period 6.", "Method of Assessment
Successful completion of the course is contingent on timely submission of all Canvas assignments and attendance at all meetings.
The full final grade for the course is based on a take-home exam consisting of short essay questions. The take-home exam will be held over three days in week 1 of period 6 (the week of 1 June 2026). English writing proficiency is a key aspect of the assessment.", "Entry Requirements
Students must have participated in the course Literary Theory (L_ELBALES101).", "Literature
To be announced in the course syllabus, which will be posted on Canvas well in advance of the start of the course.", "Additional Information Target Audience
This course is part of the Bachelor’s program Literature and Society, track English."]
course_objective:
Students become acquainted with the study of identity representation in Shakespeare’s plays and sonnets as well as their film adaptations. By the end of the course, students can:
Interpret the selected primary texts, i.e., Shakespeare’s plays and sonnets as well as their film adaptations.
Explain the concepts and arguments put forward in the selected secondary literature.
Do all this in clear and concise written English.
course_content:
Central to this course is the question: How does the representation of identity (mainly in terms of gender, ethnicity, sexuality, and age) shift from Shakespeare’s plays and sonnets to their film adaptations?
Topics and plays/film adaptations discussed in previous years include:
Social change in Romeo and Juliet (William Shakespeare, 1595).
Gender in Shakespeare in Love (John Madden, 1998) and Shakespeare’s sonnets (1609).
Ethnicity in West Side Story (Robert Wise and Jerome Robbins, 1961).
Sexuality in Private Romeo (Alan Brown, 2011).
Age in Wellkåmm to Verona (Suzanne Osten, 2006).
Both plays and film adaptations are subject to change.
additional_information_teaching_methods:
We meet once a week for four hours.
Attendance is mandatory.
Meetings are held on campus; no hybrid alternative is offered.
Each meeting consists of group discussions, exam instruction/practice, and a lecture portion.
Prior to each meeting, students complete a Canvas assignment.
Devices with access to social media (this includes laptops) are not allowed in class. If an exception needs to be made for medical reasons, students must contact the academic advisor prior to the start of the course.
There will be no meetings in period 6.
method_of_assessment:
Successful completion of the course is contingent on timely submission of all Canvas assignments and attendance at all meetings.
The full final grade for the course is based on a take-home exam consisting of short essay questions. The take-home exam will be held over three days in week 1 of period 6 (the week of 1 June 2026). English writing proficiency is a key aspect of the assessment.
literature: To be announced in the course syllabus, which will be posted on Canvas well in advance of the start of the course.
additional_information_target_audience: This course is part of the Bachelor’s program Literature and Society, track English.

course_paragraphs_json:
["Course Objective
Students
understand how travel writing is implicated in the processes of identity formation (both collective and individual) and intercultural exchange.
are able to apply theoretical notions (see below) to travel texts from ‘the long 19th century.’
can freely express their ideas in both written work and informal class discussions.
are able to engage in (and moderate) class discussions in a diversity-sensitive manner.
are (more) aware of socio-political issues that play a role in culturally diverse classroom settings.", "Course Content
This course introduces students to American and British literature written between the end of the 18th century and the beginning of the 20th century, the so-called 'long 19th century'. As it is impossible to cover all Anglo-American writing of this time-period in just seven weeks, we will focus on one specific genre: travel writing. This literary genre, which has been popular for centuries, has been much overlooked by academics and those constituting the British and American literary canons. New critical paradigms such as Transnationalism, Globalization, and Decolonization, however, necessitate a new and serious look at these texts.
We will close-read and analyze travel narratives written by authors who have produced some of the canonical texts from 'the long 19th century' (British and American), such as Charles Dickens, Robert Louis Stevenson and Margaret Fuller. In addition, we will close-read and analyze travel narratives written by authors who have been excluded from the literary canon, such as Mary Jane Seacole, Zilpha Elaw and Sarah Winnemucca Hopkins. We will discuss the major developments in the genre of (British and American) travel writing between the late 18th and early 20th century.
The course will address three themes:
Sensations of travel (weeks 1 - 2)
Taking risks (weeks 3 - 4)
The politics of travel (weeks 5 - 6)", "Additional Information Teaching Methods
The class sessions (4 hours per week) will consist of:
plenary and group discussions. All sessions will be interactive sessions. The lecturer will not summarize the assigned readings; you must come to class prepared, and be able to discuss the assigned texts with your fellow students and instructor. If you have not been able to prepare for class, you should either skip the session or notify the instructor before class (via mail).
joint close-readings of the assigned texts. The instructor will distribute hard copies for in-class close-readings. These are 'teacher’s copies' that you will have to return at the end of each session. The idea behind this is that group and class discussions may benefit from focused readings without other distractions.
in-class group work.
brief student-led discussions.
film viewings (excerpts).
optional excursion to the National Maritime Museum, Amsterdam (final week).", "Method of Assessment
30% Participation (20% active class participation; 10 % student-led discussion)
30% Canvas posts
40% Exam (digital)
The weighted average of the final grade must be 5.5 or higher.
Students will receive credits for the course if they have
submitted all six Canvas posts before the deadline stated in the course syllabus and on Canvas. Each student is allowed to have one late Canvas post submission—within 24 hours of the announced deadline. If you upload after those extra 24 hours you will not be eligible to do the regular exam but you can do the resit. If you have two or more late submissions you will not receive credits for the course.
scored a 5.5 or higher for the exam. The weighted average of the final grade must be 5.5 or higher.
attended 10 sessions out of 12. The attendance rule (80%) follows the Faculty rule for seminar sessions. It is also related to the set-up of the course, which is discussion-based. Students who miss more than 2 sessions out of 12 will not receive credits for the course. This means that if you are planning to go away for a week (and thus miss two sessions), you will have to attend the sessions during the other weeks.", "Entry Requirements
Students must have participated in Literary Theory or one of the courses from the American Studies minor package.", "Literature
Selected (excerpts of) 19th century travel writings
Selected (excerpts of) 19th century canonized texts
Scholarly articles on travel writing
The excerpts mentioned above, plus the articles, will be announced and uploaded on Canvas well before the course starts.
For in-class work the instructor will provide teacher's copies (hard-copies) of the assigned readings.

Time investment for reading the assigned texts:
The total number of hours you will need when taking this course: 20 hours per week (students enrolled in L&S take two courses per block -> 40 : 2 = 20 hours per week).
This number is roughly divided as follows:
4 hours: classroom hours
16 hours: self-study (including writing a weekly Canvas post; preparing for exam)
Please note:
The 16-hour calculation is an average number. Some weeks you will spent more hours on self-study than others.
The above calculation excludes the writing of your exam: 2 hours and 45 min.", "Additional Information Target Audience
Second-year students of the BA program Literature & Society: English; exchange students; participants in the Educational Minor (schoolvakminor) English Literature.", "Additional Information
Attendance required: 80%. This is according to Faculty rule. Students who miss more than 20% will not receive credits for the course. Exceptions will only be made in grave personal circumstances. Make sure to inform both your lecturer and the academic advisor in such cases.", "Custom Course Registration
Important note: There is a slightly different enrollment procedure for this module. The standard procedure of the Faculty of Humanities has students sign up for (I) the module, and (II) the form of tuition (lecture and/or preferred seminar group). However, for this module the instructor will assign the students to the seminar groups. Therefore, students should sign up for (I) the module, but NOT for (II) the seminar groups.
The group division will be published on the Canvas page 'Community Bachelor and Master English Literature'. Go to Homepage -> Modules -> Group Divisions in our Courses. The Group division is also announced in the online course syllabus. If you need to switch groups, please find someone from the other group who is prepared to swap with you. Then notify the course coordinator of this swap by e-mail, with the other student in the cc. If there is no one who is able to swap, please notify the instructor as soon as possible, but in any case before the start of the course.", "Explanation Canvas
Students should check Canvas regularly. Communication will occur via Canvas Announcement and Canvas Mail.

course_content:
This course introduces students to American and British literature written between the end of the 18th century and the beginning of the 20th century, the so-called 'long 19th century'. As it is impossible to cover all Anglo-American writing of this time-period in just seven weeks, we will focus on one specific genre: travel writing. This literary genre, which has been popular for centuries, has been much overlooked by academics and those constituting the British and American literary canons. New critical paradigms such as Transnationalism, Globalization, and Decolonization, however, necessitate a new and serious look at these texts.
We will close-read and analyze travel narratives written by authors who have produced some of the canonical texts from 'the long 19th century' (British and American), such as Charles Dickens, Robert Louis Stevenson and Margaret Fuller. In addition, we will close-read and analyze travel narratives written by authors who have been excluded from the literary canon, such as Mary Jane Seacole, Zilpha Elaw and Sarah Winnemucca Hopkins. We will discuss the major developments in the genre of (British and American) travel writing between the late 18th and early 20th century.
The course will address three themes:
Sensations of travel (weeks 1 - 2)
Taking risks (weeks 3 - 4)
The politics of travel (weeks 5 - 6)

course_paragraphs_json:
["Course Objective
By the end of “American Literature 1914-present,” students can
Describe and explain the relevance of some of the common themes in modern American literature, such as the American Dream or the tension between individual expression and communal goals;
Compare and contrast literary movements of the 20th century
Articulate why and how the idea of crisis and reinvention recurs throughout modern American literature
Explain how and why social, cultural, and political changes in American society gave rise to new forms of literature;
Write a clear and coherent argument about one of the course texts that is rooted in literary analysis, connects this analysis to contemporary society, and supported by secondary sources.", "Course Content
Over the course of the twentieth century, American society underwent some tremendous changes. These changes are reflected in its literature, which not only grapples with world wars, culture wars, and the arrival of more diverse voices on the literary scene, but also experimented with form and genre.
For some, these changes felt like crises; for others, they felt like liberation. How has American literature reflected and responded to these social, cultural, and political changes? And in what way(s) has it grappled with crises and dilemmas? What defines American literature in the 20th century, and is there still such a thing as “the” American canon? In this course, we will examine these questions as well as others.", "Additional Information Teaching Methods
Seminar meetings, 2 x 2 hours per week. Attendance is compulsory. Please note that you are not allowed to miss more than 3 classes, except in the case of grave personal circumstances. If such is the case, please notify both the professor and academic advisor as soon as possible.", "Method of Assessment
Students will be assessed based on in-class participation (30%) and a final essay (70%). The specifics of each assignment will be listed on Canvas and in the course syllabus.
In order to pass the course, students must receive a 5.5 or higher on both participation and the final assignment. There will be one resit possibility for the final assignment.", "Entry Requirements
Students must have participated in Literary Theory or one of the courses from the American Studies minor package.", "Literature
The Rabbit Hutch by Tess Gunty.
All other literature will be listed on the syllabus, which will be posted to Canvas well before the beginning of the course.", "Additional Information Target Audience
This module is part of the Bachelor’s program English Literature & Society, year 2. This course is also part of the American Studies minor package and of the "Schoolvakminor English Literature" for students in CIS (specialization English Language and Communication Studies and specialization Language and Mind).", "Additional Information
The level of English in this course is high, and you will be expected to participate in class discussions.", "Custom Course Registration
There is a slightly different enrollment procedure for this module. The standard procedure of the Faculty of Humanities has students sign up for (i) the module, and (ii) the form of tuition (lecture and/or preferred seminar group). However, for this module the instructor will assign the students to the seminar groups. Therefore, students should sign up for (i) the module, but not for (ii) the seminar groups.", "Recommended background knowledge
To take this course, students must have completed Literary Theory."]
course_content:
Over the course of the twentieth century, American society underwent some tremendous changes. These changes are reflected in its literature, which not only grapples with world wars, culture wars, and the arrival of more diverse voices on the literary scene, but also experimented with form and genre.
For some, these changes felt like crises; for others, they felt like liberation. How has American literature reflected and responded to these social, cultural, and political changes? And in what way(s) has it grappled with crises and dilemmas? What defines American literature in the 20th century, and is there still such a thing as “the” American canon? In this course, we will examine these questions as well as others.
additional_information_teaching_methods: Seminar meetings, 2 x 2 hours per week. Attendance is compulsory. Please note that you are not allowed to miss more than 3 classes, except in the case of grave personal circumstances. If such is the case, please notify both the professor and academic advisor as soon as possible.
method_of_assessment:
Students will be assessed based on in-class participation (30%) and a final essay (70%). The specifics of each assignment will be listed on Canvas and in the course syllabus.
In order to pass the course, students must receive a 5.5 or higher on both participation and the final assignment. There will be one resit possibility for the final assignment.
literature:
The Rabbit Hutch by Tess Gunty.
All other literature will be listed on the syllabus, which will be posted to Canvas well before the beginning of the course.
additional_information_target_audience: This module is part of the Bachelor’s program English Literature & Society, year 2. This course is also part of the American Studies minor package and of the "Schoolvakminor English Literature" for students in CIS (specialization English Language and Communication Studies and specialization Language and Mind).
recommended_background_knowledge: To take this course, students must have completed Literary Theory.

["Course Objective

structure that conveys an academic idea and its relevance and adheres to a time limit
prosodic features (intonation, voice, articulation, etc.)
body language (posture, eye-contact, etc.)
persuasive and conversational patterns (repetition, rhetorical questions, etc.)
2) Students engage in useful ways with their peers, offering feedback and working collaboratively
3) Students demonstrate awareness of their strengths and weaknesses with regards to the topics and skills addressed in the course.", "Course Content
You will be able to strategically apply structural elements, prosodic features and conversational patterns in such a way that they will help you convey a clear message. By the end of the course you are able to confidently give an oral presentation.", "Additional Information Teaching Methods
One seminar each week (appr. 3 to 4 hours each)", "Method of Assessment
A series of group and individual presentations (65%)
Peer review (25%)
Self-reflection paper (10%)
Students need a combined average of 5.5 in the class. Thus, it is possible to have lower than a 5.5 in one component, so long as the other components compensate.", "Additional Information Target Audience
Second-year students in Literature & Society: English. Native speakers of English take this course instead of Pronunciation.", "Additional Information

course_objective:
1) Students give presentations on academic topics. During these presentations they will show awareness and some mastery over the following elements:
structure that conveys an academic idea and its relevance and adheres to a time limit
prosodic features (intonation, voice, articulation, etc.)
body language (posture, eye-contact, etc.)
persuasive and conversational patterns (repetition, rhetorical questions, etc.)
2) Students engage in useful ways with their peers, offering feedback and working collaboratively
3) Students demonstrate awareness of their strengths and weaknesses with regards to the topics and skills addressed in the course.
course_content: You will be able to strategically apply structural elements, prosodic features and conversational patterns in such a way that they will help you convey a clear message. By the end of the course you are able to confidently give an oral presentation.

course_paragraphs_json:
["Course Objective
Knowledge: You will be able to describe the most common difficulties in English pronunciation. You will also be able to describe four major aspects of speech fluency in English and how they can be practised or improved.
Skills: You will be able to analyse different English pronunciations with respect to challenging English pronunciation features, including your own. You will also be able to analyse aspects of speech fluency in English and carry out exercises to improve your fluency.
Attitude: You are able to present a well-informed view of the nature of different English pronunciations and you appreciate diversity in English.
Communication: You are able to explain the potential impact of particular pronunciation features on the intelligibility and credibility of spoken English.
Learning: You are able to adapt features in your own English pronunciation according to the English pronunciation that you wish to develop. You are also able to help and support others regarding their English pronunciation.", "Course Content
We will set goals for the English pronunciation that you wish to develop both at a professional and at a personal level. We will analyse the most common difficulties in English pronunciation and the effects that these difficulties may (inadvertently) have on the intelligibility and credibility of spoken English. We will also take account of the role of pronunciation features in identity construction. You will conduct exercises, practise ear-training and be given tools that help you analyse English pronunciation features, as well as speech fluency. course_objective:
Knowledge: You will be able to describe the most common difficulties in English pronunciation. You will also be able to describe four major aspects of speech fluency in English and how they can be practised or improved.
Skills: You will be able to analyse different English pronunciations with respect to challenging English pronunciation features, including your own. You will also be able to analyse aspects of speech fluency in English and carry out exercises to improve your fluency.
Attitude: You are able to present a well-informed view of the nature of different English pronunciations and you appreciate diversity in English.
Communication: You are able to explain the potential impact of particular pronunciation features on the intelligibility and credibility of spoken English.
Learning: You are able to adapt features in your own English pronunciation according to the English pronunciation that you wish to develop. You are also able to help and support others regarding their English pronunciation.
course_content: We will set goals for the English pronunciation that you wish to develop both at a professional and at a personal level. We will analyse the most common difficulties in English pronunciation and the effects that these difficulties may (inadvertently) have on the intelligibility and credibility of spoken English. We will also take account of the role of pronunciation features in identity construction. You will conduct exercises, practise ear-training and be given tools that help you analyse English pronunciation features, as well as speech fluency. You will work with features in your own English pronunciation accordingly.
additional_information_teaching_methods: Interactive lectures (1,5 hours per week) and seminars (1,5 hours per week).
method_of_assessment:
Course work (in/complete) and Ttwo recordings of your own pronunciation. The second recording will be graded (100%) according to the progress that you have made in relation to your first recording. To successfully complete the course, students should score a grade of ≥5,5.
Course attendance and submission of all of the course work by the set deadlines is conditional for being awarded a grade for the second recording. For the seminars, 1 absence is allowed.
Course objectives 1-4 will be attained through working with the course work. These objectives will lead to course objective 5 that is assessed in the second recording.
literature:
Please note that the course does not use a text book; rather, the theoretical concepts will be explained in the lectures and be made available on PP-slides. It is assumed that you are familiar with these concepts before the seminars; they will not be repeated in the seminar. If absence of lectures leads to unfamiliarity with theoretical concepts, this may affect your grade.
The Pronunciation seminars are supported by online audio and video materials (https://english-pronunciation.weebly.com).
additional_information_target_audience: 2nd year students English Literature & Society and exchange students (non-native speakers of English). If native speakers wish to develop and/or become familiar with an English pronunciation other than their own, they are very welcome.

course_paragraphs_json:
["Course Objective
After successfully completing this course
you will have more insight into the language used in your discipline
you will be able to write a text in an appropriate academic style
You will also have greater insight into the strengths and weaknesses of your English writing skills
You will know how to further develop strengths and reduce weaknesses
You will be able to correct your own text and other people's texts for grammatical correctness and the specific linguistic features associated with coherence and cohesion
You will be able to take a critical look at your own English texts and those from your fellow students
You will develop the editing skills to improve it.", "Course Content
The main aim of this course is to further develop your writing skills in English, focusing on two aspects: your position as a writer in the academic world, i.e. as someone who is engaged in academic discourse; and editing, of your own and other people's texts. As a writer of academic texts, you need to be aware of appropriate structures at sentence level as well as at text level, of ways of using language to refer to other writers, and of ways of using academic language effectively. The emphasis in this course is on (a) gaining more insight into the language and style of your own academic discipline, (b) improving coherence, compactness and readability, and (c) developing your editing skills.", "Additional Information Teaching Methods
Seminars each week", "Method of Assessment
Two analyses of specific linguistic features (stance/engagement/quoting and referring) in texts from your own discipline (2x30%; course objectives 1, 3, 5); comparative analysis (40%; course objectives 2, 4, 6, 7). In order to pass the course, you need a 5.5 minimum for each component.", "Entry Requirements
Students must have passed Academic English CIW-L&S: Grammar (L_EABAALG103) and Academic English CIW-L&S: Writing (L_EABAALG104).", "Literature
Strongly recommended: Hannay, M. & J.L. Mackenzie (2009). Effective Writing in English. 2nd edition. Bussum: Coutinho. There will also be separate materials posted on Canvas.", "Additional Information Target Audience
Second year students of Literature & Society: English. The course is not open to students doing other degrees.", "Additional Information
Attendance is obligatory (80% minimum). If you miss more classes, you may still be allowed to finish the course if you submit an alternative assignment, but only if you’ve attended 70% of the classes."]
