course_name: Mechanics and Thermodynamics in the Cell
course_paragraphs_json:
["Course Objective
Below is provided a point-to-point list of the learning goals of the class that can be used as guidelines for the exams. At the end of this course, the students will:
know the basic concepts of physics (in particular mechanics, statistical physics and thermodynamics), physical chemistry and mathematics to describe quantitatively biology on the cellular and molecular level.
use these basic concepts to derive quantitative and predictive models that give a deeper insight into living systems.
implement and compare different models to analyze quantitatively experimental data obtained from state-of-the-art microscopy approaches and formulate new biological models.", "Course Content
Basic concepts in thermodynamics and statistical physics to describe biological process such as protein-ligand binding, and polymer conformation.
Basic concepts in mechanics to describe how biological beam responds to stress and strain. Combining statistical physics and mechanics to describe semi-flexible polymer such as DNA.
Basic concepts of hydrodynamics to understand how liquid flows in the channels, and how dimensions impact the nature of the flow and the motion of objects in liquid.
Derivation of the law of diffusion from a macroscopic and microscopic perspective and its application to describe small molecule motion, protein-ligand association kinetics, and molecular motors translocation.", "Additional Information Teaching Methods
Lectures (4h per week) & Tutorials (2h per week)", "Method of Assessment
Written exam (60% of final grade) + written tests (2x, 10% of final grade each) on part of the course contents + tutorial assessments (20% of final grade).", "Literature
Phillips, R., Kondev, J., and Theriot, J., Physical Biology of the Cell. 2nd Edition New York: Garland Science, 2012 (ISBN 0815344503). Chapter 1 to 13 (except 9 and 11). (1st edition is also fine)", "Additional Information Target Audience
3N, 3MNW mi-BB, 3WN, 3S", "Additional Information
This course is part of the Minors Biomedische Beeldvorming and Basics of Bioinformatics and Systems Biology.
Mathematics: Calculus & Mathematische Methoden (or comparable)
Physics: basics of mechanics & thermodynamics", "Recommended background knowledge
Mathematics: Calculus & Mathematische Methoden (or comparable)
Physics: basics of mechanics & thermodynamics"]
course_objective:
Below is provided a point-to-point list of the learning goals of the class that can be used as guidelines for the exams. At the end of this course, the students will:
know the basic concepts of physics (in particular mechanics, statistical physics and thermodynamics), physical chemistry and mathematics to describe quantitatively biology on the cellular and molecular level.
use these basic concepts to derive quantitative and predictive models that give a deeper insight into living systems.
implement and compare different models to analyze quantitatively experimental data obtained from state-of-the-art microscopy approaches and formulate new biological models.
course_content:
Basic concepts in thermodynamics and statistical physics to describe biological process such as protein-ligand binding, and polymer conformation.
Basic concepts in mechanics to describe how biological beam responds to stress and strain. Combining statistical physics and mechanics to describe semi-flexible polymer such as DNA.
Basic concepts of hydrodynamics to understand how liquid flows in the channels, and how dimensions impact the nature of the flow and the motion of objects in liquid.
Derivation of the law of diffusion from a macroscopic and microscopic perspective and its application to describe small molecule motion, protein-ligand association kinetics, and molecular motors translocation.
additional_information_teaching_methods: Lectures (4h per week) & Tutorials (2h per week)
method_of_assessment: Written exam (60% of final grade) + written tests (2x, 10% of final grade each) on part of the course contents + tutorial assessments (20% of final grade).
literature: Phillips, R., Kondev, J., and Theriot, J., Physical Biology of the Cell. 2nd Edition New York: Garland Science, 2012 (ISBN 0815344503). Chapter 1 to 13 (except 9 and 11). (1st edition is also fine)
additional_information_target_audience: 3N, 3MNW mi-BB, 3WN, 3S
recommended_background_knowledge:
Mathematics: Calculus & Mathematische Methoden (or comparable)
Physics: basics of mechanics & thermodynamics

teaching_method: Seminar, Study Group, Practical, Written partial exam, Lecture
course_paragraphs_json:
["Course Objective
Molecular biology studies the functioning of cells and organisms at the molecular level, and is applied in many fields. Metabolomics is a rapidly emerging field in molecular biology, and is one of the so-called omics technologies (genomics, proteomics, metabolomics). Metabolomics measures small molecules – the metabolites – in the cell or organism with the aim of determining the health status. But it can also determine the influence of the environment on health, for example through diet or exposure to toxic substances. Examples of metabolites are amino acids, ATP, sugars, neurotransmitters, lipids, etc.
Metabolomics aims to measure the complete set of metabolites (the metabolome) in organisms and is widely used in the medical, toxicological, and biological field. Metabolites function in a network and are transported to the desired destination via the streets as in a city. Metabolites have a major influence on the phenotype, behavior but also on the development of organisms.
This course aims to provide insight into the principles of metabolism in organisms, how metabolomics can be used in practice, how metabolites can be determined in organisms, and how the large amount of data can be handled, processed, visualized and statistically analysed (Big data analysis). The course has a practical approach and consists of lectures followed by a metabolomics experiment (practical). The practical is an important part of the course in which the student will conduct an experiment with zebrafish eggs and determine metabolites in the zebrafish embryos. Another important part is the processing of the large amount of data generated by using data visualization and statistical tools (introduction to processing of Big Data).
The following topics are covered:
What is metabolomics
What are metabolic networks
Basic principles and workflows for determining and processing metabolite data
Methods for the analysis of metabolites
Applications of metabolomics
Setting up a metabolomics experiment
Processing and analysis of large data (visualization, metabolite networks, statistical analysis)
The practical is an important part of the course to give the student a better insight into the various aspects of metabolomics. The student carries out a metabolomics experiment with zebrafish eggs, whereby the development from egg to embryo is monitored. The metabolites (lipids and neurotransmitters) are determined, and the data is processed, among other things by visualizing the data, creating metabolic networks and statistically processing the data.
The learning objectives at the end of the course are:
The student has knowledge and insight into the topics covered from metabolomics in cells and organism: The interactions between metabolites, proteins and genes.
The student has insight into the methods of measuring metabolites and the challenges of studying the metabolome.
The student gains experience with chemical analysis methods and the analysis of large data sets.
The student has practical experience in setting up and conducting a metabolomics experiment.
The student can process and analyse collected experimental data and can do the interpretation.", "Course Content
The course provides an introduction to metabolomics and will discuss and use the tools and techniques (practical) needed to conduct a metabolomics study. Various applications of metabolomics in biology, medical and toxicological fields will be discussed. A focus point in the course is the performance of a metabolomics experiment in which you will work with eggs of zebrafish. You follow the development from egg to embryo, determine lipids and neurotransmitters in the embryos, and process and analyse the large amount of data.
In this course a large number of fundamental and practical topics from metabolism and metabolomics are covered such as:
Metabolic Networks
Metabolomics (principles, workflows in metabolomics, applications)
Introduction to chemical analysis methods (chromatography, mass spectrometry)
Introduction to data processing (including visualization and Big data analysis)
In the practical, the students will apply the material from the lectures via a metabolomics experiment with zebrafish to understand the principles of metabolic networks, the use of analytical equipment to determine metabolites, and the processing and analysis of large data sets.", "Additional Information Teaching Methods
Lectures (18 hours)
Metabolomics practical (28 hours)
Data processing (20 hours)
Presentation (16 hours)
Practicum report (8 hours)
Self-study (78 hours)", "Method of Assessment
Examination (1/3 of the final grade, average grade at least 5.5).
Presentation (1/3 of the final grade, average grade at least 5.5).
Practicum report (1/3 of the final grade, average grade at least 5.5).
Attending practicals and working groups must be sufficient.", "Literature
Background literature, not needed, Metabolome analysis : an introduction. Silas G. Villas-Bôas, et al. 2007. ISBN-13: 978-0-471-74344-6. Chapters 1-5.", "Additional Information Target Audience
Part of the minor Biomolecular Sciences."]
course_objective:
Molecular biology studies the functioning of cells and organisms at the molecular level, and is applied in many fields. Metabolomics is a rapidly emerging field in molecular biology, and is one of the so-called omics technologies (genomics, proteomics, metabolomics). Metabolomics measures small molecules – the metabolites – in the cell or organism with the aim of determining the health status. But it can also determine the influence of the environment on health, for example through diet or exposure to toxic substances. Examples of metabolites are amino acids, ATP, sugars, neurotransmitters, lipids, etc.
Metabolomics aims to measure the complete set of metabolites (the metabolome) in organisms and is widely used in the medical, toxicological, and biological field. Metabolites function in a network and are transported to the desired destination via the streets as in a city. Metabolites have a major influence on the phenotype, behavior but also on the development of organisms.
This course aims to provide insight into the principles of metabolism in organisms, how metabolomics can be used in practice, how metabolites can be determined in organisms, and how the large amount of data can be handled, processed, visualized and statistically analysed (Big data analysis). The course has a practical approach and consists of lectures followed by a metabolomics experiment (practical). The practical is an important part of the course in which the student will conduct an experiment with zebrafish eggs and determine metabolites in the zebrafish embryos. Another important part is the processing of the large amount of data generated by using data visualization and statistical tools (introduction to processing of Big Data).
The following topics are covered:
What is metabolomics
What are metabolic networks
Basic principles and workflows for determining and processing metabolite data
Methods for the analysis of metabolites
Applications of metabolomics
Setting up a metabolomics experiment
Processing and analysis of large data (visualization, metabolite networks, statistical analysis)
The practical is an important part of the course to give the student a better insight into the various aspects of metabolomics. The student carries out a metabolomics experiment with zebrafish eggs, whereby the development from egg to embryo is monitored. The metabolites (lipids and neurotransmitters) are determined, and the data is processed, among other things by visualizing the data, creating metabolic networks and statistically processing the data.
The learning objectives at the end of the course are:
The student has knowledge and insight into the topics covered from metabolomics in cells and organism: The interactions between metabolites, proteins and genes.
The student has insight into the methods of measuring metabolites and the challenges of studying the metabolome.
The student gains experience with chemical analysis methods and the analysis of large data sets.
The student has practical experience in setting up and conducting a metabolomics experiment.
The student can process and analyse collected experimental data and can do the interpretation.
course_content:
The course provides an introduction to metabolomics and will discuss and use the tools and techniques (practical) needed to conduct a metabolomics study. Various applications of metabolomics in biology, medical and toxicological fields will be discussed. A focus point in the course is the performance of a metabolomics experiment in which you will work with eggs of zebrafish. You follow the development from egg to embryo, determine lipids and neurotransmitters in the embryos, and process and analyse the large amount of data.
In this course a large number of fundamental and practical topics from metabolism and metabolomics are covered such as:
Metabolic Networks
Metabolomics (principles, workflows in metabolomics, applications)
Introduction to chemical analysis methods (chromatography, mass spectrometry)
Introduction to data processing (including visualization and Big data analysis)
In the practical, the students will apply the material from the lectures via a metabolomics experiment with zebrafish to understand the principles of metabolic networks, the use of analytical equipment to determine metabolites, and the processing and analysis of large data sets.
additional_information_teaching_methods:
Lectures (18 hours)
Metabolomics practical (28 hours)
Data processing (20 hours)
Presentation (16 hours)
Practicum report (8 hours)
Self-study (78 hours)
method_of_assessment:
Examination (1/3 of the final grade, average grade at least 5.5).
Presentation (1/3 of the final grade, average grade at least 5.5).
Practicum report (1/3 of the final grade, average grade at least 5.5).
Attending practicals and working groups must be sufficient.
literature: Background literature, not needed, Metabolome analysis : an introduction. Silas G. Villas-Bôas, et al. 2007. ISBN-13: 978-0-471-74344-6. Chapters 1-5.
additional_information_target_audience: Part of the minor Biomolecular Sciences.

course_paragraphs_json:
["Course Objective
We expect that by the end of this course, students will be able to:
Design a realistic smart system with the potential to benefit human lives. The system acquires and processes audio, video or physiological signals and uses AI to make decisions that affect the environment accordingly. (Knowledge and understanding) (Applying knowledge and understanding) (Making judgments) (Lifelong learning skills)
Build a simplified version of this system, based on programmable microcontrollers. (Applying knowledge and understanding) (Making judgments) (Lifelong learning skills)
Work together in a team, collaboratively identifying not only the technical, but also the safety or ethical issues with their designs, and then sharing their challenges and discoveries through reports, presentations, and in-class demonstrations. (Lifelong learning skills) (Communication)", "Course Content
Pervasive (or ubiquitous) computing is a trend based on Mark Weiser's vision of computers available "always and everywhere", embedded in everyday life. This course is an introduction to pervasive computing systems that assist people in their daily lives. Think about a self-driving car, a speech-controlled wheelchair, an automatic insulin pump for diabetic patients, or a navigation system for visually impaired pedestrians.
These systems:
sense the context (time, user's location, blood sugar concentration, road scenery, etc),
recognize data patterns, reason and make intelligent decisions, and
act upon the environment, by controlling the wheels or the pump motor, suggesting the best route, or just notifying a caretaker.
The main components of such a system are sensors, controllers, and actuators. In this course, the students will learn different techniques to acquire signals from the environment, process these raw signals in order to infer context by using AI and in particular machine learning, and to write software agents for control. During the practical sessions, the students will get experience with these techniques and build their own microcontroller-based smart system. Programming is done in MATLAB and C++.", "Additional Information Teaching Methods
Lectures, mandatory practical sessions.", "Method of Assessment
Compulsory practical group assignments (LAB1 to LAB4), a group project (PROJ) and an individual digital exam in TestVision (EXAM). The LAB grade is calculated as: LAB = (LAB1 *0.1+ LAB2*0.3 + LAB3*0.3+LAB4*0.3). The project includes a report, a live presentation and a demo. The PROJ grade is calculated as: PROJ = (0.5*document) + (0.3*code) + (0.2*presentation). The practical grade is calculated as PRAC = (0.6*PROJ) + (0.4*LAB). The final grade is calculated as Final grade = (0.5*PRAC) + (0.5*EXAM). A pass requires both components to be >=5.5. It is possible to resit the exam, but not the practical.", "Entry Requirements
Knowledge of programming in C++ is recommended.", "Literature
Silvis-Cividjian, N. (2017), Pervasive Computing - Engineering Smart Systems, Springer International Publishing, ISBN 978-3-319-51654-7", "Explanation Canvas
All materials can be found in Canvas."]
course_objective:
We expect that by the end of this course, students will be able to:
Design a realistic smart system with the potential to benefit human lives. The system acquires and processes audio, video or physiological signals and uses AI to make decisions that affect the environment accordingly. (Knowledge and understanding) (Applying knowledge and understanding) (Making judgments) (Lifelong learning skills)
Build a simplified version of this system, based on programmable microcontrollers. (Applying knowledge and understanding) (Making judgments) (Lifelong learning skills)
Work together in a team, collaboratively identifying not only the technical, but also the safety or ethical issues with their designs, and then sharing their challenges and discoveries through reports, presentations, and in-class demonstrations. (Lifelong learning skills) (Communication)
course_content:
Pervasive (or ubiquitous) computing is a trend based on Mark Weiser's vision of computers available "always and everywhere", embedded in everyday life. This course is an introduction to pervasive computing systems that assist people in their daily lives. Think about a self-driving car, a speech-controlled wheelchair, an automatic insulin pump for diabetic patients, or a navigation system for visually impaired pedestrians.
These systems:
sense the context (time, user's location, blood sugar concentration, road scenery, etc),
recognize data patterns, reason and make intelligent decisions, and
act upon the environment, by controlling the wheels or the pump motor, suggesting the best route, or just notifying a caretaker.
The main components of such a system are sensors, controllers, and actuators. In this course, the students will learn different techniques to acquire signals from the environment, process these raw signals in order to infer context by using AI and in particular machine learning, and to write software agents for control. During the practical sessions, the students will get experience with these techniques and build their own microcontroller-based smart system. Programming is done in MATLAB and C++.
additional_information_teaching_methods: Lectures, mandatory practical sessions.
method_of_assessment: Compulsory practical group assignments (LAB1 to LAB4), a group project (PROJ) and an individual digital exam in TestVision (EXAM). The LAB grade is calculated as: LAB = (LAB1 *0.1+ LAB2*0.3 + LAB3*0.3+LAB4*0.3). The project includes a report, a live presentation and a demo. The PROJ grade is calculated as: PROJ = (0.5*document) + (0.3*code) + (0.2*presentation). The practical grade is calculated as PRAC = (0.6*PROJ) + (0.4*LAB). The final grade is calculated as Final grade = (0.5*PRAC) + (0.5*EXAM). A pass requires both components to be >=5.5. It is possible to resit the exam, but not the practical.
literature: Silvis-Cividjian, N. (2017), Pervasive Computing - Engineering Smart Systems, Springer International Publishing, ISBN 978-3-319-51654-7

course_paragraphs_json:
["Course Objective
This course builds a mathematical foundation for understanding machine learning, focusing on the interplay between vector calculus and regression. Designed for bachelor students in the minor Business Analytics and Data Science , it emphasizes mathematical principles that underpin modern algorithms.
The idea is to start from linear regression, move to nonparametric regression, with multilayer neural nets as an important example. Estimation and inference for such models is based on mathematical concepts from vector calculus, optimisation, probability and statistics. For each to these concepts, we refresh and extent knowledge obtained in introductory courses of the bachelor.", "Course Content
By the end of the course, students will be able to:
Understand and compute gradients, Jacobians, and Hessians of multivariate functions.
Apply the chain rule and directional derivatives in high-dimensional spaces.
Analyze scalar and vector fields relevant to optimization and learning.
Use gradient-based optimization techniques, including gradient descent, in the context of machine learning.
Understand regression models, their geometry and fitting by likelihood based inference, regularisation and the Bayesian approach
Mathematics behind fitting multilayer neural nets.", "Additional Information Teaching Methods
Lectures and exercise classes", "Method of Assessment
One exam and resit.", "Entry Requirements
basic knowledge of linear algebra, calculus, probability and statistics", "Literature
Main text: “Mathematics for Machine Learning” by Deisenroth, Faisal and Soon One
Supporting text: “Deep learning” by Bishop & Bishop", "Additional Information Target Audience
minor BADS"]
course_objective:
This course builds a mathematical foundation for understanding machine learning, focusing on the interplay between vector calculus and regression. Designed for bachelor students in the minor Business Analytics and Data Science , it emphasizes mathematical principles that underpin modern algorithms.
The idea is to start from linear regression, move to nonparametric regression, with multilayer neural nets as an important example. Estimation and inference for such models is based on mathematical concepts from vector calculus, optimisation, probability and statistics. For each to these concepts, we refresh and extent knowledge obtained in introductory courses of the bachelor.
course_content:
By the end of the course, students will be able to:
Understand and compute gradients, Jacobians, and Hessians of multivariate functions.
Apply the chain rule and directional derivatives in high-dimensional spaces.
Analyze scalar and vector fields relevant to optimization and learning.
Use gradient-based optimization techniques, including gradient descent, in the context of machine learning.
Understand regression models, their geometry and fitting by likelihood based inference, regularisation and the Bayesian approach
Mathematics behind fitting multilayer neural nets.
additional_information_teaching_methods: Lectures and exercise classes
method_of_assessment: One exam and resit.
literature:
Main text: “Mathematics for Machine Learning” by Deisenroth, Faisal and Soon One
Supporting text: “Deep learning” by Bishop & Bishop
additional_information_target_audience: minor BADS

course_paragraphs_json:
["Course Objective
At the end of this course students will be able to:
explain the different roles, possibilities, and limitations that computers currently bring for obtaining mathematical proofs.
give an informed opinion (concerning issues like rigorousness/completeness, necessity) of such computer uses in several different situations.
describe several different techniques and software tools available for computer assisted proofs and the different purposes they fulfill.
apply at least one such tool and corresponding techniques in a detailed technical case study.
work together in a small group on a project about computer assisted proofs.
present part of the project in both written and oral form.", "Course Content
This course introduces several different roles that computers can play in assisting mathematicians to obtain rigorous proofs for various mathematical statements. The relevant mathematical areas are manifold. They range from pure to applied, and include fields such as dynamical systems, number theory, graph theory, optimization, geometry, and cryptography. Examples include the proofs of the 4-colour theorem, the Kepler conjecture, the existence of a Lorenz attractor, etc.
Some topics (with partial overlap)
Representing mathematics in computers and performing computations (data structures, algorithms)
Reducing a mathematical problem to one solvable (in principle) by a computer, efficiency issues
Proof certificates, finding vs checking them
Interval arithmetic, rigorous numerics
Formal theorem proving (using Lean)", "Additional Information Teaching Methods
The first week is a mix of lectures and tutorial (computer) sessions, introducing the students to various theoretical and practical aspects of computer assisted proofs. At the end of this week, the students choose a project on which they work in groups of about 4 - 5 students for three weeks. Each group meets about 2 or 3 times per week with a teacher. In the final week, each project group is responsible for giving an oral presentation and handing in a written report about the project work.", "Method of Assessment
In the first week, students have to hand in several assignments, which all have to be marked "pass" in order to pass the course. The oral presentation counts for 30% towards the final grade and the written report counts for 70%.", "Literature
To be made available online on Canvas", "Additional Information Target Audience
Bachelor Mathematics, year 3", "Recommended background knowledge
Familiarity with programming (e.g. Python from X_400629) and software for computer algebra/scientific computing (e.g. Mathematica from XB_0006 and Matlab from X_401039). Basic mathematical background (as covered by the first two years of the bachelor programme) in linear algebra, discrete mathematics, and analysis."]
course_objective:
At the end of this course students will be able to:
explain the different roles, possibilities, and limitations that computers currently bring for obtaining mathematical proofs.
give an informed opinion (concerning issues like rigorousness/completeness, necessity) of such computer uses in several different situations.
describe several different techniques and software tools available for computer assisted proofs and the different purposes they fulfill.
apply at least one such tool and corresponding techniques in a detailed technical case study.
work together in a small group on a project about computer assisted proofs.
present part of the project in both written and oral form.
course_content:
This course introduces several different roles that computers can play in assisting mathematicians to obtain rigorous proofs for various mathematical statements. The relevant mathematical areas are manifold. They range from pure to applied, and include fields such as dynamical systems, number theory, graph theory, optimization, geometry, and cryptography. Examples include the proofs of the 4-colour theorem, the Kepler conjecture, the existence of a Lorenz attractor, etc.
Some topics (with partial overlap)
Representing mathematics in computers and performing computations (data structures, algorithms)
Reducing a mathematical problem to one solvable (in principle) by a computer, efficiency issues
Proof certificates, finding vs checking them
Interval arithmetic, rigorous numerics
Formal theorem proving (using Lean)
additional_information_teaching_methods: The first week is a mix of lectures and tutorial (computer) sessions, introducing the students to various theoretical and practical aspects of computer assisted proofs. At the end of this week, the students choose a project on which they work in groups of about 4 - 5 students for three weeks. Each group meets about 2 or 3 times per week with a teacher. In the final week, each project group is responsible for giving an oral presentation and handing in a written report about the project work.
method_of_assessment: In the first week, students have to hand in several assignments, which all have to be marked "pass" in order to pass the course. The oral presentation counts for 30% towards the final grade and the written report counts for 70%.
literature: To be made available online on Canvas
additional_information_target_audience: Bachelor Mathematics, year 3
recommended_background_knowledge: Familiarity with programming (e.g. Python from X_400629) and software for computer algebra/scientific computing (e.g. Mathematica from XB_0006 and Matlab from X_401039). Basic mathematical background (as covered by the first two years of the bachelor programme) in linear algebra, discrete mathematics, and analysis.

course_paragraphs_json:
["Course Objective
The student can independently study an advanced topic in number theory and write a clear and mathematically correct report on it.", "Course Content
The student independently studies a topic in number theory from the book "A Classical Introduction to Modern Number Theory" by Ireland and Rosen. Precise contents/chapters will be determined together with the teacher.
Example topics include:
higher reciprocity laws;
polynomial equations over finite fields and zeta functions;
(further) algebraic number theory.
The student has to write a report on the topic, including various examples, proofs, and worked out exercises.", "Additional Information Teaching Methods
This course is primarily conveyed through self-study.", "Method of Assessment
A written report, which will be judged on mathematical correctness and clarity of presentation.", "Literature
Kenneth Ireland and Michael Rosen, "A Classical Introduction to Modern Number Theory", 2nd edition, Graduate Texts in Mathematics volume 84, Springer New York.", "Additional Information Target Audience
In order to be admitted, the student must have handed in the first three homework exercises for Number Theory and scored on average at least 80% on these."]
course_objective: The student can independently study an advanced topic in number theory and write a clear and mathematically correct report on it.
additional_information_teaching_methods: This course is primarily conveyed through self-study.
method_of_assessment: A written report, which will be judged on mathematical correctness and clarity of presentation.
literature: Kenneth Ireland and Michael Rosen, "A Classical Introduction to Modern Number Theory", 2nd edition, Graduate Texts in Mathematics volume 84, Springer New York.
additional_information_target_audience: In order to be admitted, the student must have handed in the first three homework exercises for Number Theory and scored on average at least 80% on these.

course_paragraphs_json:
["Course Objective
After the completion of this extension, students can independently study an advanced topic in algebra and write a clear and mathematically correct report on it.", "Course Content
A module over a ring is what one gets when one replaces the field in the definition of a vector space over a field with a ring, i.e., it is an Abelian group under addition on which one has scalar multiplication (satisfying some properties) by the ring. The structure of a module can be very complicated, but in case the ring is a principal ideal domain and the module is generated by finitely many elements, there is a structure theorem (the Fundamental Theorem for Finitely Generated Modules over a Principal Ideal Domain) that states how one can describe all such modules, up to isomorphism, in a unique way. For example, if the ring is the set of integers, then a finitely generated module is precisely the same as a finitely generated Abelian group, and such a group is isomorphic (as a group) to the product of finitely many cyclic groups; this is part of the Fundamental Theorem for Finitely Generated Abelian Groups, which also states the conditions to choose such a product uniquely. If the ring is a polynomial ring in one variable with coefficients in a field then the corresponding statement for a finitely generated module over it can be used to give a standard form for a square matrix with coefficients in the field (its rational canonical form). Moreover, there exists an algorithm over the polynomial ring to compute this form for a given matrix.", "Additional Information Teaching Methods
The honours extension consists of studying (mostly independently) the relevant material of Chapters 10 and 12 in the book by Dummit and Foote, including working out various examples, proofs, and exercises, and writing a report on this.", "Method of Assessment
A written report, which will be judged on mathematical correctness and clarity of presentation.", "Literature
Parts of Chapters 10 and 12 of David S. Dummit, Richard M. Foote, "Abstract algebra", 3rd edition (2003), John Wiley and Sons. More
precise information is contained in the canvas pages for this extension.", "Additional Information Target Audience
In order to be admitted students must have passed Group theory (X_401105) and obtained a score of at least 80% for the first partial
exam of Ring and fields."]
course_objective: After the completion of this extension, students can independently study an advanced topic in algebra and write a clear and mathematically correct report on it.
course_content: A module over a ring is what one gets when one replaces the field in the definition of a vector space over a field with a ring, i.e., it is an Abelian group under addition on which one has scalar multiplication (satisfying some properties) by the ring. The structure of a module can be very complicated, but in case the ring is a principal ideal domain and the module is generated by finitely many elements, there is a structure theorem (the Fundamental Theorem for Finitely Generated Modules over a Principal Ideal Domain) that states how one can describe all such modules, up to isomorphism, in a unique way. For example, if the ring is the set of integers, then a finitely generated module is precisely the same as a finitely generated Abelian group, and such a group is isomorphic (as a group) to the product of finitely many cyclic groups; this is part of the Fundamental Theorem for Finitely Generated Abelian Groups, which also states the conditions to choose such a product uniquely. If the ring is a polynomial ring in one variable with coefficients in a field then the corresponding statement for a finitely generated module over it can be used to give a standard form for a square matrix with coefficients in the field (its rational canonical form). Moreover, there exists an algorithm over the polynomial ring to compute this form for a given matrix.
additional_information_teaching_methods: The honours extension consists of studying (mostly independently) the relevant material of Chapters 10 and 12 in the book by Dummit and Foote, including working out various examples, proofs, and exercises, and writing a report on this.
method_of_assessment: A written report, which will be judged on mathematical correctness and clarity of presentation.
literature:
Parts of Chapters 10 and 12 of David S. Dummit, Richard M. Foote, "Abstract algebra", 3rd edition (2003), John Wiley and Sons. More
precise information is contained in the canvas pages for this extension.
additional_information_target_audience:
In order to be admitted students must have passed Group theory (X_401105) and obtained a score of at least 80% for the first partial
exam of Ring and fields.

course_coordinator: prof. dr. R.C.A.M. van der Vorst
course_paragraphs_json:
["Course Objective
In this extension, the students learn how to apply the overarching ideas of functional analysis to some interesting examples such as polynomial approximation, numerical integration, the Riemann--Stieltjes integral. To this purpose they will read a chapter from a book and write a short report (approximately 5 pages) about it. The report must relate the content to the course Functional Analysis and must fill in the details omitted in the reference. Solved exercises and additional examples relevant to the subject can be included, as well.", "Course Content
The student can choose to write the report in one of the following three topics
Applications of the Hahn-Banach Theorem
Applications of the Uniform Boundedness Principle
Uniform approximation and Chebishev polynomials
The main source will be the book
Erwin Kreyszig, Introductory Functional Analysis with Applications, John Wiley and Sons, 1991. ISBN: 978-0-471-50459-7.
The student is welcome to research the literature to expand on this source.
Different students can choose the same topic and are also welcome to study it together. Anyway, the final report should be written independently by every student and handed in individually.", "Additional Information Teaching Methods
The extension starts in Period 5. The deadline to hand in the report is June 15. There will be three contact hours with the teacher: one at the beginning, one in the middle and one at the end of the project. The students can also use the normal contact hours (lectures, office hours) to ask further questions.", "Method of Assessment
The final grade is formed by the assessment of the final written report (approximately 5 pages). The report will be assessed following the criteria of the mathematics Bachelor report.", "Additional Information Target Audience
To participate in this module, the student must score at least 75% in the midterm of the functional analysis course."]
course_objective: In this extension, the students learn how to apply the overarching ideas of functional analysis to some interesting examples such as polynomial approximation, numerical integration, the Riemann--Stieltjes integral. To this purpose they will read a chapter from a book and write a short report (approximately 5 pages) about it. The report must relate the content to the course Functional Analysis and must fill in the details omitted in the reference. Solved exercises and additional examples relevant to the subject can be included, as well.
course_content:
The student can choose to write the report in one of the following three topics
Applications of the Hahn-Banach Theorem
Applications of the Uniform Boundedness Principle
Uniform approximation and Chebishev polynomials
The main source will be the book
Erwin Kreyszig, Introductory Functional Analysis with Applications, John Wiley and Sons, 1991. ISBN: 978-0-471-50459-7.
The student is welcome to research the literature to expand on this source.
Different students can choose the same topic and are also welcome to study it together. Anyway, the final report should be written independently by every student and handed in individually.
additional_information_teaching_methods: The extension starts in Period 5. The deadline to hand in the report is June 15. There will be three contact hours with the teacher: one at the beginning, one in the middle and one at the end of the project. The students can also use the normal contact hours (lectures, office hours) to ask further questions.
method_of_assessment: The final grade is formed by the assessment of the final written report (approximately 5 pages). The report will be assessed following the criteria of the mathematics Bachelor report.
additional_information_target_audience: To participate in this module, the student must score at least 75% in the midterm of the functional analysis course.

course_paragraphs_json:
["Course Objective
At the end of this course, students are expected to:
Be familiar with the concept of 'exhibition', historically, theoretically, and practically;
Be acquainted with international landmark exhibitions as well as exemplary Dutch institutions;
Demonstrate an understanding of the networked character of the art system and cultural sector, its various actors, objectives, processes of mediation, and its historic development, as related to diverse forms of exhibits (visual arts, architecture, heritage objects, design, film) and exhibitions (museum exhibition, festival, biennial, expo);
Have practiced their skills in synthesizing information from various sources (lectures, texts, group discussions), critically reviewing such information as well as actual exhibitions, and presenting your results orally and in writing, assisted by means of diverse media.", "Course Content
This course deals with:
The history and theory of exhibiting art and culture, from the curiosity cabinet to museums and world's fairs, and through to contemporary exhibitions, festivals, and biennials;
The function and purpose of exhibitions, which have long been a means of mediating culture and politics, educating society, establishing cultural and national canons and narratives, promoting artists and artifacts, and a vehicle for curatorial statements;
How artists have reflected upon the nature of exhibitions - not always in a positive sense (e.g. so-called "institutional critique").", "Additional Information Teaching Methods
This course is offered in English and assignments should be submitted in English.", "Method of Assessment
Method of Assessment:
Group presentation (30%): learning objectives 3,4
Written exam (70%): learning objectives 1,2,3, 4
End terms BA MKDA: 1,2,3,4,8", "Entry Requirements
See the Onderwijs- en Examenregeling (OER), c.q. Teaching and Exam Regulations (TER) for MKDA.", "Literature
A list of the mandatory class literature will be published on Canvas.", "Additional Information Target Audience
This course is compulsory for all BA MKDA students in their second year.", "Additional Information
For attendance rules, see Teaching and Examination Regulations. Students should be aware that regular attendance is necessary to pass the course.", "Recommended background knowledge
Basic knowledge in Art History and/or Cultural History."]
additional_information_teaching_methods: This course is offered in English and assignments should be submitted in English.
method_of_assessment:
Method of Assessment:
Group presentation (30%): learning objectives 3,4
Written exam (70%): learning objectives 1,2,3, 4
End terms BA MKDA: 1,2,3,4,8
literature: A list of the mandatory class literature will be published on Canvas.
additional_information_target_audience: This course is compulsory for all BA MKDA students in their second year.
recommended_background_knowledge: Basic knowledge in Art History and/or Cultural History.

course_paragraphs_json:
["Course Objective
At the end of this course, students are expected to:
Know and recognize historical urban patterns, developments in landscape architecture and their meanings.
Identify the relation between urban patterns, landscape architecture and architectural monuments.
Read plans of cities, landscape architecture and architectural monuments.
Make a visual and spatial analysis.
Compare historical developments in urbanism and landscape architecture and relate them to social, political and religious ideas.
Have written an essay (1700-2000 words) of academic structure and level, following a specific stylesheet (VU Department of Art and Culture).", "Course Content
In this course students learn the history and meaning (social, political, religious) of patterns and elements of urban development and planning, and of landscape architecture. The examples that will be discussed cover the entire world and go back until the first millennium BC.", "Additional Information Teaching Methods
Lectures and seminars. The lectures and seminars of this course are offered in English. Students following the Dutch (i.e. bilingual) track can submit all written assignments in either English or Dutch. Exceptions are multiple-choice tests, assignments with peer reviewers across language tracks, and group assignments (across language tracks)", "Method of Assessment
Tuition form, type and weight of assessment:
During the course the student completes three assignments.
Learning goals 1, 2 and 5: Assignment 2 (Multiple Choice Exam, 50%).
Learning goals 1, 3, 4, 5 and 6: Assignment (1 and) 3 (Essay, 50%).
Final Attainment Levels (eindtermen) BA MKDA: 1,2,3,5,8,9
Assignments cannot compensate one another: to pass the course both the exam and the essay need to have been graded min. 5.5.", "Entry Requirements
See the Onderwijs- en Examenregeling (OER), c.q. Teaching and Exam Regulations (TER) for MKDA.", "Literature
These books will provide the basis of the course reading list:
Barlow Rogers, Elizabeth, Landscape Design. A cultural and architectural history, Harry N. Abrams: New York 2001. (A selection of pages to be read will be announced in advance.)
Rutte, Reinout, The Making of the Netherlands, Thoth: Bussum 2023. (A selection of pages to be read will be announced in advance.)
Kostof, Spiro, The City Shaped. Urban Patterns and Meanings through History, Thames & Hudson: London 1991. (A selection of pages to be read will be announced in advance.)
Additional readings will be provided in the form of a digital reader by your tutor in advance", "Additional Information Target Audience
This course is compulsory for all BA MKDA students in their second year who chose Architecture as their specialisation.It is open to as an elective for 2nd or 3rd year MKDA students and students with backgrounds in history or planning. For exchange students approval of the coordinator is requested to be admitted to the course.

* HBO-studenten ontvangen voor dit vak meer begeleiding. Dit zal plaatsvinden via enkele aanvullende werkcolleges, die in overleg met de studenten ingepland zullen worden.*", "Additional Information
For attendance rules, see Teaching and Examination Regulations. Students should be aware that regular attendance is necessary to pass the course."]
course_objective:
At the end of this course, students are expected to:
Know and recognize historical urban patterns, developments in landscape architecture and their meanings.
Identify the relation between urban patterns, landscape architecture and architectural monuments.
Read plans of cities, landscape architecture and architectural monuments.
Make a visual and spatial analysis.
Compare historical developments in urbanism and landscape architecture and relate them to social, political and religious ideas.
Have written an essay (1700-2000 words) of academic structure and level, following a specific stylesheet (VU Department of Art and Culture).
course_content: In this course students learn the history and meaning (social, political, religious) of patterns and elements of urban development and planning, and of landscape architecture. The examples that will be discussed cover the entire world and go back until the first millennium BC.
additional_information_teaching_methods: Lectures and seminars. The lectures and seminars of this course are offered in English. Students following the Dutch (i.e. bilingual) track can submit all written assignments in either English or Dutch. Exceptions are multiple-choice tests, assignments with peer reviewers across language tracks, and group assignments (across language tracks)
method_of_assessment:
Tuition form, type and weight of assessment:
During the course the student completes three assignments.
Learning goals 1, 2 and 5: Assignment 2 (Multiple Choice Exam, 50%).
Learning goals 1, 3, 4, 5 and 6: Assignment (1 and) 3 (Essay, 50%).
Final Attainment Levels (eindtermen) BA MKDA: 1,2,3,5,8,9
Assignments cannot compensate one another: to pass the course both the exam and the essay need to have been graded min. 5.5.
literature:
These books will provide the basis of the course reading list:
Barlow Rogers, Elizabeth, Landscape Design. A cultural and architectural history, Harry N. Abrams: New York 2001. (A selection of pages to be read will be announced in advance.)
Rutte, Reinout, The Making of the Netherlands, Thoth: Bussum 2023. (A selection of pages to be read will be announced in advance.)
Kostof, Spiro, The City Shaped. Urban Patterns and Meanings through History, Thames & Hudson: London 1991. (A selection of pages to be read will be announced in advance.)
Additional readings will be provided in the form of a digital reader by your tutor in advance
additional_information_target_audience:
This course is compulsory for all BA MKDA students in their second year who chose Architecture as their specialisation.It is open to as an elective for 2nd or 3rd year MKDA students and students with backgrounds in history or planning. For exchange students approval of the coordinator is requested to be admitted to the course.

* HBO-studenten ontvangen voor dit vak meer begeleiding. Dit zal plaatsvinden via enkele aanvullende werkcolleges, die in overleg met de studenten ingepland zullen worden.*

course_name: Historiography of Media, Art, Design and Architecture
course_paragraphs_json:
["Course Objective
By the end of the course, we will:
Identify and define key historiographical theories concerning the disciplines of art, media, design, and architecture, in mutual coherence from the early modern period to the present day.
Describe and summarise different perspectives and research foci presented in relevant scientific publications.
Interpret and apply the discussed approaches to the analysis of artefacts belonging to the disciplines of art, media, design, and architecture.
Analyse objects through the historiographic approaches discussed in the course while distinguishing between their relevance and application.
Reflect on the contribution of the discussed historiographic approaches to the ways in which artefacts have been perceived over time", "Course Content
This course offers a comprehensive introduction to the historiography of media, art, design and architecture while tracing its development from the early modern period to the present day. In the lectures and working groups, we will examine a range of historiographic approaches that have shaped the ways in which these disciplines have been conceived and perceived while exploring their theoretical foundations and methodological practices. Focusing on the work of prominent historians, theorists, and authors, we will discuss how the historicization of media, art, design, and architecture was defined, as well as counter perspectives that critically analyse the existing discourse. We will engage in critical discussions, close readings, and analytical exercises to deepen our understanding of how the development of these disciplines has been studied and interpreted over time. By the end of the course, we will gain the tools to critically evaluate existing historiographic frameworks and grasp the development of ongoing", "Additional Information Teaching Methods
Lectures; active participation in discussions during tutorials; independent preparation of texts that deal with key authors and historiographic perspectives; group assignments and presentations in class.", "Method of Assessment
Final Assignment (60%): learning objectives 1,2,3,4,5
Interim Assignments (40%): learning objectives 1,2,3,4,5
End terms BA MKDA: 1,3,4,5,6,8", "Entry Requirements
See the Onderwijs- en Examenregeling (OER), c.q. Teaching and Exam Regulations (TER) for MKDA.", "Literature
A list of mandatory class literature will be published on Canvas and/or the study manual.", "Additional Information Target Audience
This course is compulsory for all BA MKDA students in their second year.
It is not open as an elective.", "Additional Information
For attendance rules, see Teaching and Examination Regulations. Students should be aware that regular attendance is necessary to pass the course."]

Describe and summarise different perspectives and research foci presented in relevant scientific publications.
Interpret and apply the discussed approaches to the analysis of artefacts belonging to the disciplines of art, media, design, and architecture.
Analyse objects through the historiographic approaches discussed in the course while distinguishing between their relevance and application.
Reflect on the contribution of the discussed historiographic approaches to the ways in which artefacts have been perceived over time

course_paragraphs_json:
["Course Objective
At the end of this course, students are expected to:
Be able to recognize and date key buildings and structures from the history of (Western) architecture;
Be able to relate these objects to historical developments in architectural style, to their social-cultural and historical contexts and to current debates;
Name typical features of architectural styles, buildings and ideas about the built environment throughout time, and be able to compare and relate these to each other;
Be able to analyse buildings with use of plans, maps, elevations, sections and other sources.
Is able to demonstrate their newly-developed skills in a written assessment.", "Course Content
In this course students focus on the history of (Western) architecture by studying the most important buildings, historical backgrounds, theoretical principles and key texts. Students learn to critically reflect on the architectural historical canon, including both Dutch and international examples. Moreover, students learn to further develop their visual analysis skills by analysing buildings and building types.

*Students of the Reinwardt Academie follow this course in period 2 in English. In this case, the course will be coordinated by a VU teacher in collaboration with a teacher from the Reinwardt Academie.*", "Additional Information Teaching Methods
Lectures, seminars, and excursion(s). The lectures and seminars of this course are offered in English only. Students following the Dutch (i.e. bilingual) track can submit all written assignments in either English or Dutch. Exceptions are multiple-choice tests, assignments with peer reviewers across language tracks, and group assignments (across language tracks).", "Method of Assessment
Written exam/final assignment (80%): learning objectives 1,2,3,4,5
Interim Assignments (20%): learning objectives 1,2,3,4
End terms BA MKDA: 1,2,3,5,8,9", "Entry Requirements
See the Onderwijs- en Examenregeling (OER), c.q. Teaching and Exam Regulations (TER) for MKDA.", "Literature
A list of mandatory class literature will be published on Canvas and/or the Study Manual.", "Additional Information Target Audience
This course is compulsory for all second-year BA MKDA students with the specialisation Architecture. It is open as an elective to other MKDA students.", "Additional Information
For attendance rules, see Teaching and Examination Regulations. Students should be aware that regular attendance is necessary to pass the course.", "Custom Course Registration
For exchange students approval of the coordinator is requested to be admitted to the course."]
course_content:
In this course students focus on the history of (Western) architecture by studying the most important buildings, historical backgrounds, theoretical principles and key texts. Students learn to critically reflect on the architectural historical canon, including both Dutch and international examples. Moreover, students learn to further develop their visual analysis skills by analysing buildings and building types.

*Students of the Reinwardt Academie follow this course in period 2 in English. In this case, the course will be coordinated by a VU teacher in collaboration with a teacher from the Reinwardt Academie.*
additional_information_teaching_methods: Lectures, seminars, and excursion(s). The lectures and seminars of this course are offered in English only. Students following the Dutch (i.e. bilingual) track can submit all written assignments in either English or Dutch. Exceptions are multiple-choice tests, assignments with peer reviewers across language tracks, and group assignments (across language tracks).
method_of_assessment:
Written exam/final assignment (80%): learning objectives 1,2,3,4,5
Interim Assignments (20%): learning objectives 1,2,3,4
End terms BA MKDA: 1,2,3,5,8,9

course_paragraphs_json:
["Course Objective
At the end of this course, students are expected to:
Have knowledge of and insight into theories and notions of (public) space and media, interfaces and (spatial) environments;
Be able to reflect on how to critically analyze mediated environments regarding their history/genealogy and/or their social and political implications;
Be able to conduct case study-based research on the relation of processes of mediation and (interconnected) environments, using appropriate academic literature, methods and terminologies, and situating their research in the history of visual and material culture;
Have improved their ability to communicate the outcome of their research to peers in a clear and well-structured manner by means of an audiovisual assignment.", "Course Content
The course deals with mediated (spatial) environments as well as environmental mediation from both a historical and a conceptual point of view. It starts from the assumption that the spaces we inhabit, populate, navigate, that we are confronted with or immersed in, are built and formatted, increasingly technologically wired, interactive and interconnected.
In other words: environments become interfaces for mediating experience, privileging certain uses and, at the same time, constraining others. Urban environments have become ‘smart’; the Internet of Things connects physical and virtual space in new and highly efficient ways; environmentalist intervention as well as political agendas and policies depend on monitoring ecology and generating data of current conditions (of e.g. air and water pollution or climate change) by means of sensor-media; large technological infrastructures intertwine place and space, the local and the global. Yet, it would be short-sighted to only conceive of these processes as recent developments enabled by 'digitality'. The course therefore draws a historical line to situate current conditions of mediating environments in the context of a shared genealogy of architectural design and technological processes of mediation.
The aim of the course is to develop a critical understanding of traditional and contemporary places, spaces, buildings, infrastructures and technologies. Their respective functionality, (an)aesthetics, social and political implications will be discussed historically and theoretically and analyzed by students in the form of case studies.", "Additional Information Teaching Methods
Lectures, seminars, and an excursion. The lectures and seminars of this course are offered in English only. Students following the Dutch (i.e. bilingual) track can submit all written assignments in either English or Dutch. Exceptions are multiple-choice tests, assignments with peer reviewers across language tracks, and group assignments (across language tracks).", "Method of Assessment
This course comprises a presentation (30%), and an audio assignment (70%) as described in the course manual.
Connection between learning objectives and assessment:
Learning objective 1: presentation and audio assignment
Learning objective 2: presentation and audio assignment
Learning objective 3: presentation, practical component and the audio assignment
Learning objective 4: presentation, practical component and the audio assignment.
End terms BA MKDA: 1,2,4,5,6,8", "Entry Requirements
See the Onderwijs- en Examenregeling (OER), c.q. Teaching and Exam Regulations (TER) for MKDA.", "Literature
A list of mandatory (and recommended) class literature will be published on Canvas and/or the Study Manual.", "Additional Information Target Audience
This course is compulsory for all BA MKDA students in their second year who chose Architecture or Media as their specialisation. It is open as an elective for 2nd or 3rd year MKDA students.", "Additional Information
All seminars and assignment are based on group work. Therefore students should be aware that specific requirements for attendance apply (as detailed in the course manual)."]
course_content:
The course deals with mediated (spatial) environments as well as environmental mediation from both a historical and a conceptual point of view. It starts from the assumption that the spaces we inhabit, populate, navigate, that we are confronted with or immersed in, are built and formatted, increasingly technologically wired, interactive and interconnected.
In other words: environments become interfaces for mediating experience, privileging certain uses and, at the same time, constraining others. Urban environments have become ‘smart’; the Internet of Things connects physical and virtual space in new and highly efficient ways; environmentalist intervention as well as political agendas and policies depend on monitoring ecology and generating data of current conditions (of e.g. air and water pollution or climate change) by means of sensor-media; large technological infrastructures intertwine place and space, the local and the global. Yet, it would be short-sighted to only conceive of these processes as recent developments enabled by 'digitality'. The course therefore draws a historical line to situate current conditions of mediating environments in the context of a shared genealogy of architectural design and technological processes of mediation.
The aim of the course is to develop a critical understanding of traditional and contemporary places, spaces, buildings, infrastructures and technologies. Their respective functionality, (an)aesthetics, social and political implications will be discussed historically and theoretically and analyzed by students in the form of case studies.
additional_information_teaching_methods: Lectures, seminars, and an excursion. The lectures and seminars of this course are offered in English only. Students following the Dutch (i.e. bilingual) track can submit all written assignments in either English or Dutch. Exceptions are multiple-choice tests, assignments with peer reviewers across language tracks, and group assignments (across language tracks).
method_of_assessment:
This course comprises a presentation (30%), and an audio assignment (70%) as described in the course manual.
Connection between learning objectives and assessment:
Learning objective 1: presentation and audio assignment
Learning objective 2: presentation and audio assignment
Learning objective 3: presentation, practical component and the audio assignment
Learning objective 4: presentation, practical component and the audio assignment.
End terms BA MKDA: 1,2,4,5,6,8

course_paragraphs_json:
["Course Objective
At the end of this course, students are expected to:
have acquired the skills to engage with and analyse various original objects, works of art, architecture, design and media, all in situ and in the contexts of the city or museum collections, in a non-dutch environment of international importance for (the history of) visual and material culture;
be able to lead a discussion on a historical/theoretical idea in relation to an art work in situ;
be able to communicate to peers, orally and on an academic level about the visual analysis of monuments and artefacts and to have gained and shared knowledge and insight about the goals of the excursion, including learning experiences;", "Course Content
In many respects, today's European culture is heir to that of the Italian Renaissance, especially in the fields of architecture and the visual arts. Florence is the Renaissance city par excellence: much of what was achieved in Florence in a relatively short time (14th-16th centuries) and with an exceptionally high quality can still be admired
in situ. This unique situation is also due to the different ways in which later generations have dealt with the material witnesses to the history of this city. In this course, students learn about the most important moments and objects from that history through individual research, and reflect on the scientific culture in which those objects were studied and described.", "Additional Information Teaching Methods
Preparatory lectures and full-time excursion demanding self-study and active participation.", "Method of Assessment
On-site presentation and discussion (70 + 30 %, incl. preparation, literature study)
Oral Presentation (70%): learning objectives 1, 3
Discussion (30%): learning objectives 1, 2, 3
End terms BA MKDA: 1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6, 8, 9, 12", "Entry Requirements
See the Onderwijs- en Examenregeling (OER), c.q. Teaching and Exam Regulations (TER) for MKDA", "Literature
A list of mandatory class literature will be published on Canvas and/or the Study Manual.", "Additional Information Target Audience
This course is compulsory for all BA MKDA students in their second year who chose Art or Architecture as their specialization. It is not open as an elective.", "Additional Information
In period 4 students are invited for a kick-off meeting regarding the practical side of the course. In period 5 students follow several lectures and read the compulsory literature. Based on this literature and the literature they collected by the student, they prepare a presentation to be held in Florence. The excursion takes place in period 6. Presence at all meetings and during the entire excursion is mandatory.
Regarding finances: participants to this excursion are strongly advised to reserve their own financial contribution in time. Savings are recommended. The VU will not cover all the costs, but will offer a small compensation (on condition of the course being completed successfully). Costs to be incurred include travel expenses (both international and local), some accommodation costs, museum entrance fees, meals, etc. The accompanying teachers will do their best to arrange free or reduced entrance fees. The course coordinator will inform the participants in good time whether transport and accommodation will be jointly arranged or not."]
course_content:
In many respects, today's European culture is heir to that of the Italian Renaissance, especially in the fields of architecture and the visual arts. Florence is the Renaissance city par excellence: much of what was achieved in Florence in a relatively short time (14th-16th centuries) and with an exceptionally high quality can still be admired
in situ. This unique situation is also due to the different ways in which later generations have dealt with the material witnesses to the history of this city. In this course, students learn about the most important moments and objects from that history through individual research, and reflect on the scientific culture in which those objects were studied and described.
additional_information_teaching_methods: Preparatory lectures and full-time excursion demanding self-study and active participation.
method_of_assessment:
On-site presentation and discussion (70 + 30 %, incl. preparation, literature study)
Oral Presentation (70%): learning objectives 1, 3
Discussion (30%): learning objectives 1, 2, 3
End terms BA MKDA: 1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6, 8, 9, 12

additional_information_target_audience: This course is compulsory for all BA MKDA students in their second year who chose Art or Architecture as their specialization. It is not open as an elective.

course_paragraphs_json:
["Course Objective
After completing this course successfully, students should be able to:
Problematise the complex and culturally layered phenomenon of dwelling in relation to architecture, (interior) design, ritual, usage and custom;
Understand the culture of ‘home’ and dwelling within design historical developments and in socio-cultural and historical contexts;
Read plans, elevations, sections, etc.;
Reproduce in writing the most important interpretations and definitions within the study of domestic space and related concepts, by studying and synthesizing relevant academic literature.
The student acquires knowledge and insight into dwelling as a cultural practice and domestic space as a layered form of cultural expression and how these are defined in various contexts. The student develops the ability to understand domestic space as an ambiguous concept and studies to be able to place it within a historical as well as a contemporary setting.", "Course Content
The way in which people live is prominent in today’s popular media. From celebrities profiles in Architectural Digest, to Instagram: ‘home’, domestic spaces, interior design and dwelling are instantly connected to the development of a particular lifestyle and to personal choices made within current trends. However, dwelling is much more than the popular media would suggest. It is a complex and layered activity of cultural significance. This course highlights several components of the study of the domestic, dwelling and housing culture, such as domestic and interior architecture, concepts of ‘home’ and dwelling, policy versus practices, the impact of changing technology and the concept of domesticity. Throughout the course these components are connected to the choices that designers and residents make or made in the designing, building and furnishing of their homes. The course pays attention to both contemporary and historical interpretations of domestic space.", "Additional Information Teaching Methods
Lectures, seminars, practical and excursions.
The lectures of this course are offered in English. Students following the Dutch (i.e. bilingual) track can submit all written assignments in either English or Dutch. Exceptions are multiple-choice tests, assignments with peer reviewers across language tracks, and group assignments (across language tracks)", "Method of Assessment
Matching of assignments and course objective:
All learning goals will be addressed during the weekly meetings and will be practiced through practical and written exercises and a smaller midterm assignment (assignment 2), a substantial paper (assignment 1), and a written exam (assignment 3) at the end. Assignments 1 and 3 will be graded, assignment 2 only has to be completed (graded as pass/fail). In order for the final grade to be published, assignment 2 has to be graded with a ‘pass.' Assignments 1 and 3 each count for 50% of the final grade, but to pass the course they both need to have been graded with at least 5.5 (sufficient).
Connection between learning objectives and assessment:
Learning objective 1 and 4: assignment 1 (paper)
Learning objective 1-4: assignment 2
Learning objectives 2 and 3: assignment 3 (exam)
Final Attainment Levels (eindtermen) BA MKDA: 1,2,4,5,8,9", "Entry Requirements
See the Onderwijs- en Examenregeling (OER), c.q. Teaching and Exam Regulations (TER) for MKDA.", "Literature
Digital reader provided by your tutor in advance.", "Additional Information Target Audience
This course is compulsory for all BA MKDA students in their second year who chose Design or Architecture as their specialization. It is open as an elective to other MKDA students.", "Additional Information
For attendance rules, see Teaching and Examination Regulations. Students should be aware that regular attendance is necessary to pass the course.", "Custom Course Registration
For exchange approval of the coordinator is requested to be admitted to the course."]
course_content: The way in which people live is prominent in today’s popular media. From celebrities profiles in Architectural Digest, to Instagram: ‘home’, domestic spaces, interior design and dwelling are instantly connected to the development of a particular lifestyle and to personal choices made within current trends. However, dwelling is much more than the popular media would suggest. It is a complex and layered activity of cultural significance. This course highlights several components of the study of the domestic, dwelling and housing culture, such as domestic and interior architecture, concepts of ‘home’ and dwelling, policy versus practices, the impact of changing technology and the concept of domesticity. Throughout the course these components are connected to the choices that designers and residents make or made in the designing, building and furnishing of their homes. The course pays attention to both contemporary and historical interpretations of domestic space.

Assignments 1 and 3 will be graded, assignment 2 only has to be completed (graded as pass/fail). In order for the final grade to be published, assignment 2 has to be graded with a ‘pass.' Assignments 1 and 3 each count for 50% of the final grade, but to pass the course they both need to have been graded with at least 5.5 (sufficient).
Connection between learning objectives and assessment:
