course_paragraphs_json:
["Course Objective
At the end of this course the student will be able to
describe the basic theory of (infinite dimensional) complete normed vector spaces, so-called Banach spaces;
apply fundamental results about bounded linear operators between Banach spaces with special emphasis on bounded linear functionals: the Hahn-Banach extension theorem, the uniform boundedness principle, the open mapping and the closed graph theorem, compactness of the unit ball with respect to weak topologies;
use orthonormal bases and projection operators as additional tools to investigate the class of Hilbert spaces, namely those Banach spaces whose norm is induced by an inner product;
generalize the notion of eigenvalues and eigenvectors for bounded linear operators on (infinite dimensional) Hilbert spaces and describe more precisely the spectral properties of compact self-adjoint operators;
recognize the above abstract framework at play in several interesting concrete examples: L^p spaces, approximation of functions by polynomials and Fourier series, solutions of integral and differential equations;
solve exercises both on the general theory of Banach and Hilbert spaces and on its application to concrete function spaces.", "Course Content
Infinite dimensional vector spaces such as the space of continuous or differentiable functions on an interval play a crucial role in analysis and in the theory of integral and differential equations. These spaces are often endowed with a natural norm (think of the uniform norm of a continuous function) which enables us to speak of convergence of sequences and leads us to the crucial question about how to best approximate a function by simpler ones like polynomials or Fourier sums.
In this course we will put the above problems in the general framework of Banach spaces and develop a general theory for these spaces and their linear transformations. A special place in our discussion will be occupied by Hilbert spaces, where the norm comes from an inner product. In this situation, we will have additional tools to approximate elements and to study the eigenvalues and eigenvectors of linear operators.
More specifically, we will learn the following topics during the course:
Basic theory and examples of Banach spaces
The space of bounded linear operators between Banach spaces
The dual of a Banach space
Weak and weak* topology
Reflexive and separable Banach spaces
Basic theory of Hilbert spaces: orthonormal basis and projection operators
Bounded linear operators on Hilbert spaces: adjoint and spectrum
The spectral theorem for self-adjoint compact operators
Applications to the solution of integral and differential equations", "Additional Information Teaching Methods
Lectures and exercise sessions, both 2 hours per week.", "Method of Assessment
For this course there are 4 hand-in assignments (total: 10%, the best two count), a midterm exam (40%) and a final exam (50%). There will also be a resit examination: the final grade will then be determined either (i) by the grade of the resit (90%) and the grade of the hand-in assignments (10%), or (ii) by the grade of the resit alone (100%), depending which of the two options results in a higher grade.", "Literature
Literature:
Lecture notes
A concise introduction to the subject is
Bryan P. Rynne and Martin A. Youngson, ‘Linear Functional Analysis’, 2nd Edition, Springer, 2008, ISBN 978-1-84800-005-6.
A book with many motivating examples covering all material from scratch in detail is
Erwin Kreyszig, ‘Introductory Functional Analysis with Applications’, John Wiley & Sons, 1978, ISBN 0-471-50731-8.", "Additional Information Target Audience
Bachelor Mathematics Year 3
Extra curricular course for VU students
Secondary subject for non-VU students", "Additional Information
This course offers an honours extension. Please have a look at the dedicated page for more information.", "Recommended background knowledge
The following background is mandatory:
Single variable calculus, Linear algebra, and Mathematical analysis.
It is recommended to revise the basic notions of metric spaces before the course starts. These can be found in the first chapter of either the two books in the literature, or in the lecture notes.
Examples from measure theory will not be studied in this course. Therefore, no prior knowledge of measure theory is needed."]
course_content:
Infinite dimensional vector spaces such as the space of continuous or differentiable functions on an interval play a crucial role in analysis and in the theory of integral and differential equations. These spaces are often endowed with a natural norm (think of the uniform norm of a continuous function) which enables us to speak of convergence of sequences and leads us to the crucial question about how to best approximate a function by simpler ones like polynomials or Fourier sums.
In this course we will put the above problems in the general framework of Banach spaces and develop a general theory for these spaces and their linear transformations. A special place in our discussion will be occupied by Hilbert spaces, where the norm comes from an inner product. In this situation, we will have additional tools to approximate elements and to study the eigenvalues and eigenvectors of linear operators.
More specifically, we will learn the following topics during the course:
Basic theory and examples of Banach spaces
The space of bounded linear operators between Banach spaces
The dual of a Banach space
Weak and weak* topology
Reflexive and separable Banach spaces
Basic theory of Hilbert spaces: orthonormal basis and projection operators
Bounded linear operators on Hilbert spaces: adjoint and spectrum
The spectral theorem for self-adjoint compact operators
Applications to the solution of integral and differential equations
additional_information_teaching_methods: Lectures and exercise sessions, both 2 hours per week.
method_of_assessment: For this course there are 4 hand-in assignments (total: 10%, the best two count), a midterm exam (40%) and a final exam (50%). There will also be a resit examination: the final grade will then be determined either (i) by the grade of the resit (90%) and the grade of the hand-in assignments (10%), or (ii) by the grade of the resit alone (100%), depending which of the two options results in a higher grade.
literature:
Literature:
Lecture notes
A concise introduction to the subject is
Bryan P. Rynne and Martin A. Youngson, ‘Linear Functional Analysis’, 2nd Edition, Springer, 2008, ISBN 978-1-84800-005-6.
A book with many motivating examples covering all material from scratch in detail is
Erwin Kreyszig, ‘Introductory Functional Analysis with Applications’, John Wiley & Sons, 1978, ISBN 0-471-50731-8.
additional_information_target_audience:
Bachelor Mathematics Year 3
Extra curricular course for VU students
Secondary subject for non-VU students
recommended_background_knowledge:
The following background is mandatory:
Single variable calculus, Linear algebra, and Mathematical analysis.
It is recommended to revise the basic notions of metric spaces before the course starts. These can be found in the first chapter of either the two books in the literature, or in the lecture notes.
Examples from measure theory will not be studied in this course. Therefore, no prior knowledge of measure theory is needed.

course_paragraphs_json:
["Course Objective
The student knows the following concepts, and can solve problems about and with them in explicit situations:
basic field theory (various properties of field extensions, including finiteness, algebraicity, separability and normality);
splitting fields, finite Galois extensions and the Galois correspondence;
cyclotomic extensions of the rationals;
finite fields, as well as their finite extensions together with their Galois groups.
The student knows the criteria for constructibility by straightedge and compass, and solvability by radicals, and can apply those in explicit situations.", "Course Content
The Babylonians could solve quadratic equations, but it took until the 16th century before (complicated) formulae were discovered for solving cubic and quartic equations. These use iterated expressions of (varying) nth roots ('radicals'). The quest for similar formulae for higher degree equations culminated in a negative answer by Ruffini and Abel in the early 19th century. Galois soon after refined the result, providing a precise criterion in terms of the symmetries of the zeroes of the equation that determines if those zeroes can be expressed using radicals.
After a more general study of field extensions and their properties, we discuss the fundamental theorem of Galois theory, one of the most beautiful results in algebra. We also discuss its consequences for the (in)solvability of the quintic by radicals, and for the (in)constructibility of regular n-gons by means of straightedge and compass.
We treat the following topics.
Properties of field extensions (including finite, algebraic, simple, separable, inseparable, normal or finite Galois extensions); examples.
Compositum of fields; algebraic closure (including a different proof of the fundamental theorem of algebra, which asserts that the complex numbers are algebraically closed).
Cyclotomic fields.
The fundamental theorem of Galois theory, which gives a 1-1 correspondence between the subgroups of the Galois group of a finite Galois extension, and the intermediate fields.
Finite fields, as well as their finite extensions together with their Galois groups.
Constructibility using straightedge and compass; (in)solvability of polynomials using radicals.", "Additional Information Teaching Methods
Lectures (14x2 hours) and tutorials (14x2 hours)", "Method of Assessment
Two partial exams (or a resit), and marked assignments. The assignments in total count for 5% towards the grade, the average of the scores for the two partial exams (or the score of the resit) counts for 95%. Alternatively, the result of the exam or the resit counts for 100% of the grade if this results in a higher score.
All of this is subject to the requirement that the average of the scores for the two partial exams (or the score of the resit) is at least 55%, otherwise the grade is capped at 5.", "Literature
David S. Dummit, Richard M. Foote, "Abstract algebra", 3rd edition (2003), John Wiley and Sons.", "Additional Information Target Audience
Bachelor Mathematics Year 2", "Recommended background knowledge
The VU courses Linear Algebra, Group Theory, as well as Rings and fields. The results treated in these three courses are used extensively throughout this course."]
course_content:
The Babylonians could solve quadratic equations, but it took until the 16th century before (complicated) formulae were discovered for solving cubic and quartic equations. These use iterated expressions of (varying) nth roots ('radicals'). The quest for similar formulae for higher degree equations culminated in a negative answer by Ruffini and Abel in the early 19th century. Galois soon after refined the result, providing a precise criterion in terms of the symmetries of the zeroes of the equation that determines if those zeroes can be expressed using radicals.
After a more general study of field extensions and their properties, we discuss the fundamental theorem of Galois theory, one of the most beautiful results in algebra. We also discuss its consequences for the (in)solvability of the quintic by radicals, and for the (in)constructibility of regular n-gons by means of straightedge and compass.
We treat the following topics.
Properties of field extensions (including finite, algebraic, simple, separable, inseparable, normal or finite Galois extensions); examples.
Compositum of fields; algebraic closure (including a different proof of the fundamental theorem of algebra, which asserts that the complex numbers are algebraically closed).
Cyclotomic fields.
The fundamental theorem of Galois theory, which gives a 1-1 correspondence between the subgroups of the Galois group of a finite Galois extension, and the intermediate fields.
Finite fields, as well as their finite extensions together with their Galois groups.
Constructibility using straightedge and compass; (in)solvability of polynomials using radicals.
additional_information_teaching_methods: Lectures (14x2 hours) and tutorials (14x2 hours)
method_of_assessment:
Two partial exams (or a resit), and marked assignments. The assignments in total count for 5% towards the grade, the average of the scores for the two partial exams (or the score of the resit) counts for 95%. Alternatively, the result of the exam or the resit counts for 100% of the grade if this results in a higher score.
All of this is subject to the requirement that the average of the scores for the two partial exams (or the score of the resit) is at least 55%, otherwise the grade is capped at 5.
literature: David S. Dummit, Richard M. Foote, "Abstract algebra", 3rd edition (2003), John Wiley and Sons.
additional_information_target_audience: Bachelor Mathematics Year 2
recommended_background_knowledge: The VU courses Linear Algebra, Group Theory, as well as Rings and fields. The results treated in these three courses are used extensively throughout this course.

course_paragraphs_json:
["Course Objective
Students become familiar with more advanced topics in mathematical statistics. While the focus is on theorems and proofs, students will also learn to apply some advanced statistical methods.
The student is familiar with commonly used multiple testing and sequential testing methods, can describe and compare them, as well as apply them and interpret results, and can prove properties of these methods, especially properties related to error control probabilities.
The student is familiar with basic concepts in decision theory, including several general as well as Bayesian notions of optimality for decisions, and can derive decision rules fitting given optimality criteria, can prove that a specific (set of) rule(s) is optimal in a given sense, and can prove basic theorems in decision theory.
The student is familiar with linear and logistic regression, can apply these methods and prove basic properties.
The student is familiar with the potential outcomes framework for causal inference as well as the standard assumptions and estimands of the framework, can apply several causal inference methods based on the propensity score as well as evaluate whether it is appropriate to use a particular method and evaluate the results, and prove basic properties of (variations on) the methods.
The student is familiar with several statistical computing methods, can argue which method to use for a specific setting and tailor it to that setting, can interpret results from application of the methods and prove basic properties of (variations on) the methods.", "Course Content
The topics in this course are treated from mathematical perspective and with a focus on theorems and proofs. Concepts will be illustrated with examples from biostatistics and students will learn to apply several advanced statistical methods. The main topics are (between parentheses a potential selection of subtopics):
Multiple testing (family-wise error rate, false discovery rate, methods to control multiplicity including the Bonferroni correction, Hochberg step-up method, Benjamini-Hochberg method)
Sequential testing (Wald's sequential probability ratio test, control charts)
Decision theory (decision rules, loss function, risk function, admissibility, minimax rules, Bayes risk, posterior expected loss)
Linear and logistic regression, especially in context of the other topics of the course
Causal inference (potential outcomes framework, assumptions, the propensity score, inverse probability of treatment weighting, propensity score matching, doubly robust methods)
Statistical computing (Monte Carlo integration, rejection sampling, importance sampling, Metropolis-Hastings)
While the focus is on theory, some of the exercises will use R. Students are not expected to write R code, but will learn how to interpret the R output for selected methods.", "Additional Information Teaching Methods
Lectures (2 hours per week) and exercises (2 hours of tutorial per week). Attendance is not mandatory.", "Method of Assessment
Written midterm and written final exam. The final exam covers all topics of the course. The final grade is the weighted average of the midterm (30%) and the final exam grade (70%), unless the final exam grade is higher. In the latter case, the final grade will be equal to the final exam grade.
The resit is a single written exam covering all topics of the course.", "Literature
Mandatory: Abramovich and Ritov (2023). Statistical theory: a concise introduction. 2nd edition. CRC Press.
In addition, a selection of mandatory articles and lecture notes/slides made available by the lecturer via Canvas (free of charge).", "Explanation Canvas
Students should register for the Canvas page of the course. Canvas will be used to share the complete syllabus, weekly materials and exercises, and practical information, including practical information regarding the exams.", "Recommended background knowledge
Mathematical Statistics (year 2 bachelor Mathematics); calculus, linear algebra, probability theory. If you haven't taken Mathematical Statistics, please contact the lecturer to discuss whether your background knowledge aligns well with this course."]
course_objective:
Students become familiar with more advanced topics in mathematical statistics. While the focus is on theorems and proofs, students will also learn to apply some advanced statistical methods.
The student is familiar with commonly used multiple testing and sequential testing methods, can describe and compare them, as well as apply them and interpret results, and can prove properties of these methods, especially properties related to error control probabilities.
The student is familiar with basic concepts in decision theory, including several general as well as Bayesian notions of optimality for decisions, and can derive decision rules fitting given optimality criteria, can prove that a specific (set of) rule(s) is optimal in a given sense, and can prove basic theorems in decision theory.
The student is familiar with linear and logistic regression, can apply these methods and prove basic properties.
The student is familiar with the potential outcomes framework for causal inference as well as the standard assumptions and estimands of the framework, can apply several causal inference methods based on the propensity score as well as evaluate whether it is appropriate to use a particular method and evaluate the results, and prove basic properties of (variations on) the methods.
The student is familiar with several statistical computing methods, can argue which method to use for a specific setting and tailor it to that setting, can interpret results from application of the methods and prove basic properties of (variations on) the methods.
course_content:
The topics in this course are treated from mathematical perspective and with a focus on theorems and proofs. Concepts will be illustrated with examples from biostatistics and students will learn to apply several advanced statistical methods. The main topics are (between parentheses a potential selection of subtopics):
Multiple testing (family-wise error rate, false discovery rate, methods to control multiplicity including the Bonferroni correction, Hochberg step-up method, Benjamini-Hochberg method)
Sequential testing (Wald's sequential probability ratio test, control charts)
Decision theory (decision rules, loss function, risk function, admissibility, minimax rules, Bayes risk, posterior expected loss)
Linear and logistic regression, especially in context of the other topics of the course
Causal inference (potential outcomes framework, assumptions, the propensity score, inverse probability of treatment weighting, propensity score matching, doubly robust methods)
Statistical computing (Monte Carlo integration, rejection sampling, importance sampling, Metropolis-Hastings)
While the focus is on theory, some of the exercises will use R. Students are not expected to write R code, but will learn how to interpret the R output for selected methods.
additional_information_teaching_methods: Lectures (2 hours per week) and exercises (2 hours of tutorial per week). Attendance is not mandatory.
method_of_assessment:
Written midterm and written final exam. The final exam covers all topics of the course. The final grade is the weighted average of the midterm (30%) and the final exam grade (70%), unless the final exam grade is higher. In the latter case, the final grade will be equal to the final exam grade.
The resit is a single written exam covering all topics of the course.

course_paragraphs_json:
["Course Objective
After this course the student...
will know basic PDE's from classical physics and the properties of their solutions.
will be able to derive solution formulas and methods, as well as describe the qualitative properties of solutions.
will be able to apply Fourier series and transforms to solve linear PDE's explicitly.", "Course Content
An overwhelming number of physical phenomena can be described by partial differential equations (PDEs). This course discusses the basic examples and methods for their solution. For first order equations as well as for the wave equation we discuss the method of characteristics, and hence the solution of such PDEs by methods from the theory of ordinary differential equations. For second order equations, in particular for the heat, wave and planar Laplace equation, we discuss the method of separation of variables. This ties in with the remarkable result of Fourier that almost any periodic function can be represented as a sum of sines and cosines, called its Fourier series; an analogous representation for non-periodic functions is provided by the Fourier transform. We discuss both, together with some theoretical background. Green's functions and fundamental solutions will be discussed for the standard examples: heat, wave and Poisson equation. While we will mostly be concerned with linear equations and the general solution techniques that exist for them, we will also make short excursions into the fascinating world of nonlinear PDEs and discuss unique solution methods for the nonlinear transport equation and its generalizations, Burger's equation and Korteweg-de Vries equation.
Topics:
Classical examples
First order equations and characteristics
d'Alembert's solution for the wave equation
Separation of variables for second order equations
Fourier series and Fourier transform
The Dirac delta-function and generalized functions
Green's functions and fundamental solutions for heat and wave equation
Travelling wave solutions for Burger's equation and Korteweg-de Vries equation
The Dirichlet principle", "Additional Information Teaching Methods
Lectures and exercise classes (both 2 hours per week)", "Method of Assessment
Two written exams with weights 50%+50%, make up your final grade. The grades for these exams are cancelled in case the student takes the resit exam, which counts for 100%.", "Literature
Peter J. Olver, "Introduction to Partial Differential Equations", Springer-Verlag, New York, 2014. ISBN 978-3-319-02099-0.", "Additional Information Target Audience
Bachelor Mathematics Year 3", "Recommended background knowledge
Linear algebra, Calculus, Analysis are necessary background"]

will be able to derive solution formulas and methods, as well as describe the qualitative properties of solutions.
will be able to apply Fourier series and transforms to solve linear PDE's explicitly.
course_content:
An overwhelming number of physical phenomena can be described by partial differential equations (PDEs). This course discusses the basic examples and methods for their solution. For first order equations as well as for the wave equation we discuss the method of characteristics, and hence the solution of such PDEs by methods from the theory of ordinary differential equations. For second order equations, in particular for the heat, wave and planar Laplace equation, we discuss the method of separation of variables. This ties in with the remarkable result of Fourier that almost any periodic function can be represented as a sum of sines and cosines, called its Fourier series; an analogous representation for non-periodic functions is provided by the Fourier transform. We discuss both, together with some theoretical background. Green's functions and fundamental solutions will be discussed for the standard examples: heat, wave and Poisson equation. While we will mostly be concerned with linear equations and the general solution techniques that exist for them, we will also make short excursions into the fascinating world of nonlinear PDEs and discuss unique solution methods for the nonlinear transport equation and its generalizations, Burger's equation and Korteweg-de Vries equation.
Topics:
Classical examples
First order equations and characteristics
d'Alembert's solution for the wave equation
Separation of variables for second order equations
Fourier series and Fourier transform
The Dirac delta-function and generalized functions
Green's functions and fundamental solutions for heat and wave equation
Travelling wave solutions for Burger's equation and Korteweg-de Vries equation
The Dirichlet principle
additional_information_teaching_methods: Lectures and exercise classes (both 2 hours per week)
method_of_assessment: Two written exams with weights 50%+50%, make up your final grade. The grades for these exams are cancelled in case the student takes the resit exam, which counts for 100%.
literature: Peter J. Olver, "Introduction to Partial Differential Equations", Springer-Verlag, New York, 2014. ISBN 978-3-319-02099-0.
additional_information_target_audience: Bachelor Mathematics Year 3
recommended_background_knowledge: Linear algebra, Calculus, Analysis are necessary background

additional_information_teaching_methods: Lectures and tutorials (2+2 hours per week)
method_of_assessment:
For this course there are hand in exercises, a midterm examination and a final exam which together determine the final grade.
The weight of the components towards the final grade will be announced on canvas. There will also be a resit
examination for which the hand-in exercises do not contribute to the grade.
literature: Will be announced on canvas.
additional_information_target_audience: Bachelor Mathematics, year 2
recommended_background_knowledge:
The VU-course Basic concepts of mathematics, in order to be able to write a proof in a clear and structured manner;
the VU-course Mathematical Analysis, for experience with convergence and continuity in the real numbers
the VU-course Fourier Analysis, for understanding convergence and continuity in abstract metric spaces.
the VU-course Group theory (groups, homomorphisms, first isomorphism theorem): this is relevant in particular for the second part of the course, but also for examples and applications throughout the course.

course_paragraphs_json:
["Course Objective
After completing this course, the student can:
Describe the structural organization of cells and the chemical principles that underlie molecular interactions and enzymatic activity.
Explain the roles of proteins, nucleic acids, lipids, and carbohydrates in cellular function.
Explain membrane structure and transport, including the mechanisms of passive and active transport across membranes.
Classify the major metabolic pathways and explain how cells convert nutrients into usable energy.
Describe mechanisms of intracellular transport, signal transduction, cytoskeletal dynamics, and cell cycle regulation.", "Course Content
This course explores the fundamental biochemical principles of cellular life, beginning with the structure, types, and evolution of cells, the chemical foundations of cellular molecules, and the kinetics and catalysis that drive cellular reactions. It then examines the structure and function of macromolecules—proteins, nucleic acids, lipids, and carbohydrates—and how they enable cellular function. The course also covers membrane architecture and the mechanisms of molecular transport across membranes. Energy metabolism is addressed through the breakdown of nutrients and the synthesis of ATP. Intracellular transport of proteins and other cargo between organelles is explored. Cellular communication via signal transduction and its modulation by chemical substances and signaling molecules is also discussed. Finally, the role of the cytoskeleton in cell structure, function, and intracellular movement is examined, and the course concludes with a discussion of cell division and apoptosis.", "Additional Information Teaching Methods
The course will be taught in a flipping-the-classroom style. Chapters from the book Essential Cell Biology should be studied as preparation for the tutorial sessions, where the most important concepts will be discussed using questions and problems. There will be ample opportunities to check for study progress, e.g. using canvas quizzes.", "Method of Assessment
There will be two exams, one at the end of period 4 (March), and the other at the end of period 5 (May). See the course syllabus for more information on assessment (e.g. format, weighting, compensation).", "Literature
Alberts, B. e.a., Essential Cell Biology 5th ed, 2019; or 6th ed, 2024", "Additional Information Target Audience
Second-year Mathematics students in the biomedical sciences track. The course is also open to exchange students and minor students. Be aware of the assumed background knowledge.", "Recommended background knowledge
Genetics (AB_1135) or a similar course. For this course, it is assumed that students have an understanding of the main concepts taught in this course (see also chapters 5-8 of Essential Cell Biology)."]
course_objective:
After completing this course, the student can:
Describe the structural organization of cells and the chemical principles that underlie molecular interactions and enzymatic activity.
Explain the roles of proteins, nucleic acids, lipids, and carbohydrates in cellular function.
Explain membrane structure and transport, including the mechanisms of passive and active transport across membranes.
Classify the major metabolic pathways and explain how cells convert nutrients into usable energy.
Describe mechanisms of intracellular transport, signal transduction, cytoskeletal dynamics, and cell cycle regulation.
course_content: This course explores the fundamental biochemical principles of cellular life, beginning with the structure, types, and evolution of cells, the chemical foundations of cellular molecules, and the kinetics and catalysis that drive cellular reactions. It then examines the structure and function of macromolecules—proteins, nucleic acids, lipids, and carbohydrates—and how they enable cellular function. The course also covers membrane architecture and the mechanisms of molecular transport across membranes. Energy metabolism is addressed through the breakdown of nutrients and the synthesis of ATP. Intracellular transport of proteins and other cargo between organelles is explored. Cellular communication via signal transduction and its modulation by chemical substances and signaling molecules is also discussed. Finally, the role of the cytoskeleton in cell structure, function, and intracellular movement is examined, and the course concludes with a discussion of cell division and apoptosis.
additional_information_teaching_methods: The course will be taught in a flipping-the-classroom style. Chapters from the book Essential Cell Biology should be studied as preparation for the tutorial sessions, where the most important concepts will be discussed using questions and problems. There will be ample opportunities to check for study progress, e.g. using canvas quizzes.
method_of_assessment: There will be two exams, one at the end of period 4 (March), and the other at the end of period 5 (May). See the course syllabus for more information on assessment (e.g. format, weighting, compensation).
literature: Alberts, B. e.a., Essential Cell Biology 5th ed, 2019; or 6th ed, 2024
additional_information_target_audience: Second-year Mathematics students in the biomedical sciences track. The course is also open to exchange students and minor students. Be aware of the assumed background knowledge.
recommended_background_knowledge: Genetics (AB_1135) or a similar course. For this course, it is assumed that students have an understanding of the main concepts taught in this course (see also chapters 5-8 of Essential Cell Biology).

course_paragraphs_json:
["Course Objective
At the end of the bachelor project, the student is able to
plan and execute a mathematical or applied mathematical literature research or research project, with guidance from a supervisor;
independently acquire new mathematical knowledge and skills, collect mathematical information, through literature study, the internet, or independent mathematical research;
write a clear scientific report on the conducted research;
present his/her research results in a clear and informative manner to fellow students and lecturers.", "Course Content
The bachelor project is an aptitude test, in which the student shows (s)he is able to apply the knowledge and skills acquired in the bachelor degree by performing a project of a considerable size, and is able to report about it both orally and in written form.
The bachelor project consists of a literature study or a constrained research project under supervision of a lecturer, on a part of mathematics of the student's choice. The lecturer generally advises the student about a suitable subject.", "Additional Information Teaching Methods
The bachelor project takes place in the second semester of the third year of the degree. It is managed by several staff members acting as bachelor project coordinators.
Each student works individually, under guidance of a lecturer, on his/her research project.
Next to this, the coordinators organise a number of mandatory events, in which practical information is given, students are given guidance in planning their research, and in which students present multiple times about their progress to their fellow students and coordinators.
The bachelor project is completed by writing a bachelor thesis (in English) and by giving an oral final presentation end of June.", "Method of Assessment
The final grade of the bachelor project is the average of the following partial grades:
the bachelor thesis (contents, level, structure, writing style, references, ...) [50%]
performance of the bachelor project (work attitude, independence, precision, planning, collaboration with supervisor, ...) [30%]
the final oral presentation (clarity, style, use of media, interaction, ...) [20%]
To pass, the partial grade for the bachelor thesis must be at least 5.5.", "Entry Requirements
Students may only start on the Bachelor Project if they meet the following condition after the results of the interim exams in December of the current academic year have been taken into account: they have earned at least 120 of the full 180 programme credits.", "Additional Information Target Audience
Year 3 of the BSc Mathematics", "Additional Information
Presence at the meetings planned by the coordinators is mandatory.
Plagiarism is of course forbidden: a plagiarism check may be done after the thesis has been handed in.", "Explanation Canvas
Deadlines and mandatory meetings will be announced on Canvas", "Recommended background knowledge
Depends on the chosen research project."]
course_content:
The bachelor project is an aptitude test, in which the student shows (s)he is able to apply the knowledge and skills acquired in the bachelor degree by performing a project of a considerable size, and is able to report about it both orally and in written form.
The bachelor project consists of a literature study or a constrained research project under supervision of a lecturer, on a part of mathematics of the student's choice. The lecturer generally advises the student about a suitable subject.
additional_information_teaching_methods:
The bachelor project takes place in the second semester of the third year of the degree. It is managed by several staff members acting as bachelor project coordinators.
Each student works individually, under guidance of a lecturer, on his/her research project.
Next to this, the coordinators organise a number of mandatory events, in which practical information is given, students are given guidance in planning their research, and in which students present multiple times about their progress to their fellow students and coordinators.
The bachelor project is completed by writing a bachelor thesis (in English) and by giving an oral final presentation end of June.
method_of_assessment:
The final grade of the bachelor project is the average of the following partial grades:
the bachelor thesis (contents, level, structure, writing style, references, ...) [50%]
performance of the bachelor project (work attitude, independence, precision, planning, collaboration with supervisor, ...) [30%]
the final oral presentation (clarity, style, use of media, interaction, ...) [20%]
To pass, the partial grade for the bachelor thesis must be at least 5.5.
additional_information_target_audience: Year 3 of the BSc Mathematics
recommended_background_knowledge: Depends on the chosen research project.

course_paragraphs_json:
["Course Objective
At the end of this course, students are expected to:
understand the importance of ‘visual literacy’ in today’s world;
have some insight into the ways in which images function in a wider cultural and societal context, acknowledging the importance of contextualization;
be familiar with the ways in which concepts such as image, medium, and visual and material culture are used within research and study;
be familiar with differences between mono-, multi- and interdisciplinary approaches in the field of visual and material culture;
have insight into (the problems of) the scope and demarcation of visual and material culture as a discipline and its various systems of categorization and classification.", "Course Content
Approaching visual and material culture provides an introduction to the broad field of media, art, design and architecture, including the many dimensions and possible approaches to visual representation based on three central angles:
First, students are exposed to key concepts of the field (such as image, object, medium, representation, visual and material culture, meaning, original and reproduction, intention and reception, etc.), and how these relate to the language and the culture in which they are used.
The second angle pertains to the difference between mono-, multi- and interdisciplinary approaches, based on the notion that combining data, methods, perspectives and/or theories from multiple disciplines may lead to insights beyond the scope of separate disciplines: 1 + 1 = 3.
Finally students are exposed to various discipline-related systems of categorization and classification such as the demarcation of disciplines and the periodization of history, also as an introduction to the History of MKDA courses in periods 2, 4 and 5.", "Additional Information Teaching Methods
Lecture, seminar, field trip", "Method of Assessment
This course comprises 2 group assignments and 4 individual assignments corresponding with the different learning objectives. Only if all 6 assignments are completed on time (and marked with a ‘pass’), access is granted to the final examination in TestVision.
Connection between learning objectives and assessment: The final examination (100% of grade) involves all learning objectives.
End terms BA MKDA: 1, 2", "Literature
The literature will be announced in Canvas.", "Additional Information Target Audience
1st year bachelor Media, Art, Design and Architecture", "Additional Information
For attendance rules, see Teaching and Examination Regulations. Students should be aware that regular attendance is necessary to pass this course."]
course_content:
Approaching visual and material culture provides an introduction to the broad field of media, art, design and architecture, including the many dimensions and possible approaches to visual representation based on three central angles:
First, students are exposed to key concepts of the field (such as image, object, medium, representation, visual and material culture, meaning, original and reproduction, intention and reception, etc.), and how these relate to the language and the culture in which they are used.
The second angle pertains to the difference between mono-, multi- and interdisciplinary approaches, based on the notion that combining data, methods, perspectives and/or theories from multiple disciplines may lead to insights beyond the scope of separate disciplines: 1 + 1 = 3.
Finally students are exposed to various discipline-related systems of categorization and classification such as the demarcation of disciplines and the periodization of history, also as an introduction to the History of MKDA courses in periods 2, 4 and 5.
additional_information_teaching_methods: Lecture, seminar, field trip
method_of_assessment:
This course comprises 2 group assignments and 4 individual assignments corresponding with the different learning objectives. Only if all 6 assignments are completed on time (and marked with a ‘pass’), access is granted to the final examination in TestVision.
Connection between learning objectives and assessment: The final examination (100% of grade) involves all learning objectives.
End terms BA MKDA: 1, 2
literature: The literature will be announced in Canvas.
additional_information_target_audience: 1st year bachelor Media, Art, Design and Architecture

course_paragraphs_json:
["Course Objective
This course aims to provide MKDA students a framework for better understanding developments in European cultural history. At the end of this course, students are expected to:
Knowledge Acquisition: Students will gain a foundational understanding of significant historical events and core concepts in the cultural history of Europe via lectures, class participation, and reading core texts.
Knowledge Recall: Students will be assessed on their ability to accurately recall and explain key historical events and concepts in European cultural history through written exams and quizzes.
Knowledge Relevance: Students will explore and discuss via debates and presentations the contemporary relevance of European cultural history, developing insights into how historical events and cultural trends continue to shape modern European society.", "Course Content
This course provides a critical and thematically structured introduction to European cultural history from the mediaeval period to the current century. It examines the interplay between cultural production and historical transformation, tracing how shifts in religious belief, political authority, scientific understanding, and artistic expression redefined European societies from the Renaissance to the modern era. Key topics include the Reformation and Counter-Reformation, Enlightenment thought, revolutionary ideologies, the rise of mass culture, and the cultural consequences of industrialization, nationalism, and war. Drawing on a wide range of primary sources—including visual art, literature, political treatises, and philosophical texts—students will explore the evolving relationship between culture and power in European history. Special attention will be given to the role of cultural institutions such as the church, court, academy, and museum, and to the evolving definitions of cultural authority, taste, and legitimacy. Students will engage with the concept of "culture" in its broadest sense—encompassing intellectual life, religious practice, visual and material expression, political ideology, and everyday experience—while critically interrogating how these domains intersect with power, identity, and social change.", "Additional Information Teaching Methods
The sessions of this course are offered in English. Students following the Dutch (i.e. bilingual) track may in some cases submit their written assignments in either English or Dutch. Exceptions are multiple-choice tests, assignments with peer reviewers across language tracks, and group assignments (across language tracks).", "Method of Assessment
Assessments include presentations, literature synopsis, knowledge quizzes, and a written examination. These assignments correspond with the learning objectives (1, 2, 3) to a ) acquire an overview of European cultural knowledge through digesting lecture and reading materials, b) being able to actively recall these details in written and spoken form, and c) being able to explain the development and relevance of European cultural developments over the centuries.
End terms BA MKDA: 1, 3", "Literature
Texts provided in the syllabus/Canvas which form the core readings and topics in the course sessions.", "Additional Information Target Audience
This course is compulsory for all BA MKDA students in their first year.", "Additional Information
For attendance rules, see Teaching and Examination Regulations. Students should be aware that regular attendance is necessary to pass the course."]
course_objective:
This course aims to provide MKDA students a framework for better understanding developments in European cultural history. At the end of this course, students are expected to:
Knowledge Acquisition: Students will gain a foundational understanding of significant historical events and core concepts in the cultural history of Europe via lectures, class participation, and reading core texts.
Knowledge Recall: Students will be assessed on their ability to accurately recall and explain key historical events and concepts in European cultural history through written exams and quizzes.
Knowledge Relevance: Students will explore and discuss via debates and presentations the contemporary relevance of European cultural history, developing insights into how historical events and cultural trends continue to shape modern European society.
course_content: This course provides a critical and thematically structured introduction to European cultural history from the mediaeval period to the current century. It examines the interplay between cultural production and historical transformation, tracing how shifts in religious belief, political authority, scientific understanding, and artistic expression redefined European societies from the Renaissance to the modern era. Key topics include the Reformation and Counter-Reformation, Enlightenment thought, revolutionary ideologies, the rise of mass culture, and the cultural consequences of industrialization, nationalism, and war. Drawing on a wide range of primary sources—including visual art, literature, political treatises, and philosophical texts—students will explore the evolving relationship between culture and power in European history. Special attention will be given to the role of cultural institutions such as the church, court, academy, and museum, and to the evolving definitions of cultural authority, taste, and legitimacy. Students will engage with the concept of "culture" in its broadest sense—encompassing intellectual life, religious practice, visual and material expression, political ideology, and everyday experience—while critically interrogating how these domains intersect with power, identity, and social change.
additional_information_teaching_methods: The sessions of this course are offered in English. Students following the Dutch (i.e. bilingual) track may in some cases submit their written assignments in either English or Dutch. Exceptions are multiple-choice tests, assignments with peer reviewers across language tracks, and group assignments (across language tracks).
method_of_assessment:
Assessments include presentations, literature synopsis, knowledge quizzes, and a written examination. These assignments correspond with the learning objectives (1, 2, 3) to a ) acquire an overview of European cultural knowledge through digesting lecture and reading materials, b) being able to actively recall these details in written and spoken form, and c) being able to explain the development and relevance of European cultural developments over the centuries.
End terms BA MKDA: 1, 3
literature: Texts provided in the syllabus/Canvas which form the core readings and topics in the course sessions.
additional_information_target_audience: This course is compulsory for all BA MKDA students in their first year.

course_paragraphs_json:
["Course Objective
At the end of this course, students are expected to:
be able to find relevant scholarly information in a systematic manner on a topic of study of their choice, by searching in catalogues and search engines, like the catalogue of the university library, e-resources, online catalogues and visual databases;
know the importance of careful accounting for sources and can make a bibliography according to the conventions applied/used by MKDA;
be trained in knowing and recognizing a number of characteristics of images which are used as arguments;
be trained in evaluating websites and publications as to their academic level and usability;
have the competence to write a brief essay about their own research, the resulting text having a clear structure and argumentative line so as to be comprehensible for its readers.", "Course Content
An academic education is not just a matter of acquiring new knowledge and insights. It is also important to develop a number of skills needed for doing research in an academic setting and for communicating it both verbally and visually.
In this course, students start training in doing scholarly work. They are expected to fill their own ‘toolbox’ with skills, allowing them for the remainder of their study, and afterwards, to deal in an academic manner with information. This course consists of an intensive training of different skills, in relation to a topic of their choice. The knowledge and skills students gradually acquire in this way culminate in writing a scholarly essay as a final assignment.", "Additional Information Teaching Methods
Lecture, seminar, practical training.", "Method of Assessment
Assessment takes place on the basis of 6 partial assignments, which have to be completed on time. When all 6 assignments are marked with a ‘pass’, the course’s final grade is a ‘P’ (pass). In all other cases the course’s final grade is an ‘F’ (fail). The first 5 partial assignments serve as preliminary assessments and serve to improve the course’s attainability, as well as preparation for the 6th assignment.
NB: For first-year students passing the language proficiency test is a precondition for passing this course.
NB: For first-year students, this course should be completed with a ‘pass’ to be eligible for a positive binding study advice (BSA).
Connection between learning objectives and assessment:
Learning objectives 1 and 2: assignment 1 (searching and assessing publications).
Learning objectives 3 and 4: assignment 2 (analysing, evaluating and processing information) and assignment 3 (text analysis).
Learning objective 5: assignment 4 (text plan), assignment 5 (written presentation 1st draft) and assignment 6 (written presentation final draft).
End terms BA MADA: 1,2,5,9", "Literature
The literature will be announced in the syllabus/Canvas.", "Additional Information Target Audience
1st year bachelor Media, Art, Design and Architecture, and Premaster students Arts and Culture / Heritage Studies.", "Additional Information
For attendance rules, see Teaching and Examination Regulations. Students should be aware that regular attendance is necessary to pass the course.
This course is also taken by Premaster students.", "Custom Course Registration
For this course there is an exception to the standard enrolment procedure (whereby students sign up for the course, the learning approach and the examination). For this course the seminar division in groups is made by the course coordinator, after which the signing up for seminars is handled by the Education Office. Students can sign up for the course and lectures, but not for the seminars."]
course_content:
An academic education is not just a matter of acquiring new knowledge and insights. It is also important to develop a number of skills needed for doing research in an academic setting and for communicating it both verbally and visually.
In this course, students start training in doing scholarly work. They are expected to fill their own ‘toolbox’ with skills, allowing them for the remainder of their study, and afterwards, to deal in an academic manner with information. This course consists of an intensive training of different skills, in relation to a topic of their choice. The knowledge and skills students gradually acquire in this way culminate in writing a scholarly essay as a final assignment.
additional_information_teaching_methods: Lecture, seminar, practical training.
method_of_assessment:
Assessment takes place on the basis of 6 partial assignments, which have to be completed on time. When all 6 assignments are marked with a ‘pass’, the course’s final grade is a ‘P’ (pass). In all other cases the course’s final grade is an ‘F’ (fail). The first 5 partial assignments serve as preliminary assessments and serve to improve the course’s attainability, as well as preparation for the 6th assignment.
NB: For first-year students passing the language proficiency test is a precondition for passing this course.
NB: For first-year students, this course should be completed with a ‘pass’ to be eligible for a positive binding study advice (BSA).
Connection between learning objectives and assessment:
Learning objectives 1 and 2: assignment 1 (searching and assessing publications).
Learning objectives 3 and 4: assignment 2 (analysing, evaluating and processing information) and assignment 3 (text analysis).
Learning objective 5: assignment 4 (text plan), assignment 5 (written presentation 1st draft) and assignment 6 (written presentation final draft).
End terms BA MADA: 1,2,5,9
literature: The literature will be announced in the syllabus/Canvas.
additional_information_target_audience: 1st year bachelor Media, Art, Design and Architecture, and Premaster students Arts and Culture / Heritage Studies.

course_name: History of Media, Art, Design and Architecture: Early Modern
course_paragraphs_json:
["Course Objective
At the end of this course, students are expected to have:
knowledge of the historical framework of major objects from the period of the late Middle Ages (ca 1400) to around 1800, and to be capable of naming major movements to which these objects belong, as well as globally date and subsume them under a style, movement (or ‘ism’);
knowledge of the cultural historical context in which art, (media), design and architecture function during this period;
insight as well as to have practiced using discipline-related terms and concepts;
insight into the variety of functions and meanings of (specific) objects and images, as well as to their intended meanings and different interpretations;
developed a critical attitude regarding scholarly and otherwise relevant literature.", "Course Content
History of MKDA: Early Modern forms, together with History of MKDA II and III (periods 4 and 5), an in-depth triptych covering the essentially Western history of visual and material culture from ca 1400 onwards. This tryptich constitutes a deepening of the early modern period from the Cultural History course from period 1.
Handbooks generally describe the history of one medium or discipline. In History of MKDA I, II and II, the histories of art, (media), design and architecture are interwoven chronologically, where, given the nature and history of the disciplines, art and architecture will be more dominant in the Early Modern period.
History of MKDA: Early Modern covers the period from the late Middle Ages (ca. 1400) up to ca. 1800. Through a series of lectures and seminars, students will gain insights into and become familiar with crucial developments in in the history of Western visual and material culture by means of characteristic art, (media), design and architecture. This provides the historical basis for the continuation of the MKDA study.", "Additional Information Teaching Methods
Lecture meetings, seminars, field trip (if possible)", "Method of Assessment
Assessment takes place by:
Oral Presentation (20%): learning objectives 2,3,5.
Written (sub)exams (together 80%): learning objectives 1,2,3,4,5.
Endterms BA MKDA: 1,2,3,12
The oral presentation involves critically processing literature in the field of media, art, design and architecture.
The written (sub)exams include knowledge and insight questions and/or image recognition questions (for a given image/object/media/architecture, note the maker, representation/title, year, location, technique(s) used and/or material.", "Literature
Koenraad Jonckheere, A New History of Western Art: From Antiquity to the Present Day, Hannibal Books, 2022).
Additional literature will be announced in the syllabus/Canvas.", "Additional Information Target Audience
1st year bachelor Media, Art, Design and Architecture", "Additional Information
For attendance rules, see Teaching and Examination Regulations. Students should be aware that regular attendance is necessary to pass the course.", "Recommended background knowledge
not applicable"]
course_content:
History of MKDA: Early Modern forms, together with History of MKDA II and III (periods 4 and 5), an in-depth triptych covering the essentially Western history of visual and material culture from ca 1400 onwards. This tryptich constitutes a deepening of the early modern period from the Cultural History course from period 1.
Handbooks generally describe the history of one medium or discipline. In History of MKDA I, II and II, the histories of art, (media), design and architecture are interwoven chronologically, where, given the nature and history of the disciplines, art and architecture will be more dominant in the Early Modern period.
History of MKDA: Early Modern covers the period from the late Middle Ages (ca. 1400) up to ca. 1800. Through a series of lectures and seminars, students will gain insights into and become familiar with crucial developments in in the history of Western visual and material culture by means of characteristic art, (media), design and architecture. This provides the historical basis for the continuation of the MKDA study.
additional_information_teaching_methods: Lecture meetings, seminars, field trip (if possible)
method_of_assessment:
Assessment takes place by:
Oral Presentation (20%): learning objectives 2,3,5.
Written (sub)exams (together 80%): learning objectives 1,2,3,4,5.
Endterms BA MKDA: 1,2,3,12
The oral presentation involves critically processing literature in the field of media, art, design and architecture.
The written (sub)exams include knowledge and insight questions and/or image recognition questions (for a given image/object/media/architecture, note the maker, representation/title, year, location, technique(s) used and/or material.
literature:
Koenraad Jonckheere, A New History of Western Art: From Antiquity to the Present Day, Hannibal Books, 2022).
Additional literature will be announced in the syllabus/Canvas.
additional_information_target_audience: 1st year bachelor Media, Art, Design and Architecture
recommended_background_knowledge: not applicable

course_paragraphs_json:
["Course Objective
At the end of this course, students are expected to:
have knowledge of basic concepts for the visual and material analysis of images, objects and buildings, as employed in scholarly literature within the four different disciplines;
be able to apply these concepts in their own descriptions of images, objects and buildings;
have basic insight into the interrelationships of different media in images, objects and architecture;
be acquainted with several theories and methods for analysing and describing images, objects and architecture in relation to their context.", "Course Content
Proficiency in the analysis of visual images and material artefacts is essential for research in the field of media, art, design and architecture. The composition of items of fine art and visual design, the storylines of movies, the material features of artefacts, the visualization of the structure of buildings – these are all aspects encountered by students during their study with which they have to become acquainted. This course provides an introduction to observing, analysing and describing MKDA’s objects of study, as well as to the different ways in which the visual and material characteristics of media, art, design and architecture may take on particular meanings.", "Additional Information Teaching Methods
Lecture meeting and Q & A session, seminar.", "Method of Assessment
Assessment takes place on the basis of two written assignments each around 1.250 words, with each amounting to 50% of the final grade. If the final grade is a pass, it is not necessary to do a resit for non-passing partial assignments. If the final grade is a fail, a resit can be organized for each failed partial assignment.
Connection between learning objectives and assessment: The two assignments correspond with the four learning objectives.
The course corresponds with the following end terms of the Bachelor Media, Art, design and Architecture: 4, 5, 8.", "Literature
The literature will be announced in the syllabus/Canvas.", "Additional Information Target Audience
1st year bachelor Media, Art, Design and Architecture", "Additional Information
For attendance rules, see Teaching and Examination Regulations. Students should be aware that regular attendance is necessary to pass the course."]

The composition of items of fine art and visual design, the storylines of movies, the material features of artefacts, the visualization of the structure of buildings – these are all aspects encountered by students during their study with which they have to become acquainted. This course provides an introduction to observing, analysing and describing MKDA’s objects of study, as well as to the different ways in which the visual and material characteristics of media, art, design and architecture may take on particular meanings.

course_paragraphs_json:
["Course Objective
Course objectives are:
You have knowledge of and insight into the most important areas of English grammar, particularly those which typically cause students problems when writing formal English.
You have insight into your own strengths and weaknesses in grammatical terms, and know how to go about resolving the weaknesses.
You have knowledge of the structure and register of academic texts in your discipline.
You have insight into the most important stylistic and rhetorical aspects of formal written texts in English.
You have insight into the strengths and weaknesses in your own English writing skills, and know how you can go about expanding the strengths and reducing the weaknesses.
You can write a well-structured English text in a formal style about a subject related to your own degree. The text is free of serious lexical and grammatical mistakes that have a negative effect on the readability of your text.", "Course Content
The course for students of MKDA consists of a grammar and a writing component.
The grammar component consists of an introduction into the most important aspects of English grammar, with an emphasis on the structures which are frequently used in academic language and on structures which typically cause problems for students when writing formal English. The writing component consists of a lecture series focusing on the characteristics of written academic English, plus a series of seminars which provide practice on specific language elements and also guide students in writing academic texts.", "Additional Information Teaching Methods
Lectures and seminars each week", "Method of Assessment
Grammar: multiple choice computer exam (50%): learning objectives 1, 2
Writing: a series of writing assignments about a topic in your field (50%): learning objectives 2, 3, 4, 5, 6
Relationship to the final attainment levels of the BA MKDA: 8, 10
In order to pass the course, you need a minimum of 5.5 for both components.", "Additional Information Target Audience
First-year students of MKDA", "Additional Information
This is an obligatory course in the first year programme for MKDA and is not open to students following other degrees.
For attendance rules, see Teaching and Examination Regulations. Students should be aware that regular attendance is necessary to pass the course."]
course_objective:
Course objectives are:
You have knowledge of and insight into the most important areas of English grammar, particularly those which typically cause students problems when writing formal English.
You have insight into your own strengths and weaknesses in grammatical terms, and know how to go about resolving the weaknesses.
You have knowledge of the structure and register of academic texts in your discipline.
You have insight into the most important stylistic and rhetorical aspects of formal written texts in English.
You have insight into the strengths and weaknesses in your own English writing skills, and know how you can go about expanding the strengths and reducing the weaknesses.
You can write a well-structured English text in a formal style about a subject related to your own degree. The text is free of serious lexical and grammatical mistakes that have a negative effect on the readability of your text.
course_content:
The course for students of MKDA consists of a grammar and a writing component.
The grammar component consists of an introduction into the most important aspects of English grammar, with an emphasis on the structures which are frequently used in academic language and on structures which typically cause problems for students when writing formal English. The writing component consists of a lecture series focusing on the characteristics of written academic English, plus a series of seminars which provide practice on specific language elements and also guide students in writing academic texts.
additional_information_teaching_methods: Lectures and seminars each week
method_of_assessment:
Grammar: multiple choice computer exam (50%): learning objectives 1, 2
Writing: a series of writing assignments about a topic in your field (50%): learning objectives 2, 3, 4, 5, 6
Relationship to the final attainment levels of the BA MKDA: 8, 10
In order to pass the course, you need a minimum of 5.5 for both components.
additional_information_target_audience: First-year students of MKDA

course_name: History of Media, Art, Design and Architecture: Modern
course_paragraphs_json:
["Course Objective
At the end of this course, students are expected to have:
knowledge of the cultural historical context in which western images and objects function during the period from around 1800 to approx. 1960;
knowledge of crucial developments in western media, art, design and architecture in this period with respect to style periods, ways of thinking, objectives (manifestos), discourses, production processes and (technological) media;
insights into the importance of an interdisciplinary approach of issues within the discipline;
insight into and gained experience in applying discipline-related terms and concepts;
grown acquainted with a limited number of theoretical approaches in relation to modernity and possible criticisms of it;
knowledge of and insight into the chronology and features of style periods within the era addressed.", "Course Content
History of Media, Art, Design and Architecture: Modern is part of triptych, together with the two other History of MKDA courses (in periods 2 and 5). This course triptych provides a comprehensive overview of the history of western visual and material culture in the early modern, modern, and postmodern eras and up to the present day. History of MKDA Modern provides insight into the history of western visual and material culture from around 1800 to around 1960.
In a series of lectures, the course provides an overview of historical ideas and developments from this period. Starting from the concept of ‘modernity’ (which also comprises anti-modernist tendencies), this course addresses different cultural developments in their socio-economic context.
Questions addressed include: How did new tools and technical means of (re)production such as photography and film contribute to new ways of looking and representation? How did our views on ‘realism’ change? Which effects did ‘the modernist project’ have as a product and symptom of rationalization, industrialization and mass consumption? How did avant-garde movements look at modernity and how did they try to push it into particular directions? Students get acquainted with..." style periods, (technological) media, and theoretical and methodological approaches. A critical consideration of formative events reveals both connections and differences, thus deepening the historical basis for the subsequent courses of the curriculum.", "Additional Information Teaching Methods
Lecture, seminar, literature study, (excursion).", "Method of Assessment
Written examination (80%): learning objectives 1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6, and
group assignment (20%): learning objectives 2, 6.
Connection between learning objectives and assessments:
Learning objective 1: examination (knowledge questions)
Learning objective 2: assignment, examination (image recognition, knowledge questions)
Learning objective 3: examination (essay questions)
Learning objective 4: examination (knowledge questions)
Learning objective 5: examination (essay questions)
Learning objective 6: assignment, examination (image recognition).
End terms: 1, 2, 3, 12.", "Literature
The literature will be announced in the syllabus/Canvas.", "Additional Information Target Audience
1st year bachelor Media, Art, Design and Architecture", "Additional Information
This module is a compulsory course in the first year.
For attendance rules, see Teaching and Examination Regulations. Students should be aware that regular attendance is necessary to pass the course.", "Recommended background knowledge
The courses “Cultural History” (period 1) and “History of Media, Art, Desgin, and Architecture: Early Modern” (period 2) have been followed."]
course_content:
History of Media, Art, Design and Architecture: Modern is part of triptych, together with the two other History of MKDA courses (in periods 2 and 5). This course triptych provides a comprehensive overview of the history of western visual and material culture in the early modern, modern, and postmodern eras and up to the present day. History of MKDA Modern provides insight into the history of western visual and material culture from around 1800 to around 1960.
In a series of lectures, the course provides an overview of historical ideas and developments from this period. Starting from the concept of ‘modernity’ (which also comprises anti-modernist tendencies), this course addresses different cultural developments in their socio-economic context.
Questions addressed include: How did new tools and technical means of (re)production such as photography and film contribute to new ways of looking and representation? How did our views on ‘realism’ change? Which effects did ‘the modernist project’ have as a product and symptom of rationalization, industrialization and mass consumption? How did avant-garde movements look at modernity and how did they try to push it into particular directions? Students get acquainted with..." style periods, (technological) media, and theoretical and methodological approaches. A critical consideration of formative events reveals both connections and differences, thus deepening the historical basis for the subsequent courses of the curriculum.
additional_information_teaching_methods: Lecture, seminar, literature study, (excursion).
method_of_assessment:
Written examination (80%): learning objectives 1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6, and
group assignment (20%): learning objectives 2, 6.
Connection between learning objectives and assessments:
Learning objective 1: examination (knowledge questions)
Learning objective 2: assignment, examination (image recognition, knowledge questions)
Learning objective 3: examination (essay questions)
Learning objective 4: examination (knowledge questions)
Learning objective 5: examination (essay questions)
Learning objective 6: assignment, examination (image recognition).
End terms: 1, 2, 3, 12.
literature: The literature will be announced in the syllabus/Canvas.
additional_information_target_audience: 1st year bachelor Media, Art, Design and Architecture
recommended_background_knowledge: The courses “Cultural History” (period 1) and “History of Media, Art, Desgin, and Architecture: Early Modern” (period 2) have been followed.
