course_paragraphs_json:
["Course Objective
Epistemology is the philosophical study of knowledge, belief, truth, rationality and their social and political applications. This course is an active learning course in epistemology, focusing on its applied and social/political dimensions, like echo chambers, conspiracy theories, and propaganda and ideology. Each student is expected to engage in serious self-evaluation and critical self-reflection of their work and their peer's work. The overarching goal is that this will facilitate an authentic learning experience.
Course Goals:
Educated self-reflection: To facilitate self-reflection on your work and progress in epistemology (Reflection Journal)
Applications: To apply concepts, arguments, and theories from epistemology to real-world cases (Seminar activities and Exam).
Conceptualization, understanding, and debate framing: To conceptualize and frame debates in public life using the resources of epistemology (Seminar activities and Reflection Journal; Exam)
Intellectual development: To formulate, present, and defend your own argument and educated judgment in epistemology (Seminars and Exam).
Intellectual engagement: To read, interpret and critically respond to contemporary essays in epistemology (Seminar and Reflection Journal activities)", "Course Content
This course is a critical introduction to epistemology, focusing on its applied, social, and political dimensions. It provides a firm foundation in epistemology and zooms in on contemporary social-political challenges, including questions like:
When, if ever, is giving someone a platform to express their views impermissible?
Is it irrational to believe conspiracy theories? Why?
What is so problematic about information bubbles or echo chambers?
How should we respond to skeptics?
Can beliefs ever be wrongful or unjust? How?
What is ideology, and how does it influence thought and belief?
Do some beliefs signal social identity or group loyalty—if so, how should we evaluate them?
Are there racial, class-based, or gender-based standpoints which give certain groups epistemic advantages?
Should we even care about 'knowledge' or 'truth'? What are (or should be) the epistemic goals of education?
What is the basis of trust? When can we trust what people say?
We will first learn about the core concepts of epistemology that are used in many debates—knowledge, truth, justification, evidence, and some of the controversies surrounding these concepts. We will then explore social-political topics in epistemology, where various core concepts are applied and new concepts and controversies are introduced.", "Additional Information Teaching Methods
Lectures and seminars (active learning groups).", "Method of Assessment
Reflection Journal (Short writing portfolio)(40%): learning goals 1, 3, 5
In-person Written Exam (argument analysis; case study; and short essay) (60%): learning goals 2, 3, 4.
Seminar activities (pass/fail): learning goals 2, 3, 4, 5.", "Literature
To be announced in the course guide", "Additional Information Target Audience
Second year PPE students.", "Additional Information
Please note that participation in the seminars is mandatory.
Lectures are highly recommended. It is hard to excel in the course without attending the lectures, as this is where nuanced interpretations and connections are explored and where deeper insights are developed—the course content cannot be gleaned from the readings alone.
For better understanding and to facilitate in-class discussion, the required reading for each lecture should be read in advance.", "Explanation Canvas
The course program will be on canvas. All course readings and assignments are on canvas.", "Recommended background knowledge
Mandatory courses PPE specialization Track 1: Philosophy"]
course_objective:
Epistemology is the philosophical study of knowledge, belief, truth, rationality and their social and political applications. This course is an active learning course in epistemology, focusing on its applied and social/political dimensions, like echo chambers, conspiracy theories, and propaganda and ideology. Each student is expected to engage in serious self-evaluation and critical self-reflection of their work and their peer's work. The overarching goal is that this will facilitate an authentic learning experience.
Course Goals:
Educated self-reflection: To facilitate self-reflection on your work and progress in epistemology (Reflection Journal)
Applications: To apply concepts, arguments, and theories from epistemology to real-world cases (Seminar activities and Exam).
Conceptualization, understanding, and debate framing: To conceptualize and frame debates in public life using the resources of epistemology (Seminar activities and Reflection Journal; Exam)
Intellectual development: To formulate, present, and defend your own argument and educated judgment in epistemology (Seminars and Exam).
Intellectual engagement: To read, interpret and critically respond to contemporary essays in epistemology (Seminar and Reflection Journal activities)
course_content:
This course is a critical introduction to epistemology, focusing on its applied, social, and political dimensions. It provides a firm foundation in epistemology and zooms in on contemporary social-political challenges, including questions like:
When, if ever, is giving someone a platform to express their views impermissible?
Is it irrational to believe conspiracy theories? Why?
What is so problematic about information bubbles or echo chambers?
How should we respond to skeptics?
Can beliefs ever be wrongful or unjust? How?
What is ideology, and how does it influence thought and belief?
Do some beliefs signal social identity or group loyalty—if so, how should we evaluate them?
Are there racial, class-based, or gender-based standpoints which give certain groups epistemic advantages?
Should we even care about 'knowledge' or 'truth'? What are (or should be) the epistemic goals of education?
What is the basis of trust? When can we trust what people say?
We will first learn about the core concepts of epistemology that are used in many debates—knowledge, truth, justification, evidence, and some of the controversies surrounding these concepts. We will then explore social-political topics in epistemology, where various core concepts are applied and new concepts and controversies are introduced.
additional_information_teaching_methods: Lectures and seminars (active learning groups).
method_of_assessment:
Reflection Journal (Short writing portfolio)(40%): learning goals 1, 3, 5
In-person Written Exam (argument analysis; case study; and short essay) (60%): learning goals 2, 3, 4.
Seminar activities (pass/fail): learning goals 2, 3, 4, 5.

course_name: Ethics II: Autonomy, Freedom and Responsibility
course_paragraphs_json:
["Course Objective
Distinguish and evaluate different types of responsibility: Learn to differentiate between (a) causal, legal and moral responsibility, (b) retrospective, retrospective and remedial responsibility, and (c) individual and collective responsibility, and assess their relevance in ethical and political contexts.
Understand key theories of moral responsibility: Develop a clear grasp of major philosophical approaches to (retrospective) moral responsibility, including debates about blame and praise, freedom, and the relationship between responsibility and normative ethics.
Critically analyze relation between responsibility, social freedom and justice: Explore how responsibility functions in contexts of debates about freedom, distributive justice and structural injustices.
Develop philosophical writing and argumentation skills: Improve your ability to construct clear, well-reasoned written arguments, with a focus on clarity and coherence.", "Course Content
Think of how often responsibility is invoked—in headlines, political commentary, personal conversations, and moments of self-reflection. Public debate around climate change, inequality, global conflict, and political scandal is saturated with responsibility claims. So too are our everyday discussions about consumption, civic behavior, and moral choices. Sometimes the term “responsibility” is used explicitly; often it is only implied. But what does it actually mean to be morally responsible?
This course investigates the concept of moral responsibility as it appears across public, interpersonal, and personal domains. We aim to understand and critically assess how responsibility claims are made and what they presuppose. What kinds of responsibility are there? When is someone blameworthy or praiseworthy? What is the relationship between moral responsibility and normative judgments about right and wrong?
Module 1–2: The Foundations of Moral Responsibility
In the first part of the course, we will examine foundational questions in the ethics of responsibility:
What is the relationship between normative ethics (what’s right or wrong) and moral responsibility (who’s to blame or praise)?
How should we distinguish between different kinds of responsibility?
What do classic debates about freedom of the will and determinism tell us about responsibility?
What is blame, and when is it warranted or unjustified?
We will engage with key historical and contemporary texts to build a critical framework for thinking about moral responsibility.
Module 3: Responsibility, Freedom and Justice
In the second half of the course, we will turn to questions of responsibility that arise in the context of theories of freedom and justice. First we examine the role that responsibility plays in different views about social freedom. In particular, we discuss and assess accounts of social and political freedom that are defined in terms of responsibility. We then turn to accounts of distributive justice. In particular, we contrast luck-egalitarianism with (left- and right-) libertarian views. Finally, we examine how responsibility functions in cases of structural injustice, where harms emerge not from individual wrongdoing but from collective patterns and institutional structures.", "Additional Information Teaching Methods
Lectures and seminars", "Method of Assessment
Mid term essay (40%): 1, 2, 4
Final exam (60%)
Tests
Course Objectives: 1, 2, 3, 4
Seminar activities (Pass/Fail)
Tests
Course Objectives: 1, 2, 3, 4", "Literature
The list of readings will be announced on Canvas.", "Additional Information Target Audience
Second year PPE students", "Recommended background knowledge
First semester courses of Philosophy PPE track"]

Critically analyze relation between responsibility, social freedom and justice: Explore how responsibility functions in contexts of debates about freedom, distributive justice and structural injustices.
Develop philosophical writing and argumentation skills: Improve your ability to construct clear, well-reasoned written arguments, with a focus on clarity and coherence.

Think of how often responsibility is invoked—in headlines, political commentary, personal conversations, and moments of self-reflection. Public debate around climate change, inequality, global conflict, and political scandal is saturated with responsibility claims. So too are our everyday discussions about consumption, civic behavior, and moral choices. Sometimes the term “responsibility” is used explicitly; often it is only implied. But what does it actually mean to be morally responsible?
This course investigates the concept of moral responsibility as it appears across public, interpersonal, and personal domains. We aim to understand and critically assess how responsibility claims are made and what they presuppose. What kinds of responsibility are there? When is someone blameworthy or praiseworthy? What is the relationship between moral responsibility and normative judgments about right and wrong?
Module 1–2: The Foundations of Moral Responsibility
In the first part of the course, we will examine foundational questions in the ethics of responsibility:
What is the relationship between normative ethics (what’s right or wrong) and moral responsibility (who’s to blame or praise)?
How should we distinguish between different kinds of responsibility?
What do classic debates about freedom of the will and determinism tell us about responsibility?
What is blame, and when is it warranted or unjustified?
We will engage with key historical and contemporary texts to build a critical framework for thinking about moral responsibility.
Module 3: Responsibility, Freedom and Justice
In the second half of the course, we will turn to questions of responsibility that arise in the context of theories of freedom and justice. First we examine the role that responsibility plays in different views about social freedom. In particular, we discuss and assess accounts of social and political freedom that are defined in terms of responsibility. We then turn to accounts of distributive justice. In particular, we contrast luck-egalitarianism with (left- and right-) libertarian views. Finally, we examine how responsibility functions in cases of structural injustice, where harms emerge not from individual wrongdoing but from collective patterns and institutional structures.

course_paragraphs_json:
["Course Objective
In his The Subjection of Women (1861), John Stuart Mill (1806-1873) makes the case that both men and women are to be considered to be equal.
Only by ascribing gender equality to its members, can a society implement intellectual freedom, he claims. In his On Liberty (1859), that was co-authored with his wife Harriet Taylor Mill (1807-1858), Mill presents a similar argument, this time for liberty. However, On Liberty warns about a blanket attribution of liberty to all human beings.
In this course we will set both the texts in relation to each other to understand whether Mill changed his position between On Liberty and Subjection. We will also reflect on the consistency of Mills’ position on human freedom in these texts and in some relevant of his writings on policy too.", "Course Content
Learning objectives
On successful completion, you will:
learn to read and understand a text carefully;
see the connections between the past, present and future;
gain a deeper understanding of your place in the world;
obtain a good introductory understanding about a key thinker in the European liberal tradition;
apply critical skills to contemporary situations.", "Additional Information Teaching Methods
Lectures and seminars (active learning groups).", "Method of Assessment
Methods of assessment (the final grade is determined by a weighted average of three components):
Reading assignments through Feedback Fruits (10%; assessment of learning objective 1)
2 papers (45% each; assessment of learning objectives 2-5)", "Literature
Details TBA through Canvas.", "Additional Information Target Audience
Second year PPE students", "Additional Information
Please note that participation in the seminars is mandatory.", "Recommended background knowledge
Mandatory courses PPE specialization Track 1: Philosophy"]
course_objective:
In his The Subjection of Women (1861), John Stuart Mill (1806-1873) makes the case that both men and women are to be considered to be equal.
Only by ascribing gender equality to its members, can a society implement intellectual freedom, he claims. In his On Liberty (1859), that was co-authored with his wife Harriet Taylor Mill (1807-1858), Mill presents a similar argument, this time for liberty. However, On Liberty warns about a blanket attribution of liberty to all human beings.
In this course we will set both the texts in relation to each other to understand whether Mill changed his position between On Liberty and Subjection. We will also reflect on the consistency of Mills’ position on human freedom in these texts and in some relevant of his writings on policy too.

course_paragraphs_json:
["Course Objective
The learning objective of this course are:
The ability to place contemporary discussions about global justice in a historical context
To acquire knowledge of different theories of global justice and of key concepts (global democracy, human rights, just war)
The ability to critically assess the history and theories of global justice and to apply insights to contemporary issues", "Course Content
The search for justice has been a central theme in human history. The political and institutional implementation of the ideals of justice has traditionally been assumed to be restricted to the confines of the modern nation-state. This course considers questions of justice that go beyond these confines. Questions we will address include:
Which duties, if any, do we have towards citizens in other parts of the world? What is the relation between human rights and global justice? Which transnational institutional arrangement have been or should be established to secure global justice? How should we deal with states that grossly violate the rights of their citizens? What principles of justice govern armed conflict?
We will consider work by a variety of political philosophers and theorists who address these questions. Some of the authors that we will read include Griffin, Rawls, Sen, Abizadeh, Blake, Miller, Walzer, McMahan, and Frowe. The positions and theories are discussed in the context of various problems, including extreme poverty, inequality, failing states, democracy, human rights and military conflicts.", "Additional Information Teaching Methods
Lectures and seminars (active learning groups). Please note that participation is mandatory.", "Method of Assessment
Written exam (50%, assessing learning outcomes 1-3), essay (50%, assessing learning outcomes 1-3) and seminar assignments (pass/fail).", "Literature
Weekly readings to be announced on canvas", "Additional Information Target Audience
Second year PPE students", "Additional Information
Please note that participation in the seminar groups is mandatory.", "Recommended background knowledge
Mandatory courses PPE specialization Track 1: Philosophy"]

course_paragraphs_json:
["Course Objective
This course’s main objective is to make students understand the importance of institutions in shaping politics and policies. After this course, students should be able to:
Define and use the concept of political institutions and discuss it in relation to the relevant literature.
Describe (patterns in) the large variety of political institutions across countries and other contexts.
Explain and evaluate the way in which political institutions shape political behaviour, interaction, and discourse.
Explain how political institutions develop and change, why they often remain unchanged, and how institutional change is possible.
Explain the differences between various strands of neo-institutionalist theory in political science.
Apply various concepts and theories in the analysis of concrete cases of politics and policy-making.
Present their findings in writing and reflect on them with other students.", "Course Content
The study of political institutions occupies a central position in political science. Drawing upon both established and recent research from within the feld of comparative politics, this course surveys the major theories and findings about the causes, consequences and conduct of political institutions. It does so by first laying out the conceptual groundwork for examining the causal links between institutions, organizations and the costs of exchange (Part I). Next, this course traces the origins of and changes in political institutions through the lenses of competing schools of thought (Part II). Finally, it systematizes the variability in the shape of political institutions in democracies (Part III) and its implications for policy (Part IV).", "Additional Information Teaching Methods
Lectures and seminars.", "Method of Assessment
Midterm assignment or exam (50%, assessing learning outcomes 1-7) and final exam (50%, assessing learning outcomes 1-7)", "Literature
To be announced in the course manual.", "Additional Information Target Audience
Second-year PPE students.", "Additional Information
Please note that participation in the seminars is mandatory."]

This course’s main objective is to make students understand the importance of institutions in shaping politics and policies. After this course, students should be able to:

Explain and evaluate the way in which political institutions shape political behaviour, interaction, and discourse.
Explain how political institutions develop and change, why they often remain unchanged, and how institutional change is possible.
Explain the differences between various strands of neo-institutionalist theory in political science.
Apply various concepts and theories in the analysis of concrete cases of politics and policy-making.
Present their findings in writing and reflect on them with other students.

Drawing upon both established and recent research from within the feld of comparative politics, this course surveys the major theories and findings about the causes, consequences and conduct of political institutions. It does so by first laying out the conceptual groundwork for examining the causal links between institutions, organizations and the costs of exchange (Part I). Next, this course traces the origins of and changes in political institutions through the lenses of competing schools of thought (Part II). Finally, it systematizes the variability in the shape of political institutions in democracies (Part III) and its implications for policy (Part IV).

course_paragraphs_json:
["Course Objective
By the end of this course the students will have gained the following skills:
(A) Knowledge
1 Students have a deep(er) knowledge of the main International Relations theories and approaches.
2 Students have knowledge of the relevant topics and issues in the field of International Relations
(B) Application
3 Students can apply the more abstract theories and approaches to contemporary issues and case studies of global politics
4 Students will be able to critically assess situations where rival theories may present complementary explanations
5 Students can work in a group on such a contemporary case study, collect relevant additional literature and data, and discuss and present the findings
(C) Judgement
6 Students can individually write a theoretical essay on a topic related to the content of issues covered in this course.", "Course Content
Building on 'Political Science: State, Power and Conflict' from year 1, this course offers a comprehensive overview of the discipline and subject of International Relations (IR) and its main concepts, issues and theories and approaches. The course is guided by the question of to what extent, and how, the current process of globalization is changing the nature and content of global politics, approaching this question from the various competing theoretical perspectives IR has to offer. Traditionally, the object of study for IR has been the conflict between and cooperation of sovereign states. This model is, however, increasingly regarded as outdated inasmuch as more and more non-state actors such as multinationals, NGOs, and transnational social movements appear to play a prominent role in world politics. In addition, we can also observe transnational forms of regulation through international organizations and the emerging structures of what is called ‘global governance’. The question has been raised whether in the face of these processes of globalization and transnationalization, states have lost the sovereignty that used to be the basis of the international system. Yet, there are still many instances where state power is very visible. Recent geopolitical developments and events related to, for instance, the rise of China have also once more brought home the message that classical themes of interstate rivalry and international security have not lost their relevance in this new era. In this course the focus will be on seeking to understand these broader questions through various theoretical lenses, as well as to address contemporary issues within global politics such as postcolonialism, international law, and the UN. Alongside the lecture series, students will work in groups in the seminars on contemporary case-studies, learning to apply relatively abstract theories and concepts to concrete questions. In addition, students will be writing a short assignment on a pertinent question related to global politics.", "Additional Information Teaching Methods
Lectures and seminars (active learning groups).", "Method of Assessment
Written exam (60%) - Corresponds with learning objectives 1, 2, 3 and 4
Paper (40%) - Corresponds with learning objectives 1, 3, 4 and 6
Electoral observation (pass/fail) - Corresponds with learning objectives 3, 4 and 5", "Literature
Baylis, J. S. Smith and P. Owens (eds.) (2023), The Globalization of World Politics: An Introduction to International Relations, 9th Edition, Oxford UP
Selection of journal articles and/or book chapters, which will be announced on Canvas.", "Additional Information Target Audience
Second year PPE students", "Additional Information
Please note that participation in the seminars is mandatory.", "Recommended background knowledge
PPE course Political Science: State, Power and Conflict; mandatory courses PPE specialisation track 3: Political Science."]

4 Students will be able to critically assess situations where rival theories may present complementary explanations

The course is guided by the question of to what extent, and how, the current process of globalization is changing the nature and content of global politics, approaching this question from the various competing theoretical perspectives IR has to offer. Traditionally, the object of study for IR has been the conflict between and cooperation of sovereign states. This model is, however, increasingly regarded as outdated inasmuch as more and more non-state actors such as multinationals, NGOs, and transnational social movements appear to play a prominent role in world politics. In addition, we can also observe transnational forms of regulation through international organizations and the emerging structures of what is called ‘global governance’. The question has been raised whether in the face of these processes of globalization and transnationalization, states have lost the sovereignty that used to be the basis of the international system. Yet, there are still many instances where state power is very visible. Recent geopolitical developments and events related to, for instance, the rise of China have also once more brought home the message that classical themes of interstate rivalry and international security have not lost their relevance in this new era. In this course the focus will be on seeking to understand these broader questions through various theoretical lenses, as well as to address contemporary issues within global politics such as postcolonialism, international law, and the UN. course_paragraphs_json:
["Course Objective
This course’s overarching objectives are to make students understand major topics of international security and to enable them to apply key concepts and approaches and to critically reflect upon debates and research in international security.
After this course, students have acquired knowledge and understanding of:
(1) Key issues and challenges to international security.
(2) Key practices of the international community in addressing challenges to international security, including peacekeeping and the United Nations system of collective security and legitimizing the use of armed force.
(3) Core concepts and debates in the social scientific study of international security, including the security dilemma, the democratic peace phenomenon, and the changing nature of warfare.
Application: Students have further acquired the competences to:
(4) Apply key concepts and approaches of international security to the empirical study of current and historical cases.
Making judgements: Through the completion of this course, students are enabled to:
(5) Critically reflect upon research results and relating those results to theoretical debates within international security.", "Course Content
International Security issues have remained at the forefront of academic and policy debates since the inception of International Relations (IR) as a distinct discipline. This course introduces students to some of the major debates and current topics in international security. Throughout, the course familiarizes students with key concepts and theoretical frameworks of international security, while also investigating empirical cases and devoting space to bring in guest lecturers.", "Additional Information Teaching Methods
Lectures and seminars", "Method of Assessment
The course grade will be based on the results of two assignments, each of which amounts to 50% of the final grade (assessing learning outcomes 1-5). The first is an individual assignment and the second is a group assignment.", "Additional Information Target Audience
Second year PPE students"]

course_name: The European Union: Institutions, Politics and Policy
course_paragraphs_json:
["Course Objective
After this course, students should be able to:
Describe the most important evolutions concerning the history of European integration, of the institutional structure of the European Union, and of key selected issues.
Explain how the European Union affects domestic politics as well as what its role is in international relations in a number of selected issues.
Apply key approaches to European integration and concepts to an understanding of the history and a selection of contemporary themes and policies of European Union politics.
Identify and analyse key contemporary themes of European politics.
Present their findings in writing and reflect on them with other students.", "Course Content
The European Union has a large influence on political decision-making and policy-making inits member states. A good understanding of the operations of the EU, as well as of the dynamics through which it develops, is therefore essential to assess the way it affects contemporary politics and policy. This course introduces students to the way the EU operates, its institutional architecture, its history, and its modes of decision-making. The course highlights how EU decision-making affects domestic politics as well as how it is situated in a broader, international context.
Besides paying attention to the main characteristics of EU decision-making, the course familiarizes students with key theories of European integration (more intergovernmental versus more supranational approaches) and with alternative theories (e.g. social constructivist approaches). These insights are applied to selected policy domains that touch both upon the EU’s internal politics (e.g. economic and monetary policy) as well as upon its engagement in the global realm (e.g. trade, migration, security).", "Additional Information Teaching Methods
Lectures and seminars (active learning groups). Please note that participation in the seminars is mandatory.", "Method of Assessment
Midterm short research paper (30% assessing learning outcomes 1 -5), written final exam (70% assessing learning outcomes 1-5).", "Literature
Cini, M. and N. Pérez-Solórzano Borragán (eds.) (2022), European Union Politics, 7th edition, Oxford UP
Selection of journal articles and/or book chapters listed on Canvas", "Additional Information Target Audience
Second year PPE students", "Additional Information
Please note that participation in the seminars is mandatory.", "Recommended background knowledge
Mandatory courses PPE specialization Track 2: Political Science"]
course_objective:
After this course, students should be able to:
Describe the most important evolutions concerning the history of European integration, of the institutional structure of the European Union, and of key selected issues.
Explain how the European Union affects domestic politics as well as what its role is in international relations in a number of selected issues.
Apply key approaches to European integration and concepts to an understanding of the history and a selection of contemporary themes and policies of European Union politics.
Identify and analyse key contemporary themes of European politics.
Present their findings in writing and reflect on them with other students.
course_content:
The European Union has a large influence on political decision-making and policy-making inits member states. A good understanding of the operations of the EU, as well as of the dynamics through which it develops, is therefore essential to assess the way it affects contemporary politics and policy. This course introduces students to the way the EU operates, its institutional architecture, its history, and its modes of decision-making. The course highlights how EU decision-making affects domestic politics as well as how it is situated in a broader, international context.
Besides paying attention to the main characteristics of EU decision-making, the course familiarizes students with key theories of European integration (more intergovernmental versus more supranational approaches) and with alternative theories (e.g. social constructivist approaches). These insights are applied to selected policy domains that touch both upon the EU’s internal politics (e.g. economic and monetary policy) as well as upon its engagement in the global realm (e.g. trade, migration, security).
additional_information_teaching_methods: Lectures and seminars (active learning groups). Please note that participation in the seminars is mandatory.

course_paragraphs_json:
["Course Objective
After completion of the course, the student is able to apply theories on political communication and journalism:
To critically analyse and give feedback on research literature about the news and political information impact on citizens’ attitudes and behaviour;
To assess theoretical and empirical alternatives of how political information influences public opinion;
To evaluate their own work and the work by others on the real-world impact of political information and news in the digital age;
To argue and contribute to a discussion on the impact of news in the digital age on citizenship knowledge, skills and attitudes.
To orally present and discuss choices made by politicians, journalists, and citizens in terms of democratic citizenship.", "Course Content
In almost no political systems do citizens have direct contact with their political representatives. One could say – and scholars of political communication have done so – that politicians operate in a highly mediatized environment, where media are citizens’ principal source of political information. The field of political communication investigates how politics is portrayed in media (i.e. by journalists), and subsequently, how citizens process and use that information about politics. For example a significant area of research in the political communication field, looks at which political issues are on the media agenda, how they are transferred to the public agenda and how does that influence people’s vote choice. Another significant focus I on which part of certain political argumenta are made salient by the journalist (i.e. how is an issue framed in a news article), and how does that enhance or hinder political knowledge?
Political Communication is a vast academic field, and one period is not enough time to give even a tacit introduction to all the content and issues within its purview. In this course, we therefore focus on news impacts – that is, how news is made, and what its effects are on public opinion and behaviour. The readings are a capita selecta. Many other articles could have been chosen. Because Political Communication is an inherently diverse and interdisciplinary field, this is reflected in the readings. Overall, this course helps students to find answers to political communication questions with a combined theoretical and practical approach. Theoretically, students will study classic and recent literature on political communication.
During the lectures we spend time to contextualize the readings assigned for each topic, as well as discuss the societal and pragmatic implications. During the tutorials, students work in groups on their weekly challenges and assignments. These activities aim to train students to communicate core concepts in political communication to various audiences and device convincing arguments to make complex political ideas through the public. Among the challenges that politics faces, there is how to get citizens engaged and involved in democracy. Communication is one of the tools that political communicators experts and advisors use to enhance citizens involvement in politics. The course challenges and assignments aim to make students to acquire and improve their communication skills applied to the political process.
Given that this is a political communication course, students are expected to follow news on politics closely during this period. As we will see in this course, path to news and political information are certainly varied so you have plenty of options to choose from. In any case, make sure that you keep up with current events by reading newspapers (paper version or online), watch national or international television news shows, listen to news analyses on the radio, podcasts or on social media.", "Additional Information Teaching Methods
Literature Lectures - Monday and Tuesday - The theoretical understanding of each week’s topic is central during the lectures. To enhance students’ theoretical understanding, they will give a presentation in groups to introduce one of the papers assigned that week. Groups who are not presenting on that lecture, hand in one discussion question (one question per group not presenting). The lecture will include a workshop dynamic in the second part of the class in which the presentation of the reading will take place. The theoretical investigation, as stated in Learning Objectives #1 and #2, is central in the remainder of the lecture. During the lecture, we try to identify what parts of the theory are relevant to understand causes, consequences or mechanisms identified underlying political communication processes. Moreover, we will work toward identifying what parts of the current state of the field could be improved, based on the reading questions you prepared. Based on our theoretical investigation, students work on a weekly challenge – for more information, see Section 5.
Working Groups - Thursday and Friday- During the Working Groups, we pay attention to the empirical implications of the theories under study that week.
The students will work on teams:
To prepare a Group Debate around a topical issue on political communication with substantial societal impact; (Learning Objective #5).
To prepare Two Weekly Challenges to increase citizenship knowledge on the concepts of course literature and tie those concepts to a real-world event (Learning Objective #3 and #4).
To prepare One individual Assignment to analyse the role of social media algorithms in mediating your news media diets (Learning Objective #3 and #4).
During the tutorial, students get time and support to develop the material for the assignments and the debate preparation. Students will also receive peer-feedback on their assignments during the Working Groups and implement that feedback in their final submissions (Learning Objective #3).", "Method of Assessment
The final grade exist of (1) Portfolio of Assignments; and (2) the Oral Exam. Each element makes up 50% of the final grade. The Portfolio of Assignments consists of three parts:
(a) Two Weekly Challenges
(b) The Group Debate
(c) Group Preparation and Presentation of the assigned readings and questions to other groups
There is no compensation possible between the portfolio of assignments and the oral exam. That is, both have to be sufficient, i.e., higher than a 5.5. If a student has an insufficient grade for either the portfolio of assignments or the oral exam, the student takes a resit of the entire course by doing an individual assignment – this will be made available to Canvas. What is possible, however, is to compensate within the portfolio of assignments.", "Literature
A selection of scientific papers included on Canvas and chapters of the books below will be part of the mandatory literature:
Perloff, R. M. (2020). The dynamics of news: Journalism in the 21st-century media milieu. Routledge. Chapters, 2, 3 and 4.
Klinger, U., Kreiss, D., & Mutsvairo, B. (2023). Platforms, power, and politics: An introduction to political communication in the digital age. John Wiley & Sons. Chapters 1 and 2.
Wolfsfeld, G. (2022). Making sense of media and politics: Five principles in political communication. Taylor & Francis. Chapter 3, 4
Bruns, A. (2019). Are filter bubbles real?. John Wiley & Sons. Chapter 2, 3", "Additional Information Target Audience
Second year PPE students", "Additional Information
An active academic participation is expected, which means that you are prepared for every meeting, participate actively and positively in class. This includes both class discussions and informal in-class assignments, including writing tasks.
Participation is mandatory in all meetings.", "Recommended background knowledge
Mandatory courses PPE specialization Track 3: Political Science"]
course_content:
In almost no political systems do citizens have direct contact with their political representatives. One could say – and scholars of political communication have done so – that politicians operate in a highly mediatized environment, where media are citizens’ principal source of political information. The field of political communication investigates how politics is portrayed in media (i.e. by journalists), and subsequently, how citizens process and use that information about politics. For example a significant area of research in the political communication field, looks at which political issues are on the media agenda, how they are transferred to the public agenda and how does that influence people’s vote choice. Another significant focus I on which part of certain political argumenta are made salient by the journalist (i.e. how is an issue framed in a news article), and how does that enhance or hinder political knowledge?
Political Communication is a vast academic field, and one period is not enough time to give even a tacit introduction to all the content and issues within its purview. In this course, we therefore focus on news impacts – that is, how news is made, and what its effects are on public opinion and behaviour. The readings are a capita selecta. Many other articles could have been chosen. Because Political Communication is an inherently diverse and interdisciplinary field, this is reflected in the readings. Overall, this course helps students to find answers to political communication questions with a combined theoretical and practical approach. Theoretically, students will study classic and recent literature on political communication.
During the lectures we spend time to contextualize the readings assigned for each topic, as well as discuss the societal and pragmatic implications. During the tutorials, students work in groups on their weekly challenges and assignments. These activities aim to train students to communicate core concepts in political communication to various audiences and device convincing arguments to make complex political ideas through the public. Among the challenges that politics faces, there is how to get citizens engaged and involved in democracy. Communication is one of the tools that political communicators experts and advisors use to enhance citizens involvement in politics. The course challenges and assignments aim to make students to acquire and improve their communication skills applied to the political process.
Given that this is a political communication course, students are expected to follow news on politics closely during this period. As we will see in this course, path to news and political information are certainly varied so you have plenty of options to choose from. In any case, make sure that you keep up with current events by reading newspapers (paper version or online), watch national or international television news shows, listen to news analyses on the radio, podcasts or on social media.
additional_information_teaching_methods:
Literature Lectures - Monday and Tuesday - The theoretical understanding of each week’s topic is central during the lectures. To enhance students’ theoretical understanding, they will give a presentation in groups to introduce one of the papers assigned that week. Groups who are not presenting on that lecture, hand in one discussion question (one question per group not presenting). The lecture will include a workshop dynamic in the second part of the class in which the presentation of the reading will take place. The theoretical investigation, as stated in Learning Objectives #1 and #2, is central in the remainder of the lecture. During the lecture, we try to identify what parts of the theory are relevant to understand causes, consequences or mechanisms identified underlying political communication processes. Moreover, we will work toward identifying what parts of the current state of the field could be improved, based on the reading questions you prepared. Based on our theoretical investigation, students work on a weekly challenge – for more information, see Section 5.
Working Groups - Thursday and Friday- During the Working Groups, we pay attention to the empirical implications of the theories under study that week.
The students will work on teams:
To prepare a Group Debate around a topical issue on political communication with substantial societal impact; (Learning Objective #5).
To prepare Two Weekly Challenges to increase citizenship knowledge on the concepts of course literature and tie those concepts to a real-world event (Learning Objective #3 and #4).
To prepare One individual Assignment to analyse the role of social media algorithms in mediating your news media diets (Learning Objective #3 and #4).
During the tutorial, students get time and support to develop the material for the assignments and the debate preparation. Students will also receive peer-feedback on their assignments during the Working Groups and implement that feedback in their final submissions (Learning Objective #3).
method_of_assessment:
The final grade exist of (1) Portfolio of Assignments; and (2) the Oral Exam. Each element makes up 50% of the final grade. The Portfolio of Assignments consists of three parts:
(a) Two Weekly Challenges
(b) The Group Debate
(c) Group Preparation and Presentation of the assigned readings and questions to other groups
There is no compensation possible between the portfolio of assignments and the oral exam. That is, both have to be sufficient, i.e., higher than a 5.5. If a student has an insufficient grade for either the portfolio of assignments or the oral exam, the student takes a resit of the entire course by doing an individual assignment – this will be made available to Canvas. What is possible, however, is to compensate within the portfolio of assignments.
literature:
A selection of scientific papers included on Canvas and chapters of the books below will be part of the mandatory literature:
Perloff, R. M. (2020). The dynamics of news: Journalism in the 21st-century media milieu. Routledge. Chapters, 2, 3 and 4.
Klinger, U., Kreiss, D., & Mutsvairo, B. (2023). Platforms, power, and politics: An introduction to political communication in the digital age. John Wiley & Sons. Chapters 1 and 2.
Wolfsfeld, G. (2022). Making sense of media and politics: Five principles in political communication. Taylor & Francis. Chapter 3, 4
Bruns, A. (2019). Are filter bubbles real?. John Wiley & Sons. Chapter 2, 3

course_paragraphs_json:
["Course Objective
Acquire knowledge of and insight into the contemporary global political economy, in particular how the contradictory process of globalization reshapes the relationship between states and markets;
Acquire an understanding of rival concepts and theories within International Political Economy and their application to issues in contemporary global political economy;
Conduct research on a chosen issue in International Political Economy and present the findings in academic writing (paper).", "Course Content
This course offers students an introduction to the subject of International Political Economy (IPE). Throughout, the course will be guided by the question of to what extent, and how, the current process of globalization is changing the relationship between states and markets, between public regulation and the private economy, between state and capital. Traditionally, IPE studies the relationship between ‘the economic’ and ‘the political’ within the interaction (patterns of cooperation and conflict) between nation states. While the global financial and economic crisis of 2008 and beyond alrady made clear that this state-centric perspective is no longer adequate, the recent Corona pandemic and susbequent global health, economic and social crisis has made that even more plane to see for all citizens of the world. At the same time, both crises have also shown that states, although apparently vulnerable in the face of global forces (whether market forces or an unknown virus), are also crucial when it comes to protecting the workings of global capitalism, and save not just jobs (and lives) but also 'the market', and the continuation of private capital accumulation. This shows that indeed the relationship between states and markets is not a one-way street. In other words, politics and policies are shaped by the interests and activities of transnational (market) actors and by economic globalization but the latter is also driven by politics, and shaped (indeed enabled) by the policy choices that states make. It is from this perspective that this course will examine the various approaches within IPE such as liberalism, mercantilism and structuralism; the (de-)globalization of production and the role of transnational corporations; the international monetary system and the globalization of finance; the global financial crisis and the eurozone crisis; the political economy of development; the rise of China and other emerging powers, and the political economy of global health, and of energy and the environment.", "Additional Information Teaching Methods
Lectures and seminars", "Method of Assessment
Written exam (75%, assessing learning outcomes 1-2) and written assignment (25%, assessing learning outcome 3).
seminar assignments (pass/fail).", "Literature
David N. Balaam & Bradford Dillman, Introduction to International Political Economy, Latest Edition. ISBN: 9781138206991.
Online articles and other readings (provided via Canvas).", "Additional Information Target Audience
Second-year PPE students", "Additional Information
Please note that participation in the seminars is mandatory.", "Recommended background knowledge
Mandatory courses PPE specialization track Political Science"]

Traditionally, IPE studies the relationship between ‘the economic’ and ‘the political’ within the interaction (patterns of cooperation and conflict) between nation states. While the global financial and economic crisis of 2008 and beyond alrady made clear that this state-centric perspective is no longer adequate, the recent Corona pandemic and susbequent global health, economic and social crisis has made that even more plane to see for all citizens of the world. At the same time, both crises have also shown that states, although apparently vulnerable in the face of global forces (whether market forces or an unknown virus), are also crucial when it comes to protecting the workings of global capitalism, and save not just jobs (and lives) but also 'the market', and the continuation of private capital accumulation. This shows that indeed the relationship between states and markets is not a one-way street. In other words, politics and policies are shaped by the interests and activities of transnational (market) actors and by economic globalization but the latter is also driven by politics, and shaped (indeed enabled) by the policy choices that states make. It is from this perspective that this course will examine the various approaches within IPE such as liberalism, mercantilism and structuralism; the (de-)globalization of production and the role of transnational corporations; the international monetary system and the globalization of finance; the global financial crisis and the eurozone crisis; the political economy of development; the rise of China and other emerging powers, and the political economy of global health, and of energy and the environment.

course_paragraphs_json:
["Course Objective
This course provides a solid understanding of microeconomic theory and introduces modern econometric techniques that enable students to perform data analysis aimed at microeconomic policy evaluation.
Specific learning outcomes upon completion of this curricular item are:
acquiring basic knowledge on the impact of risk and uncertainty on individual decision making
mastering intermediate game theory techniques to analyze strategic interactions
understanding the importance of (asymmetric) information on economic transactions
recognizing how the existence of externalities may distort the allocation of resources
mastering the use of economic models to understand labour markets
being able to evaluate public policy aimed at correcting market failures
being able to critically assess the ability of econometric techniques to estimate causal impacts of public policies
apply basic econometric techniques to real-world data using R", "Course Content
This course concentrates on the interaction between microeconomic theory, real-world events and empirical data.
The first part of the course (weeks 1-4) covers microeconomic theory including risk and expected utility theory, the economics of information, game theory, principal-agent models, moral hazard and adverse selection, externalities, and labor markets. The goal is to get acquainted with setting up appropriate models to analyze market outcomes under various assumptions. The role of government policies to deal with market failure is discussed throughout.
The second part of the course (weeks 5-6) introduces different econometric techniques related to estimating causal impacts of economic policies. We will discuss randomized field experiments, linear regression models, instrumental variables estimation and the difference-in-differences model. All techniques will be applied to real-world data sets, using R. The main focus will be on correctly interpreting estimation results and distinguishing between correlation and causality. Applications may include: the returns to schooling, the effect of public health insurance, fertility and labor supply, and the impact of raising the alcohol purchasing age on road accidents.", "Additional Information Teaching Methods
Lectures and seminars", "Method of Assessment
Written midterm (50%, assessment of learning objectives 1,2,3,4).
Final exam (50%, assessment of learning objectives 5,6,7,8)

course_objective:
This course provides a solid understanding of microeconomic theory and introduces modern econometric techniques that enable students to perform data analysis aimed at microeconomic policy evaluation.
Specific learning outcomes upon completion of this curricular item are:
acquiring basic knowledge on the impact of risk and uncertainty on individual decision making
mastering intermediate game theory techniques to analyze strategic interactions
understanding the importance of (asymmetric) information on economic transactions
recognizing how the existence of externalities may distort the allocation of resources
mastering the use of economic models to understand labour markets
being able to evaluate public policy aimed at correcting market failures
being able to critically assess the ability of econometric techniques to estimate causal impacts of public policies
apply basic econometric techniques to real-world data using R
course_content:
This course concentrates on the interaction between microeconomic theory, real-world events and empirical data.
The first part of the course (weeks 1-4) covers microeconomic theory including risk and expected utility theory, the economics of information, game theory, principal-agent models, moral hazard and adverse selection, externalities, and labor markets. The goal is to get acquainted with setting up appropriate models to analyze market outcomes under various assumptions. The role of government policies to deal with market failure is discussed throughout.
The second part of the course (weeks 5-6) introduces different econometric techniques related to estimating causal impacts of economic policies. We will discuss randomized field experiments, linear regression models, instrumental variables estimation and the difference-in-differences model. All techniques will be applied to real-world data sets, using R. The main focus will be on correctly interpreting estimation results and distinguishing between correlation and causality. Applications may include: the returns to schooling, the effect of public health insurance, fertility and labor supply, and the impact of raising the alcohol purchasing age on road accidents.
additional_information_teaching_methods: Lectures and seminars
method_of_assessment:
Written midterm (50%, assessment of learning objectives 1,2,3,4).
Final exam (50%, assessment of learning objectives 5,6,7,8)
Seminar attendance/participation (pass/fail).
literature:
Snyder, C. and W. Nicholson (2017), Microeconomic theory: Basic principles and extensions, 12th edition, Cengage Learning
Angrist, J. and Pischke, J-S. (2015), Mastering Metrics: The Path from Cause to Effect, Princeton University Press
additional_information_target_audience: Second year PPE students

course_paragraphs_json:
["Course Objective
Evaluation of Macroeconomic Research & Economic Policies (1)
After successfully completing this course:
You can identify the main findings of economic research papers and evaluate their quality and usefulness for policy advice.
You can effectively use findings from economic research to assess the impacts of macroeconomic policy on short-and long-run economic developments.
You can effectively use findings from economic research to advocate for or against a specific reform of macroeconomic policy.
Self-Reflection (2)
After successfully completing this course, you can reflect on the extent to which your existing knowledge and understanding enables you to evaluate specific macroeconomic policies.
Knowledge & Understanding of Empirical Macroeconomics (3)
After successfully completing this course, you can demonstrate your knowledge and understanding of concepts related to the identification of causal effects in empirical macroeconomic research by discussing and evaluating the identification strategy used in macroeconomic research papers.
Knowledge & Understanding of Macroeconomic Policy Institutions (4)
After successfully completing this course, you can demonstrate your knowledge and understanding of the institutions of European fiscal and monetary governance.
Knowledge & Understanding of Macroeconomic Theory (5)
After successfully completing this course:
You can demonstrate your knowledge and understanding of theoretical arguments concerning economic policies (based on theories and models you have encountered before, e.g. IS-LM and the Solow model, but in particular the more advanced dynamic theories and models examined in this course) by integrating them into short essays and policy papers.
You can formally analyze the implications of varying the assumptions of simplified dynamic macroeconomic models.", "Course Content
We live in uncertain times. The European economies had barely recovered from the effects of the financial and sovereign debt crises of a decade and a half ago when they got hit by the Covid-19 pandemic. Going forward, countries face macroeconomic policy challenges related to the climate transition, the recent inflation spike and geopolitical instability. What can be learned from earlier experiences, from cross-country variation in policy response, and from the theoretical and empirical literature on fiscal and monetary policy to guide decision makers? Is further fiscal stimulus needed or wanted going forward? Are current levels of government debt too high to ask for more public investment? How can Central Banks balance their responsibility for price stability and financial stability? What policy makers believe are the answer to these questions will shape their response to the current economic crisis and recovery.
You will put yourself in the shoes of a policy consultant who has been asked to advise European policymakers on their monetary or fiscal policy. You will start by providing advice based on your current knowledge and understanding of macroeconomics gained in previous courses. You will reflect on how far this takes you in providing satisfactory advice, and which issues you need to understand better. You will then dig more deeply into the existing empirical and theoretical research by macroeconomists relevant for these issues, reflect on how convincing this research is, and use the findings from this research to develop more satisfactory advice.", "Additional Information Teaching Methods
Lectures (4 hours per week), seminars (4 hours per week, attendance
required).", "Method of Assessment
Midterm Exam (40%) (1,3,5)
Final Exam (40%) (1,3,4,5)
Team Policy Brief (20%) (1,2,3)
Seminar assignments (pass/fail) (3,4,5)
Preparation for Roundtable presentation and discussion. (1,2,3,4,5)", "Literature
We provide extensive notes and videos and assign additional readings from newspapers and magazines, blogs, and academic journals. We use an online textbook, Garín, Lester, and Sims, 2020, ‘Intermediate Macroeconomics’, available on Canvas. Whenever we need to apply traditional macroeconomic models (IS-LM), students can refer to the textbook from Development of Macroeconomic Thought: McDowell, Thom, Pastine, Frank, Bernanke (2012) Principles of Economics ,3rd European Edition, McGraw Hill.", "Additional Information Target Audience
Second year PPE students.", "Additional Information
Please note that participation in the seminars is mandatory.", "Recommended background knowledge
Mandatory courses PPE specialization Track 2: Economics"]

We live in uncertain times. The European economies had barely recovered from the effects of the financial and sovereign debt crises of a decade and a half ago when they got hit by the Covid-19 pandemic. Going forward, countries face macroeconomic policy challenges related to the climate transition, the recent inflation spike and geopolitical instability. What can be learned from earlier experiences, from cross-country variation in policy response, and from the theoretical and empirical literature on fiscal and monetary policy to guide decision makers? Is further fiscal stimulus needed or wanted going forward? Are current levels of government debt too high to ask for more public investment? How can Central Banks balance their responsibility for price stability and financial stability? What policy makers believe are the answer to these questions will shape their response to the current economic crisis and recovery.
You will put yourself in the shoes of a policy consultant who has been asked to advise European policymakers on their monetary or fiscal policy.
