course_paragraphs_json:
["Course Objective
Specific learning outcomes upon completion of this curricular item are
Students will gain a solid understanding of the main concepts and theories of global income distribution, international trade and economic development.
Students will be better able to assess empirical information and to apply theoretical models to real life cases, which will help them in developing independent and critical opinions on the contemporary debate on the interlinkages between globalisation, global inequality and economic development.", "Course Content
This course introduces students to modern approaches to the analysis of development economics and international trade. The course covers three themes: conceptualizing and tracking the evolution of economic wellbeing; the meaning of economic development and its drivers; and the role of international trade. We take as point of departure in this course that economic development refers to the process through which people, and countries, are lifted out of poverty. Accordingly, the first two weeks of the course will introduce students to the challenges of measuring and monitoring poverty and inequality in the developing country context. We will address prospects for the international community’s objective of ending global poverty by 2030. The Poverty-Inequality-Growth relationship is examined and it shown that both accelerated growth and improved distribution have a critical role to play in the quest to end poverty within the coming decades. We then move, during the next two weeks, to the analysis of the main paradigms that have been proposed to understand economic development, followed by a detailed discussion of three key dimensions, namely urbanization/migration, human capital, and agriculture. In the final two weeks, students will learn about classic as well as contemporary theories concerning international trade - a key engine of economic development. The course will ask whether and under what conditions the gains from free trade and free migration might outweigh the risks and, hence, when and under what conditions protectionism and the closing of borders might be justified.
In light of the Covid pandemic and present-day volatility in international economic and political relations, particular pattention will be paid to the consequences of these crises for both the development process and poverty decline. We shall consider, for example, how after decades of increased trade and falling poverty, up to one third of the trade volumes have been lost and over 100 million people have likely fallen into extreme poverty. Will this mark the reversal of globalization trends? Will there be a resurgence of persistent poverty? Or are recent reversals a transient phenomenon such that we will soon be back on track?", "Additional Information Teaching Methods
Lectures and seminars (active learning groups). Please note that participation in the seminars is mandatory.", "Method of Assessment
Two written assignments (10% each, learning outcome 2)
Mid-term test (20%, learning outcomes 1,2)
Final exam (60%, learning outcomes 1,2)", "Literature
The primary reading for the course is Todaro, M. and Smith, S. (2015) Economic Development 12th edition (Harlow: Pearson Education Ltd.).
Students are strongly advised to purchase this textbook (available at VU Bookstore). Additional readings, where applicable, will be supplied by the instructors.", "Additional Information Target Audience
Second year PPE students", "Additional Information
Please note that participation in the seminars is mandatory.", "Recommended background knowledge
Mandatory courses specialization Track 2: Economics"]
course_objective:
Specific learning outcomes upon completion of this curricular item are
Students will gain a solid understanding of the main concepts and theories of global income distribution, international trade and economic development.
Students will be better able to assess empirical information and to apply theoretical models to real life cases, which will help them in developing independent and critical opinions on the contemporary debate on the interlinkages between globalisation, global inequality and economic development.
course_content:
This course introduces students to modern approaches to the analysis of development economics and international trade. The course covers three themes: conceptualizing and tracking the evolution of economic wellbeing; the meaning of economic development and its drivers; and the role of international trade. We take as point of departure in this course that economic development refers to the process through which people, and countries, are lifted out of poverty. Accordingly, the first two weeks of the course will introduce students to the challenges of measuring and monitoring poverty and inequality in the developing country context. We will address prospects for the international community’s objective of ending global poverty by 2030. The Poverty-Inequality-Growth relationship is examined and it shown that both accelerated growth and improved distribution have a critical role to play in the quest to end poverty within the coming decades. We then move, during the next two weeks, to the analysis of the main paradigms that have been proposed to understand economic development, followed by a detailed discussion of three key dimensions, namely urbanization/migration, human capital, and agriculture. In the final two weeks, students will learn about classic as well as contemporary theories concerning international trade - a key engine of economic development. The course will ask whether and under what conditions the gains from free trade and free migration might outweigh the risks and, hence, when and under what conditions protectionism and the closing of borders might be justified.
In light of the Covid pandemic and present-day volatility in international economic and political relations, particular pattention will be paid to the consequences of these crises for both the development process and poverty decline. We shall consider, for example, how after decades of increased trade and falling poverty, up to one third of the trade volumes have been lost and over 100 million people have likely fallen into extreme poverty. Will this mark the reversal of globalization trends? Will there be a resurgence of persistent poverty? Or are recent reversals a transient phenomenon such that we will soon be back on track?
additional_information_teaching_methods: Lectures and seminars (active learning groups). Please note that participation in the seminars is mandatory.
method_of_assessment:
Two written assignments (10% each, learning outcome 2)
Mid-term test (20%, learning outcomes 1,2)
Final exam (60%, learning outcomes 1,2)
literature:
The primary reading for the course is Todaro, M. and Smith, S. (2015) Economic Development 12th edition (Harlow: Pearson Education Ltd.).
Students are strongly advised to purchase this textbook (available at VU Bookstore). Additional readings, where applicable, will be supplied by the instructors.
additional_information_target_audience: Second year PPE students
recommended_background_knowledge: Mandatory courses specialization Track 2: Economics

course_paragraphs_json:
["Course Objective
Public economics studies the role of government in a market economy, much from a microeconomic and structural perspective. The objective of this course is to identify, justify, analyze and evaluate policy options. This includes selecting suitable policy instruments, such as taxation, subsidization, regulation or nudges, and to understand their intended and unintended consequences at a conceptual and analytical level. Using problem sets, insightful computer-aided exercises, along with policy-focused class discussions, and embedding in empirical context, this course will increase and deepen your understanding the role of government and the scope and limitations of economic policy.
LEARNING OBJECTIVES
Upon completion of the course:
Students understand theoretical underpinnings, mechanisms, and functioning of policy tools in public economics, and they appreciate empirical dimensions of government involvement and policy.
Students possess the relevant skills and master the choice and use of modeling tools to address important public economics questions in stylized cases and real-life applications.
Students are able to positively assess and normatively evaluate efficacy, effectiveness, equity, and efficiency of alternative economic policy measures in light of set objectives and relative to desirable social goals.", "Course Content
Public economics studies the role of government in a market economy. A public finance perspective provides the main organizing principle: what are government tasks, what expenditures do they require, and what is a good way of financing them?
This course covers an array of topics central to economic policy making, and will discuss underlying economic theory, but also embed it in the context of empirical research.
Classic topics include the correction of market failure in the presence of national public goods (judicial system or national defense) and global public goods (climate change), as well as distributional goals with which welfare state institutions are concerned. Associated expenditures are mainly financed through taxation.
We discuss welfare implications of taxation of incomes, consumption, or wealth, implied by adverse incentive effects on economic behavior. The central trade-off in public finance is that between the dual goals of efficiency and equity. Government policy is at most second-best relative to the goal overall maximization of social welfare. The course will occasionally touch upon behavioral public finance aspects that point to limitations of and challenges for economic policy when citizens are boundedly rational and do not react as desired to public interventions; the government may have a role as choice architect.
Problems triggered by asymmetric information constitute another central aspect of modern public finance, and accordingly tools will be applied to issues in social insurance design. We also emphasize important aspects that limit tax revenue generation in practice: tax evasion by individuals, tax avoidance by multinational firms and tax competition between jurisdictions.
The course emphasizes applications of economic modeling. We use tailor-made applications with computer-based tools (Desmos) to this end. Both theoretical and empirical economic work in policy context will be discussed.", "Additional Information Teaching Methods
2 lectures per week; 2 seminars per week.", "Method of Assessment
Midterm (40%) and final exam (60%) – both with individual assessment of learning objectives 1., 2., and 3.; seminar assignments (pass/fail); we offer students the possibility of earning a grade-enhancing “bonus point” through significant active participation efforts (presentations, discussions, case studies, data work).", "Literature
Hindriks, J. and G. D. Myles (2013), Intermediate Public Economics, 2nd edition, MIT Press. Additional reading will be announced on Canvas or in the course guide.", "Additional Information Target Audience
Second year PPE students.", "Additional Information
The course may have important intersections with an array of economics courses in, for instance, microeconomics, development economics, environmental economics, labor economics, and industrial organization.", "Recommended background knowledge
Mandatory courses PPE specialization Track 2: Economics"]
course_objective:
Public economics studies the role of government in a market economy, much from a microeconomic and structural perspective. The objective of this course is to identify, justify, analyze and evaluate policy options. This includes selecting suitable policy instruments, such as taxation, subsidization, regulation or nudges, and to understand their intended and unintended consequences at a conceptual and analytical level. Using problem sets, insightful computer-aided exercises, along with policy-focused class discussions, and embedding in empirical context, this course will increase and deepen your understanding the role of government and the scope and limitations of economic policy.
LEARNING OBJECTIVES
Upon completion of the course:
Students understand theoretical underpinnings, mechanisms, and functioning of policy tools in public economics, and they appreciate empirical dimensions of government involvement and policy.
Students possess the relevant skills and master the choice and use of modeling tools to address important public economics questions in stylized cases and real-life applications.
Students are able to positively assess and normatively evaluate efficacy, effectiveness, equity, and efficiency of alternative economic policy measures in light of set objectives and relative to desirable social goals.
course_content:
Public economics studies the role of government in a market economy. A public finance perspective provides the main organizing principle: what are government tasks, what expenditures do they require, and what is a good way of financing them?
This course covers an array of topics central to economic policy making, and will discuss underlying economic theory, but also embed it in the context of empirical research.
Classic topics include the correction of market failure in the presence of national public goods (judicial system or national defense) and global public goods (climate change), as well as distributional goals with which welfare state institutions are concerned. Associated expenditures are mainly financed through taxation.
We discuss welfare implications of taxation of incomes, consumption, or wealth, implied by adverse incentive effects on economic behavior. The central trade-off in public finance is that between the dual goals of efficiency and equity. Government policy is at most second-best relative to the goal overall maximization of social welfare. The course will occasionally touch upon behavioral public finance aspects that point to limitations of and challenges for economic policy when citizens are boundedly rational and do not react as desired to public interventions; the government may have a role as choice architect.
Problems triggered by asymmetric information constitute another central aspect of modern public finance, and accordingly tools will be applied to issues in social insurance design. We also emphasize important aspects that limit tax revenue generation in practice: tax evasion by individuals, tax avoidance by multinational firms and tax competition between jurisdictions.
The course emphasizes applications of economic modeling. We use tailor-made applications with computer-based tools (Desmos) to this end. Both theoretical and empirical economic work in policy context will be discussed.
additional_information_teaching_methods: 2 lectures per week; 2 seminars per week.
method_of_assessment: Midterm (40%) and final exam (60%) – both with individual assessment of learning objectives 1., 2., and 3.; seminar assignments (pass/fail); we offer students the possibility of earning a grade-enhancing “bonus point” through significant active participation efforts (presentations, discussions, case studies, data work).
literature: Hindriks, J. and G. D. Myles (2013), Intermediate Public Economics, 2nd edition, MIT Press. Additional reading will be announced on Canvas or in the course guide.
additional_information_target_audience: Second year PPE students.
recommended_background_knowledge: Mandatory courses PPE specialization Track 2: Economics

course_paragraphs_json:
["Course Objective
At the end of the course the student is able:
demonstrates knowledge how axiomatic choice models in economics can be empirically tested, what the (replicated and robust) evidence-based facts about actual choice in economics are.
demonstrates being able to perform “micro-economic analyses” of quantitative behavioral economic models.
is able to set-up and conduct elementary experiments and reflect upon their experimental setup and critically question empirical evidence.
is able to adopt a critical evidence-based attitude towards economics, both positive and normative, and to reflect upon effective behavioral economic policies.
demonstrates awareness of own personal behavioral biases and of other persons.", "Course Content
Behavioral economics is reshaping economics. Many experiments demonstrate that people behave differently than predicted by the standard rational-choice model of homo economics in textbooks. These empirical findings result from systematic biases with a physiological origin related to psychological process in the human brain. Behavioral economics recognizes this origin and explores its consequences to arrive at evidence-based economics as a positive science and evidence-based economic policy as its normative counterpart. Behavioral economics therefore has serious consequences for economic policy itself and thinking about economic policy. For instance, making automatic enrollment in pension savings the default choice option substantially increases the number of participants in US pension saving schemes. This tinkering with what is called the choice architecture is called nudging and has led for instance to the foundation of the Behavioral Insights Team (BIT), a social company that started as the world’s first government institution dedicated to the application of behavioral sciences. Cass Sunstein and Nobel-laureate 2017 Richard Thaler have advocated these policies and labelled them libertarian paternalism and view it as an alternative to laissez-faire.
In this course a selection of established behavioral economic topics will be introduced: preference reversal, loss aversion, framing, sunk cost fallacy, endowment effect, judgement of risk, gambler’s fallacy, hot-hand fallacy, Allais’ paradox, Prospect Theory, satisficing, menu dependence, mental accounting, other-regarding preferences, reciprocity, trust, limited strategic thinking, quantal response equilibrium and welfare analysis.", "Additional Information Teaching Methods
Lectures, seminars, and online experiments in which theory, exercises, policy implications, and your class’ experimental data are critically discussed.", "Method of Assessment
Participation in a series of experiments (5% final grade): Assessment of learning objective 3.
Mid-term assignment (35% final grade): It consists of a written survey on the first five seminars.
Assessment of learning objectives 1, 2, 4 and 5.
Final assignment (60% final grade):
It consists of conducting several classical experiments (15% final grade), reporting and summarizing your data (15% final grade) and reporting on your experiments (30% final grade).
Assessment of learning objectives 1, 2, 3, 4 and 5.
Attending the seminars is mandatory and in according with PPE regulations.", "Literature
Sanjit Dhami (2016) The Foundations of Behavioral Economic Analysis, Oxford University Press. ISBN: 9780198715535
Selected texts, scientific articles and supporting YouTube videos.
Textbook, articles and videos are available for free via the ubvu.vu.nl", "Additional Information Target Audience
Second year PPE students", "Explanation Canvas
Please note that participation in the seminars is mandatory", "Recommended background knowledge
Mandatory courses PPE specialization Track 3: Economics"]
course_objective:
At the end of the course the student is able:
demonstrates knowledge how axiomatic choice models in economics can be empirically tested, what the (replicated and robust) evidence-based facts about actual choice in economics are.
demonstrates being able to perform “micro-economic analyses” of quantitative behavioral economic models.
is able to set-up and conduct elementary experiments and reflect upon their experimental setup and critically question empirical evidence.
is able to adopt a critical evidence-based attitude towards economics, both positive and normative, and to reflect upon effective behavioral economic policies.
demonstrates awareness of own personal behavioral biases and of other persons.
course_content:
Behavioral economics is reshaping economics. Many experiments demonstrate that people behave differently than predicted by the standard rational-choice model of homo economics in textbooks. These empirical findings result from systematic biases with a physiological origin related to psychological process in the human brain. Behavioral economics recognizes this origin and explores its consequences to arrive at evidence-based economics as a positive science and evidence-based economic policy as its normative counterpart. Behavioral economics therefore has serious consequences for economic policy itself and thinking about economic policy. For instance, making automatic enrollment in pension savings the default choice option substantially increases the number of participants in US pension saving schemes. This tinkering with what is called the choice architecture is called nudging and has led for instance to the foundation of the Behavioral Insights Team (BIT), a social company that started as the world’s first government institution dedicated to the application of behavioral sciences. Cass Sunstein and Nobel-laureate 2017 Richard Thaler have advocated these policies and labelled them libertarian paternalism and view it as an alternative to laissez-faire.
In this course a selection of established behavioral economic topics will be introduced: preference reversal, loss aversion, framing, sunk cost fallacy, endowment effect, judgement of risk, gambler’s fallacy, hot-hand fallacy, Allais’ paradox, Prospect Theory, satisficing, menu dependence, mental accounting, other-regarding preferences, reciprocity, trust, limited strategic thinking, quantal response equilibrium and welfare analysis.
additional_information_teaching_methods: Lectures, seminars, and online experiments in which theory, exercises, policy implications, and your class’ experimental data are critically discussed.
method_of_assessment:
Participation in a series of experiments (5% final grade): Assessment of learning objective 3.
Mid-term assignment (35% final grade): It consists of a written survey on the first five seminars.
Assessment of learning objectives 1, 2, 4 and 5.
Final assignment (60% final grade):
It consists of conducting several classical experiments (15% final grade), reporting and summarizing your data (15% final grade) and reporting on your experiments (30% final grade).
Assessment of learning objectives 1, 2, 3, 4 and 5.
Attending the seminars is mandatory and in according with PPE regulations.
literature:
Sanjit Dhami (2016) The Foundations of Behavioral Economic Analysis, Oxford University Press. ISBN: 9780198715535
Selected texts, scientific articles and supporting YouTube videos.
Textbook, articles and videos are available for free via the ubvu.vu.nl
additional_information_target_audience: Second year PPE students
recommended_background_knowledge: Mandatory courses PPE specialization Track 3: Economics

course_paragraphs_json:
["Course Objective
After successfully completing the course, the student should be able
to understand what institutions are and how institutions impact the behavior of economic actors,
to think self-reflectively, including with the use of formal theoretical models, about the role of institutions in social life,
to critically and creatively develop and articulate their own view about the role of (some) institutions in social life, and
to collaboratively construct, articulate, and interrogate questions about the role of institutions in social life that they themselves find significant.", "Course Content
All economic activity takes place within a framework of institutions that constrain individual behavior and thereby affect resource allocation, income distribution, and economic growth. This course introduces recent approaches in the field of new institutional economics. The overarching theme of the course is the persistent recurrance of tragedies of the commons whenever individuals get to interact—analysing how such problems arise in various (static and dynamic) contexts and how their negative effects can be averted is the main focus of the course. In the process, we will study the development of the institutional environment, or ‘rules of the game’, that guides individual behavior. These are both formal, explicit rules (like constitutions, laws, and property rights) and informal, implicit rules (like social conventions and norms). Our focus is on the interactional emergence of institutions—a topic that falls in-between (and supplements) public-choice approaches standardly covered in a Public Economics course and individual-decision-making approaches standardly covered in a Behavioural Economics course.", "Additional Information Teaching Methods
The course uses lectures, seminars, as well as bonus practical sessions devoted to creating simulations of some of the phenomena discussed in the course.", "Method of Assessment
The final grade for the course is a weighted average of the following elements:
15%: Weekly substantive group questions (course objectives (1), (2), and (4)).
40%: Common-pool resource group assignment (course objectives (1), (3), and (4)).
45%: Final individual exam or, alternatively, a Simulation individual assignment (course objectives (2) and (3)).
A necessary condition for passing the course is (i) the attendance of at least 75% of the seminars and (ii) completing any seminar activities assigned by the seminar instructor.
A sufficient condition for passing the course is a final weighted-average grade of 6.00 (a weighted-average grade between 5.50–6.00 is rounded up to 6.00).", "Literature
Most of the formal models are discussed in Samuel Bowles. 2004. Microeconomics: Behavior, Institutions, and Evolution. Princeton University Press. Particularly, chapters 1, 2, and 4.
We will additionally read and engage with the work of Ronald Coase, Daron Acemoglu, Elinor Ostrom, recent advances in the theory of networks, stratification economics (William Darity Jr.), and critical approaches to political economy.", "Additional Information Target Audience
Second-year PPE students.", "Additional Information
Please note that, according to the standard PPE policy, participation in the seminars is compulsory.", "Explanation Canvas
All the relevant information will be provided on Canvas and students are expected to keep track of the Canvas syllabus page on a regular basis.", "Recommended background knowledge
There are no additional prerequisites beyond the standard compulsory first-year PPE courses (particularly, ‘Methods of PPE I’ and ‘Foundations of Microeconomics’). Courses in the PPE specialisation track ‘Economics’ are helpful."]

course_content: All economic activity takes place within a framework of institutions that constrain individual behavior and thereby affect resource allocation, income distribution, and economic growth. This course introduces recent approaches in the field of new institutional economics. The overarching theme of the course is the persistent recurrance of tragedies of the commons whenever individuals get to interact—analysing how such problems arise in various (static and dynamic) contexts and how their negative effects can be averted is the main focus of the course. In the process, we will study the development of the institutional environment, or ‘rules of the game’, that guides individual behavior. These are both formal, explicit rules (like constitutions, laws, and property rights) and informal, implicit rules (like social conventions and norms). Our focus is on the interactional emergence of institutions—a topic that falls in-between (and supplements) public-choice approaches standardly covered in a Public Economics course and individual-decision-making approaches standardly covered in a Behavioural Economics course.
additional_information_teaching_methods: The course uses lectures, seminars, as well as bonus practical sessions devoted to creating simulations of some of the phenomena discussed in the course.
method_of_assessment:
The final grade for the course is a weighted average of the following elements:
15%: Weekly substantive group questions (course objectives (1), (2), and (4)).
40%: Common-pool resource group assignment (course objectives (1), (3), and (4)).
45%: Final individual exam or, alternatively, a Simulation individual assignment (course objectives (2) and (3)).
A necessary condition for passing the course is (i) the attendance of at least 75% of the seminars and (ii) completing any seminar activities assigned by the seminar instructor.
A sufficient condition for passing the course is a final weighted-average grade of 6.00 (a weighted-average grade between 5.50–6.00 is rounded up to 6.00).
literature:
Most of the formal models are discussed in Samuel Bowles. 2004. Microeconomics: Behavior, Institutions, and Evolution. Princeton University Press. Particularly, chapters 1, 2, and 4.
We will additionally read and engage with the work of Ronald Coase, Daron Acemoglu, Elinor Ostrom, recent advances in the theory of networks, stratification economics (William Darity Jr.), and critical approaches to political economy.
additional_information_target_audience: Second-year PPE students.
recommended_background_knowledge: There are no additional prerequisites beyond the standard compulsory first-year PPE courses (particularly, ‘Methods of PPE I’ and ‘Foundations of Microeconomics’). Courses in the PPE specialisation track ‘Economics’ are helpful.
